  • 1 plant mister

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: To make the biga, mix all-purpose flour, instant yeast, and water in a medium bowl, cover the bowl, and let rest for about 12 hours, or overnight.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: To make the dough, use your fingers to pull the biga into walnut-size pieces, and place the pieces in the bowl of a stand mixer.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Add instant yeast, nonfat dry milk, salt, water, olive oil, and all-purpose flour to the biga and beat slowly with a flat beater paddle or beaters for about 3 minutes.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Replace the beater paddle with the dough hook, increase the speed to medium, and knead for 10 minutes. The dough should be very sticky and slack.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Transfer the dough to a lightly greased bowl or dough-rising bucket, cover the bowl or bucket, and let the dough rise for 2 to 3 hours, gently deflating it and turning it over every 45 minutes or so.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Transfer the dough to a lightly greased work surface and use a bench knife or dough scraper to divide it in half.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Working with one half at a time, shape the dough into a rough log.

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text: Transfer the log to a parchment-lined baking sheet, or one sprinkled with cornmeal or semolina, and flatten it into an irregular 10" X 4" oval.

docs.title: Step 9
docs.text: Use your fingers, your entire finger, not just the tip, to indent the surface of the dough vigorously and thoroughly. Repeat with the remaining piece of dough.

docs.title: Step 10
docs.text: Cover the loaves with heavily greased plastic wrap or reusable cover, and set them aside to rise until very puffy, 2 to 3 hours, depending on the warmth of your kitchen.

docs.title: Step 11
docs.text: Half an hour before you want to make the bread, preheat the oven to 425°F. Spritz water into the oven with a clean plant mister for about 5 seconds. Place the bread in the oven and spritz water into the oven three more times during the first 10 minutes of baking.

docs.title: Step 12
docs.text: Bake the loaves for total of about 25 minutes, or until they're a deep golden brown and their interior temperature measures 210°F.

docs.title: Step 13
docs.text: Remove the loaves from the pan and return them to the oven. Turn off the oven, crack the door open a couple of inches, and let the loaves cool completely in the oven.

docs.title: Step 14
docs.text: Dust the loaves generously with flour.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text:
• The King Arthur Baking Company All-Purpose Baker's Companion
  • https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bRGHpCNl72o

docs.title: Cinnamon Raisin Sourdough Bread
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 1 loaf 3.75 hours

docs.title: Ingredients - Dough
docs.text:
• 360 g all-purpose flour
  • 113 g sourdough starter
  • 2.5 tsp instant yeast
  • 1 Tbsp granulated sugar
  • 8 g salt
  • 1 large egg
  • 71 g unsalted butter
  • 152 g water

docs.title: Ingredients - Filling
docs.text:
Serves 1
  • 50 g granulated sugar
  • 1.5 tsp cinnamon
  • 2 tsp all-purpose flour
  • 1 egg
  • 1 Tbsp water
  • 74 g raisins
  • some unsalted butter (optional)
Serves 2
  • 100 g granulated sugar
  • 3 tsp cinnamon
  • 4 tsp all-purpose flour
  • 1 egg
  • 1 Tbsp water
  • 148 g raisins
  • some unsalted butter (optional)

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 lightly greased container
  • 1 aluminum foil

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Weigh your all-purpose flour; or measure it by gently spooning it into a cup, then sweeping off any excess. Combine sourdough starter, ripe (fed) or discard, instant yeast, granulated sugar, salt, egg, room temperature unsalted butter, lukewarm water and mix and knead — using your hands, a stand mixer, or a bread machine set on the dough cycle — to make a soft, smooth dough.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Place the dough in a lightly greased container, and allow it to rise for 1 1/2 to 2 hours, until it's just about doubled in bulk.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: To make the filling: While the dough is rising, make the filling by stirring together the granulated sugar, cinnamon, and all-purpose flour.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Gently deflate the dough, and transfer it to a lightly greased work surface.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Roll and pat the dough into a rough rectangle approximately 6" x 20".

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Brush the dough with the egg and water mixture and sprinkle it evenly with the filling and raisins, leaving a bare strip about 1" wide along one short edge; this will make the log you're about to roll easier to seal.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Starting with the short end that's covered with filling, roll the dough into a log. Pinch the ends to seal, and pinch the long seam closed.

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text: Transfer the log, seam-side down, to a lightly greased 9" x 5" loaf pan. Cover and allow the bread to rise until it's crested about 1" over the rim of the pan, about 1 hour.

docs.title: Step 9
docs.text: While the dough is rising, preheat the oven to 350°F.

docs.title: Step 10
docs.text: Bake the bread for 40 to 45 minutes, tenting it lightly with aluminum foil after the first 15 to 20 minutes. The bread's crust will be golden brown, and the interior of the finished loaf should measure 190°F on a digital thermometer.

docs.title: Step 11
docs.text: Remove the bread from the oven, and gently loosen the edges. Turn it out of the pan, and brush the top surface with unsalted butter (optional), if desired; this will give it a soft, satiny crust. Allow the bread to cool completely before slicing.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.kingarthurbaking.com/recipes/cinnamon-raisin-sourdough-bread-recipe

docs.title: Cinnamon Streusel Bread
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 16 1 hour

docs.title: Ingredients - Cinnamon Sugar Swirl
docs.text:
• 0.5 cup brown sugar
  • 2 tsp ground cinnamon
  • 1 pinch salt

docs.title: Ingredients - Bread
docs.text:
• 0.75 cup butter
  • 0.33 cup granulated sugar
  • 0.33 cup light brown sugar
  • 2 large eggs
  • 1 Tbsp vanilla
  • 2.25 cups all-purpose flour
  • 2 tsp baking powder
  • 0.5 tsp baking soda
  • 1 tsp cinnamon
  • 1 tsp salt
  • 1 cup buttermilk

docs.title: Ingredients - Cinnamon Streusel Topping
docs.text:
• 0.75 cup all-purpose flour
  • 0.33 cup brown sugar
  • 2 tsp cinnamon
  • some salt
  • 6 Tbsp butter

docs.title: Ingredients - Vanilla Glaze
docs.text:
• 1 cup powdered sugar
  • 0.5 tsp vanilla
  • 1 Tbsp butter, melted
  • 1 Tbsp milk or cream
  • 1 pinch salt

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 1 pound loaf pan
  • 1 parchment paper
  • 1 small bowl
  • 1 stand mixer
  • 1 rubber spatula
  • 1 butter knife
  • 1 wire rack
  • 1 small bowl

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Preheat the oven to 350°F and line a 1 pound loaf pan with parchment paper on all sides. Set aside.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: In a small bowl, combine 1/2 cup brown sugar, 2 teaspoons ground cinnamon, and a pinch of salt to make the cinnamon sugar swirl. Mix together and set aside.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: In a stand mixer fit with the whisk attachment, cream the butter, granulated sugar and light brown sugar together until light and fluffy, about 2 minutes.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Scrape down the sides of the bowl and add the eggs and vanilla extract, beating until smooth and well combined.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: In a separate bowl combine the all-purpose flour, baking powder, baking soda, cinnamon, and salt. Stir to evenly distributed everything.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Add about half of the dry ingredients and mix. Next, add the buttermilk and mix. Add the remaining dry ingredients and mix until no streaks of flour remain. Do not over mix.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Spoon half the batter into your prepared pan and use a greased rubber spatula to spread the batter to the edges. Top with the cinnamon sugar mixture. Spoon the remaining batter over the sugar and spread to the edges of the pan.

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text: Use a butter knife to make big swirls in your bread, dragging your knife through the bread a few times.

docs.title: Step 9
docs.text: Make the streusel topping (I usually just do this in the dirty bowl you made the batter in because I am lazy, but you can also use a clean bowl). Combine the all-purpose flour, brown sugar, cinnamon, and salt and stir to combine. Add the melted butter and mix until the mixture resembles wet sand and clumps together.

docs.title: Step 10
docs.text: Sprinkle the streusel evenly over the top of your bread.

docs.title: Step 11
docs.text: Bake for 45 minutes or until a knife inserted into he middle comes out mostly clean and the bread is golden brown. Transfer to a wire rack to cool.

docs.title: Step 12
docs.text: While the bread cools, make the vanilla glaze. Combine 1 cup powdered sugar, 1/2 teaspoon vanilla extract, 1 tablespoon butter, melted, 1 tablespoon milk or cream, pinch of salt to make the glaze in a small bowl and whisk together until smooth and creamy.

docs.title: Step 13
docs.text: Once the bread is cool, drizzle with the glaze and enjoy!

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://bromabakery.com/cinnamon-streusel-bread/

docs.title: Cornbread
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 12 35 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 85 g cornmeal
  • 213 g all-purpose flour
  • 141 g granulated sugar
  • 1 Tbsp baking powder
  • 0.5 tsp salt
  • 0.33 cup oil
  • 42 g unsalted butter
  • 2 large eggs
  • 1.25 cups milk

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 8 X 8 or 9 X 9 inch baking pan
  • 1 large bowl
  • 1 whisk or rubber spatula

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Preheat the oven to 350°F. Lightly grease an 8 X 8 or 9 X 9 inch baking pan (I always use metal; glass pans will bake differently).

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: For the cornbread, in a large bowl, whisk together the cornmeal, all-purpose flour, granulated sugar, baking powder, and salt. Add the oil, unsalted butter, beaten eggs, and milk and stir with a whisk or rubber spatula until just combined. The batter will be runny.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Spread the batter evenly in the prepared pan. Bake for 30 to 35 minutes until a toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean or with a few moist crumbs.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text:
• https://www.melskitchencafe.com/the-cornbread-and-fluffy-honey-butter/
  • https://www.thepancakeprincess.com/2019/11/24/best-sweet-cornbread-bake-off/

docs.title: Cranberry Orange Bread
docs.text: Total Time 1.50 hours

docs.title: Ingredients - Cake
docs.text:
• 2 cup (240 g) whole wheat pastry flour
  • 1 cup (198 g) granulated sugar
  • 1 tsp baking powder
  • 0.25 tsp baking soda
  • 1 tsp salt
  • 6 Tbsp (85 g) melted butter
  • 1 egg
  • 0.67 cup (151 g) buttermilk
  • 1 large orange zest
  • 0.75 tsp vanilla
  • 0.33 cup (76 g) orange juice
  • 1 cup (114 g) dried cranberries
  • 0.5 cup almonds (optional)

docs.title: Ingredients - Glaze
docs.text:
• 2 Tbsp (28 g) unsalted butter
  • 0.5 cup (57 g) confectioners' sugar
  • 2 Tbsp orange juice
  • 0.5 tsp vanilla

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 9x5 loaf pan
  • 1 large bowl
  • 1 small bowl

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Preheat oven to 370°F. Grease (optional) a 9x5 loaf pan. Soak dried cranberries in hot water for 0.5 hours or overnight.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: In a large bowl, whisk together whole wheat pastry flour, granulated sugar, baking powder, baking soda, and salt.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: In a small bowl, whisk together melted butter, egg, buttermilk, orange zest, vanilla, and orange juice.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Add wet ingredients to dry and stir until just combined.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Gently fold in dried cranberries (and chopped and roasted almonds (optional), if using).

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Bake and check at 35 minutes. Keep baking until golden brown (around 45 minutes).

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Cool in pan for 10 minutes.

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text:
Prepare glaze by simply whisking together the melted unsalted butter, confectioners' sugar, orange juice and vanilla, then pour glaze over the loaf. Allow to set a few minutes, then enjoy!

Note

If using fresh cranberries, use 2 cups of them and increase the amount of granulated sugar.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • Recipe Box

docs.title: Croissants
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 12 1.13 hours

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 500 g strong white bread flour
  • 10 g salt
  • 80 g granulated sugar
  • 10 g instant yeast
  • 300 ml water
  • 300 g unsalted butter
  • 1 egg

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 mixer
  • 1 dough hook
  • 1 plastic bag

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Put the strong white bread flour into a bowl of a mixer fitted with a dough hook. Add the salt and caster sugar to one side of the bowl and the instant yeast to the other. Add the cool water and mix on a slow speed for 2 minutes, then on a medium speed for 6 minutes. The dough should be fairly stiff.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Tip the dough out onto a lightly floured surface and shape it into a ball. Dust with flour, put into a clean plastic bag and chill in the fridge for 1 hour.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: On a lightly floured surface, roll out your dough to a rectangle, about 60 x 20cm; it should be about 1cm thick. Flatten the unsalted butter to a rectangle, about 40 x 19cm, by bashing it with a rolling pin. Put the butter on the dough so that it covers the bottom two-thirds of the dough. Make sure that it is positioned neatly and comes almost to the edges.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Fold the exposed dough at the top down over one-third of the butter. Now gently cut off the exposed bit of butter, without going through the dough, and put it on the top of the dough you have just folded down. Fold the bottom half of the dough up. You will now have a sandwich of two layers of butter and three of dough. Pinch the edges lightly to seal in the butter. Put the dough back in the plastic bag and chill in the fridge for an hour to harden the butter.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Take the dough out of the bag and put it on the lightly floured work surface with a short end towards you. Roll into a rectangle, about 60 x 20cm, as before. This time fold up one-third of the dough and then fold the top third down on top to make a neat square to make a neat square. This is called a single turn. Put the dough back into the plastic bag and chill for another hour. Repeat this stage twice more, putting the dough back into the fridge for an hour between turns.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Your dough now needs to be left in the fridge for 8 hours, or overnight, to rest and rise slightly.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: When you are ready to shape the croissants, line 2 or 3 baking trays with baking parchment or silicone paper.

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text: Put the dough on a lightly floured surface and roll out to a rectangle, a little more than 42cm long and 30cm wide; it should be about 7mm thick. Trim the edges to neaten them.

docs.title: Step 9
docs.text: Cut the rectangle lengthways into 2 strips, then cut triangles along the length of each strip; these should be 12cm wide at the base and about 15cm high (from the middle of the base to the tip). Once you have cut the first triangle, you can use it as a template for the rest. You should get 6 triangles from each strip.

docs.title: Step 10
docs.text: Before rolling, hold down the wide base of the triangle and gently tug the opposite thin end to cause a slight tension in the dough. Now starting at the thick end of the triangle, roll up into a croissant. You will have 12 medium-sized croissants. For a traditional crescent shape, turn the ends in towards each other slightly.

docs.title: Step 11
docs.text: Put the croissants on the prepared baking trays, leaving space in between them to expand; allow 4 – 6 per tray. Put each tray inside a clean plastic bag and leave the croissants to rise at cool room temperature (18 – 24°C) until at least doubled in size. This should take about 2 hours.

docs.title: Step 12
docs.text: Heat your oven to 200°C (400°F).

docs.title: Step 13
docs.text: Lightly whisk the egg with a pinch of salt to make an egg wash. Brush the top and sides of the croissants with the eggwash. Bake for 15 – 20 minutes or until golden brown. Cool on a wire rack. Eat warm.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.paulhollywood.com/post/croissants

docs.title: Delicious Zucchini Bread
docs.text: Total Time 60 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 2 cups all-purpose flour
  • 1 tsp baking soda
  • 1 tsp salt
  • 3 eggs
  • 3 tsp vanilla
  • 1 cup oil
  • 2 cups zucchini

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 5 x 9 loaf pans
  • 1 electric mixer

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Preheat oven to 350°F

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Grease and flour two 5 x 9 loaf pans.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Whisk all-purpose flour, baking soda, and salt together. In a separate bowl, put eggs, vanilla, oil, and peeled zucchini and dry ingredients in bowl of electric mixer in the order given (sift dry ingredients together) and beat until well mixed.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Bake 45 minutes to 1 hour. It is done when you stick a knife in it and it comes out clean.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • Tante Myrna Seccia

docs.title: Flour Tortillas
docs.text: Total Time 18 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 360 g all-purpose flour
  • 1 tsp salt
  • 1 tsp baking powder
  • 66 g vegetable oil
  • 227 g warm water

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 medium-size bowl
  • 1 silicone spatula or a sturdy wooden spoon
  • 1 rolling pin

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Combine all-purpose flour, salt and baking powder in a medium-size bowl. Using a sturdy silicone spatula or a sturdy wooden spoon, mix dry ingredients until well combined.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Make a well in the center of the dry ingredients and add the vegetable oil and warm water. Stir well from the bottom up, until all dry ingredients are incorporated and the dough begins to come together and form a shaggy ball.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Turn dough out onto a lightly floured work surface and knead for 1 to 2 minutes until the dough is nice and smooth. Proceed with step number 6 below for the remainder of the recipe.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Combine flour, salt and baking powder in the bowl of a stand mixer. Using the dough hook, mix dry ingredients until well combined.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Add oil and water with mixer running at a medium speed. After about 1 minute, or when mixture comes together and begins to form a ball, decrease mixing speed to low. Continue to mix for 1 minute or until dough is smooth.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Transfer dough to a lightly floured work surface. Divide into 16 equal portions. Turn each piece to coat with flour. Form each piece into a ball and flatten with the palm of your hand. Cover flattened balls of dough with a clean kitchen towel and allow to rest for at least 15 minutes (or as much as 2 hours) before proceeding.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: After the rest period, heat a large pan over medium heat. Roll each dough piece into a rough circle, about 6 to 7 inches in diameter, keep work surface and rolling pin lightly floured. Don’t stack uncooked tortillas on top of each other or they will stick together. (I like to separate my tortillas with parchment paper.)

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text: When the pan is hot, place one dough circle into the pan and allow to cook 45 seconds to 1 minute or until the bottom surface has a few pale brown spots and the uncooked surface is bubbly. If browning too fast, reduce the heat a bit. If it’s taking longer than a minute to see a few pale golden brown spots on the underside of tortillas, increase the heat a bit. Flip to other side and cook for 15 to 20 seconds. The tortillas should be nice and soft but have a few small brown spots on the surface.

docs.title: Step 9
docs.text: Remove from pan with tongs and stack in a covered container or zippered bag to keep the tortillas soft.

docs.title: Step 10
docs.text: Serve warm or allow to cool for later use. When ready to use, place a slightly damp paper towel in the bottom of a microwave-safe container (with a cover) that will hold the stacked tortillas. Microwave uncovered for 15 to 30 seconds (start with 15) or until warm, then keep covered to hold heat while serving.

docs.title: Step 11
docs.text: Store in an airtight container or zippered bag at room temperature for 24 hours or refrigerate for up to 1 week. To freeze, separate tortillas with parchment paper or waxed paper and place in a zippered bag before placing in the freezer.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://thecafesucrefarine.com/best-ever-homemade-flour-tortillas/

docs.title: French Bread
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 2 loaves 19.88 hours

docs.title: Ingredients - Preferment
docs.text:
• 222 g all-purpose flour
  • 0.25 generous tsp instant yeast
  • 222 g cool water

docs.title: Ingredients - Dough
docs.text:
• 319 g warm water
  • 519 g all-purpose flour
  • 15 g salt
  • 0.5 scant tsp instant yeast

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 medium bowl
  • 1 bowl scraper
  • 1 round or oval proofing baskets (brotforms)
  • 1 cast iron skillet
  • 1 parchment
  • 1 baker’s lame or razor blade

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Weigh your flour; or measure it by gently spooning it into a cup, then sweeping off any excess.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: The evening before you want to bake, make the poolish preferment. In a medium bowl, combine the all-purpose flour, instant yeast, and cool water. Mix until no dry patches of flour remain. Cover and let it rest overnight at room temperature, 12 to 16 hours.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Add the warm water to the preferment, then squeeze the preferment through your fingers to break it up. Next, holding your hand in a claw-like position, vigorously mix the preferment into the water until well combined. The mixture will look like foamy milk with some small pieces of preferment still visible.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Add the all-purpose flour, salt, and instant yeast, mixing well until no dry spots remain. Using a wet hand and a light touch, quickly work the dough against the side of the bowl until it begins to smooth out and is tacky.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Once you’ve mixed your dough, let it rest, covered, for 20 minutes.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: To fold the dough. Using a wet hand or bowl scraper, reach down between the side of the bowl and the dough, as though you were going to lift the dough out. Instead of lifting, stretch the bottom of the dough up and over its top. Repeat 8 to 12 more times, working your way around the bowl. This process of stretching the dough, which takes the place of kneading, is called a bowl fold.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Cover and let the dough rest for another 20 minutes, then perform another bowl fold.

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text: Let the dough rest for 20 minutes, then perform a coil fold. With wet hands, reach under the dough and stretch the middle upward until the dough releases from the dish. Roll it forward off your hands, allowing it to fold over (or “coil”) on itself. Rotate the bowl 90° (a quarter turn) and repeat 2 to 3 more times, until the dough resists stretching.

docs.title: Step 9
docs.text: Cover and let the dough rest at room temperature for 1 hour, or until it feels very puffy and marshmallowy.

docs.title: Step 10
docs.text: Use a bowl scraper to gently ease the dough out of the bowl and onto a work surface lightly dusted with flour, then divide the dough into 2 even pieces (650 g each).

docs.title: Step 11
docs.text: Gently preshape each piece of dough into a round.

docs.title: Step 12
docs.text: Cover the preshaped dough and let it rest on a lightly floured surface for 15 minutes.

docs.title: Step 13
docs.text: Generously dust two 9" x 3" round or oval proofing baskets (brotforms) with flour. Shape each piece of dough into a boule or bâtard, then place them seam-side up in the prepared baskets.

docs.title: Step 14
docs.text: Cover the baskets and let the dough rise until it looks and feels marshmallowy and a small indentation remains when pressed with a floured finger, 45 minutes to 1 hour. Meanwhile, preheat the oven to 475°F with a baking steel or stone on the middle rack and an empty cast iron skillet or a cake pan filled with lava rocks on the rack below. If possible, adjust the stone and pan so that the skillet isn't directly under the stone, making it easier for steam to reach the baking bread.

docs.title: Step 15
docs.text: When ready to bake, gently invert the loaves side by side onto a sheet of parchment. Use a baker’s lame or razor blade to score the tops of the loaves.

docs.title: Step 16
docs.text: Load the loaves (still on the parchment) into the oven, placing them on the stone, and carefully pour about 1 cup (roughly 227 g) warm water into the skillet.

docs.title: Step 17
docs.text:
Bake the loaves for 32 to 38 minutes, until the crust is firm and medium golden brown. Let the loaves cool completely before slicing. French bread is best eaten the day it's baked. Freeze for longer storage.

Tip

If you’d like, you can replace the generous 1/4 teaspoon instant yeast in the preferment with 1 tablespoon (14 g) sourdough culture for more flavor.

Tip

You can substitute up to 25% whole wheat in place of some of the all-purpose flour in the final dough without making any significant changes to hydration. To do this, make the preferment as written, then use 3 1/4 cups (390 g) all-purpose flour and 1 cup plus 2 1/2 tablespoons (130g) whole wheat flour in the dough. All other instructions remain the same.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text:
• https://www.kingarthurbaking.com/recipes/everyday-french-loaf-recipe
  • https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=A-QvjTmSJyY

docs.title: Garlic Bread
docs.text: Total Time 2 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
Serves 3-4
  • 1 sticks (113 g) butter, softened
  • 1 cloves garlic, minced
  • 0.5 scallion, minced
  • 0.5 Tbsp Parmesan
  • 0.5 Tbsp parsley
  • some hot sauce
  • some salt
  • some pepper
  • 1 French baguette
Serves 6-8
  • 2 sticks (227 g) butter, softened
  • 2 cloves garlic, minced
  • 1 scallion, minced
  • 1 Tbsp Parmesan
  • 1 Tbsp parsley
  • some hot sauce
  • some salt
  • some pepper
  • 1 French baguette

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text: • 1 small bowl

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Preheat broiler with rack 4 inches from heat.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: In a small bowl, mix butter, softened, together with garlic, minced, scallion, minced, Parmesan, parsley, hot sauce to taste and salt and pepper, to taste.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Slice French baguette horizontally.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Spread butter on both halves.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Place on a sheet pan and toast under the broiler, about 2 minutes.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text:
• https://www.foodnetwork.com/recipes/guy-fieri/garlic-bread-recipe-1944539
  • https://www.thekitchn.com/garlic-bread-recipe-reviews-23116514

docs.title: Gilligan Monkey Bread
docs.text: Total Time 35 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients - Bread
docs.text:
• 2 Bridgeford loaves
  • 114 g butter
  • 198 g cinnamon and sugar
  • 198 g Pecans or walnuts (optional)

docs.title: Ingredients - Glaze
docs.text:
• 114 g confectioners' sugar (optional)
  • 2 Tbsp milk (optional)
  • 1 tsp vanilla (optional)

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 Bundt pan
  • 1 plastic wrap
  • 1 platter

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Cut up partially defrosted Bridgeford loaves.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Dip them in melted butter, then roll them (one piece at a time) in cinnamon and sugar mixture.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Place each piece in a well prepared Bundt pan.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: At this point you can let it rise before baking or cover it up with plastic wrap and then foil to bake the next morning.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Remove from the fridge and preheat the oven to 350°F. Bake around 30 to 35 minutes or longer, but keep watch. You don't want to over or under bake it, so be sure it's done when you remove from the oven.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Invert carefully on a platter. Give it a few minutes to let all the syrup out before removing the pan.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: At this point, you can serve it, or top it with a glaze made of confectioners' sugar (optional), milk (optional) and vanilla (optional)).

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text: Pecans or walnuts (optional) may be added when prepping.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text:
• Gilligan Family
  • https://www.melskitchencafe.com/the-best-monkey-bread/

docs.title: Grilled Naan
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 8 5.5 hours

docs.title: Ingredients - Sponge
docs.text:
• 177 g all-purpose flour
  • 53 g whole wheat flour
  • 1/4 tsp instant yeast
  • 170 g water

docs.title: Ingredients - Dough
docs.text:
• 270 g all-purpose flour
  • 9 g tsp salt
  • 1/2 tsp baking soda
  • 1 tsp cream of tarter
  • 170 g full-fat plain Greek yogurt or whole milk

docs.title: Ingredients - Topping
docs.text:
• 28 g ghee or butter
  • 2 tsp nigella seeds (optional)
  • 0.25 cup cilantro

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 large bowl
  • 1 cast iron pan

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: To make the sponge: Weigh your flour; or measure it by gently spooning it into a cup, then sweeping off any excess. Mix the sponge ingredients together in a mixing bowl. Cover the bowl and set it aside for 4 hours (or up to about 16 hours), until the mixture is bubbly and has a nice aroma.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: To make the dough: Add the dough ingredients to the sponge, and mix and knead to make a smooth, soft (but not sticky) dough. Adjust its consistency with additional flour or water, if necessary.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Divide the dough into 8 balls (106 g each, about 2 1/4", the size of a tennis ball). Let them rest, covered, for a half hour in the refrigerator.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Stretch each ball into an oval shape a scant 1/4" thick.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: To grill the naan: Heat your grill on high; make sure it gets good and hot. Brush one side of the flatbread with oil and lay it, oiled side down, on the grill grate. Close the grill lid (if your grill has a lid). After 1 minute, pick up the bread with a spatula, turn it 45°, and put it back down to cook for another minute; it'll start to puff up a bit. Oil the top side, then turn it over, cover the grill or pan, and cook for 2 minutes to finish. Remove the naan from the heat. Repeat with the remaining pieces of dough.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: To cook naan on the stovetop: Heat a cast iron pan over medium-high heat. Brush one side of the naan with oil, and lay it into the pan. Cover the cooking bread with a pot lid; start checking after 1 minute; the bottom should be turning golden brown. If not, give it more time. Oil the top side, turn it over, and cook for an additional couple of minutes or so, until brown and cooked all the way through. Remove the naan from the heat. Repeat with the remaining pieces of dough.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: To serve, brush the naan with melted butter or ghee, and season it with salt and pepper while it's still hot. Stack the breads to keep them soft.

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text:
Store naan, well-wrapped, on the counter for two days; freeze for longer storage.

Tip

If you'd prefer to bake the naan, place them on a parchment-lined baking sheet (or directly on a baking stone), and bake them on the bottom rack of a preheated 450°F oven for 6 to 8 minutes, until they're puffed and golden.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.kingarthurbaking.com/recipes/grilled-naan-recipe

docs.title: Honey Beer Bread
docs.text: Total Time 60 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 3 cups (360 g) flour
  • 2 Tbsp sugar
  • 1 Tbsp baking powder
  • 1 tsp salt
  • 1 12-oz bottle beer
  • 2 Tbsp (42 g) honey
  • 4 Tbsp (57 g) butter

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 loaf pan
  • 1 pan
  • 1 Spoon

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Preheat oven to 350°F.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Grease loaf pan.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Whisk together flour, sugar, baking powder, and salt. Stir in beer and melted honey.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Pour half melted butter into pan. Spoon in batter and pour rest of butter on top.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Bake 50 to 60 minutes.

docs.title: Honey Challah with Assorted Toppings
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 6 large or 8 medium challahs 3.08 hours

docs.title: Ingredients - Dough
docs.text:
• 1.5 tsp yeast
  • 1 tsp granulated sugar
  • 38 g lukewarm water
  • 84 g honey
  • 1 tsp salt
  • 41 g vegetable oil
  • 0.17 egg
  • 114 g lukewarm water
  • 378 g bread flour

docs.title: Ingredients - Sweet Crumb Topping
docs.text:
• 20 g bread flour
  • 33 g granulated sugar
  • 16.5 g vegetable oil
  • 0.25 tsp vanilla
  • 1 pinch salt

docs.title: Ingredients - Honey or Maple Syrup Glaze
docs.text:
• some honey (optional)
  • some maple syrup (optional)

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 bowl
  • 1 spoon

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Add the yeast, granulated sugar and 38 g lukewarm water to a bowl and rest for a few minutes until the yeast starts to bloom. Add the honey, salt, 41 g vegetable oil and egg and mix to incorporate. Stir in 114 g of lukewarm water.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Add half of the bread flour and mix with a spoon until creamy. Add almost all of the rest of the flour (leaving over 1/2 cup or so) and knead with your hands until your dough is smooth and elastic, adding more flour as needed, until the dough is no longer sticky.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: When you are done kneading, grease the dough with remaining oil and cover it with a towel. Put it in a warm place (I like to put my oven on 200 degrees and put it on top of the oven). Leave the dough to rise for 1.5 to 2 hours. Pound it down, take challa for hafrashas challah, and braid. When you are done shaping the loaves, leave them to rise for 30 minutes. Brush with egg and topping of your choice. Bake at 350°F until golden brown, about 35 minutes. (check the bottoms of the challahs, they should be browned and hollow when you tap on them).

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: For the sweet crumb topping, mix bread flour, granulated sugar, 11 g to 16.5 g vegetable oil, vanilla, salt with a spoon until crumbly and sprinkle over challah.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: You can mix some honey (optional) or maple syrup (optional) in with the egg wash and brush over challah. For more of a sticky glaze, egg wash the challah as usual and bake. As soon as the challah comes out of oven, brush liberally with honey or maple syrup (you can warm it on the stovetop or microwave it to make it easier to spread). You’ll have a sweet and sticky glaze.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text:
• https://busyinbrooklyn.com/honey-challa-with-assorted-toppings/
  • https://www.thekitchn.com/challah-recipe-reviews-22969552
  • https://youtube.com/watch?v=1FcR1PDzC94&si=tDbaP9S1RaTcP5Sp

docs.title: Honey Cornbread
docs.text: Total Time 60 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 1 cup buttermilk
  • 0.67 cup honey
  • 2 large eggs
  • 4 Tbsp unsalted butter
  • 1.25 cup all-purpose flour
  • 1 cup cornmeal
  • 1 tsp salt
  • 1 tsp baking powder
  • 0.25 tsp baking soda

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 8-inch square baking pan
  • 1 bowl
  • 1 large bowl

docs.title: Instructions
docs.text:
Note

Even though we used 2/3 cup, we found that the type of honey didn’t affect the flavor of the cornbread much—except with very strong honey, such as buckwheat. That lent a distinctive deep, molasses-y flavor that some of our tasters didn’t like. The test kitchen’s favorite cornmeal is Anson Mills Fine Yellow Cornmeal.

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Adjust oven rack to middle position and heat oven to 375°F. Grease 8-inch square baking pan. Whisk buttermilk, honey, eggs, and melted unsalted butter in bowl until thoroughly combined and no streaks of honey remain. Whisk all-purpose flour, cornmeal, salt, baking powder, and baking soda together in large bowl.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Whisk buttermilk mixture into flour mixture until thoroughly combined. Transfer batter to prepared pan. Bake until golden brown and toothpick inserted in center comes out clean, 30 to 35 minutes. Let cool in pan for 5 minutes. Remove cornbread from pan and let cool on wire rack for 15 to 20 minutes. Serve.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.cookscountry.com/recipes/7117-honey-cornbread

docs.title: Irish Soda Bread
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 1 9" loaf 55 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 276 g Irish-style flour
  • 150 g bread flour
  • 37 g granulated sugar
  • 1 tsp baking soda
  • 1.5 tsp kosher salt
  • 95 g currants
  • 99 g raisins (alternative)
  • 57 g unsalted butter
  • 302 g buttermilk
  • 1 large egg
  • 254 g whole wheat (alternative)
  • 150 g all-purpose flour (alternative)

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 8" or 9" round cake pan
  • 1 medium-sized mixing bowl
  • 1 mixer
  • 1 bowl
  • 1 sharp knife

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Preheat the oven to 400°F. Lightly grease an 8" or 9" round cake pan.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: In a medium-sized mixing bowl, whisk together the Irish-style flour, bread flour, granulated sugar, baking soda, kosher salt, and currants or raisins (alternative).

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Using a mixer, a pastry fork or blender, or your fingers, work in the unsalted butter until it's evenly distributed and no large chunks remain.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: In a separate bowl (or in a measuring cup) whisk together the buttermilk and egg. Pour this mixture into the dry ingredients and mix to combine. The dough will be stiff; if it's too crumbly to squeeze together, add another tablespoon or two of buttermilk.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Knead the dough a couple of times to make sure it's holding together, then shape it into a ball. Flatten the ball slightly, and place the loaf in your pan. Use a sharp knife to cut a 1/2" deep cross in the loaf.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Bake the bread for about 45 to 55 minutes, until it's golden brown and a cake tester or toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean. Remove the bread from the oven and brush the top with melted butter.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text:
Store for about 2 days, well wrapped, at room temperature; freeze for longer storage (up to about a month).

Tip

Our Irish-style flour will result in a soda bread with superior flavor and texture. Substituting premium whole wheat or white whole wheat flour is fine, but you'll want to reduce the amount of whole wheat (alternative) to 2 1/4 cups and substitute the bread flour with all-purpose flour (alternative).

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.kingarthurbaking.com/recipes/irish-soda-bread-recipe

docs.title: Japanese Milk Bread Rolls
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 10 3.08 hours

docs.title: Ratios
docs.text: flour  water  milk 1 part 3 parts 3 parts

docs.title: Ingredients - Tangzhong
docs.text:
• 14 g bread flour
  • 43 g water
  • 43 g whole milk

docs.title: Ingredients - Dough
docs.text:
• 300 g bread flour
  • 14 g milk powder
  • 50 g granulated sugar
  • 2 tsp salt
  • 1 Tbsp instant yeast
  • 113 g whole milk
  • 1 large egg
  • 57 g unsalted butter

docs.title: Ingredients - Egg Wash
docs.text:
• 1 large egg
  • 1 Tbsp cold water

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 small saucepan
  • 1 small mixing bowl
  • 1 8" or 9" round cake pan

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Weigh your bread flour; or measure it by gently spooning it into a cup, then sweeping off any excess.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: To make the tangzhong: Combine bread flour, water, and whole milk in a small saucepan, and whisk until no lumps remain.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Place the saucepan over low heat, and cook the mixture, whisking constantly, until thick and the whisk leaves lines on the bottom of the pan, about 3 to 5 minutes.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Transfer the tangzhong to a small mixing bowl or measuring cup and let it cool to room temperature.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: To make the dough: Combine the tangzhong with the bread flour, milk powder, granulated sugar, salt, instant yeast, whole milk, egg, and melted unsalted butter, then mix and knead - by hand, mixer, or bread machine - until a smooth, elastic dough forms.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Shape the dough into a ball, and let it rest in a lightly greased covered bowl for 60 to 90 minutes, until puffy but not necessarily doubled in bulk.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Gently deflate the dough, divide it into 8 equal pieces (for large rolls) or 10 equal pieces (for medium-sized rolls), and shape each piece into a ball.

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text: Place the rolls into a lightly greased 8" or 9" round cake pan. Cover the pan, and let the rolls rest for 40 to 50 minutes, until puffy.

docs.title: Step 9
docs.text: Preheat the oven to 350°F. Brush the rolls with milk or egg wash (1 large egg beaten with 1 tablespoon cold water), and bake for 25 to 30 minutes, until golden brown on top; a digital thermometer inserted into the center of the middle roll should read at least 190°F.

docs.title: Step 10
docs.text: Remove the rolls from the oven. Allow them to cool in the pan for 10 minutes, then transfer them to a rack to cool completely.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.kingarthurbaking.com/recipes/japanese-milk-bread-rolls-recipe

docs.title: Japanese Milk Bread
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 1 loaf 3.25 hours

docs.title: Ratios
docs.text: flour  water  milk 1 part 3 parts 3 parts

docs.title: Ingredients - Tangzhong
docs.text:
• 43 g water
  • 43 g whole milk
  • 14 g bread flour

docs.title: Ingredients - Dough
docs.text:
• 300 g bread flour
  • 14 g dry milk
  • 50 g granulated sugar
  • 6 g salt
  • 1 Tbsp instant yeast
  • 113 g whole milk
  • 1 large egg
  • 57 g unsalted butter

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 small saucepan
  • 1 small mixing bowl or measuring cup
  • 1 lightly greased bowl
  • 1 9" x 5" loaf pan

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Combine water, whole milk, and bread flour in a small saucepan, and whisk until no lumps remain.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Place the saucepan over low heat and cook the mixture, whisking constantly, until thick and the whisk leaves lines on the bottom of the pan, about 3 to 5 minutes.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Transfer the tangzhong to a small mixing bowl or measuring cup and let it cool to lukewarm.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Weigh your flour; or measure it by gently spooning it into a cup, then sweeping off any excess. Combine the tangzhong with the bread flour, dry milk, granulated sugar, salt, instant yeast, whole milk, egg, and melted unsalted butter, then mix and knead — by mixer or bread machine — until a smooth, elastic dough forms; this could take almost 15 minutes in a stand mixer.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Shape the dough into a ball, and let it rest in a lightly greased bowl, covered, for 1 to 1.5 hours, until puffy but not necessarily doubled in bulk.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Gently deflate the dough and divide it into four equal pieces; if you have a scale each piece will weigh between 170 g and 175 g.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Round each piece of dough into a rough ball by pulling the edges into the center. Cover with greased plastic wrap, and let rest for 15 minutes; or for up to 1 hour, if that works better with your schedule.

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text: Flatten each piece of dough into a 5" x 8" rectangle, then fold the short ends in towards one another like a letter. Flatten the folded pieces into rectangles again (this time about 3" x 6") and, starting with a short end, roll them each into a 4" log.

docs.title: Step 9
docs.text: Place the logs in a row of four — seam side down and side by side — in a lightly greased 9" x 5" loaf pan.

docs.title: Step 10
docs.text: Cover the loaf and allow it to rest/rise for 40 to 50 minutes, until puffy.

docs.title: Step 11
docs.text: Towards the end of the rising time, preheat the oven to 350°F.

docs.title: Step 12
docs.text: To bake the bread: Brush the loaf with milk and bake it for 30 to 35 minutes, until it's golden brown on top and a digital thermometer inserted into the center reads at least 190°F.

docs.title: Step 13
docs.text: Remove the loaf from the oven and cool it in the pan until you can transfer it safely to a rack to cool completely.

docs.title: Step 14
docs.text: Store leftover bread, well wrapped, at cool room temperature for 5 to 7 days; freeze for longer storage.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.kingarthurbaking.com/recipes/japanese-milk-bread-recipe

docs.title: Lemon Blueberry Bread
docs.text: Total Time 50 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 0.75 cups melted coconut oil
  • 1 cup sugar
  • 3 eggs
  • 0.5 tsp vanilla
  • 2 Tbsp lemon zest
  • 1 cup yogurt
  • 0.25 cup lemon juice
  • 2 cups flour
  • 1 tsp baking powder
  • 0.5 tsp baking soda
  • 0.5 tsp salt
  • 2 Tbsp flaxmeal
  • 1 cup blueberries
  • 2 tsp lemon juice
  • 1 cup powdered sugar

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 loaf pan
  • 1 parchment paper
  • 1 bowl

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Preheat oven to 350°F. Line a loaf pan with parchment paper.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Combine melted coconut oil, sugar, eggs, vanilla, lemon zest, yogurt, and 1/4 cup lemon juice.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: In a separate bowl, combine flour, baking powder, and baking soda. Add salt.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Combine all ingredients and flaxmeal and fold in blueberries.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Bake approximately 45 to 50 minutes.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: For glaze, whisk together 2 tsp lemon juice and powdered sugar and drizzle over cooled cake.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • Recipe Box

docs.title: Lemon Bread
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 10 1.08 hours

docs.title: Ingredients - Bread
docs.text:
• 1.5 cups all-purpose flour
  • 3.4 oz instant lemon pudding mix
  • 1.2 tsp baking powder
  • 0.5 tsp baking soda
  • 0.5 tsp salt
  • 3 eggs
  • 1 cup granulated sugar
  • 2 Tbsp unsalted butter
  • 1 tsp vanilla
  • 2 tsp lemon extract
  • 0.33 cup lemon juice
  • 0.5 cup vegetable oil
  • 0.75 cup plain Greek yogurt
  • 1 lemon

docs.title: Ingredients - Frosting
docs.text:
• 3 Tbsp butter
  • 3 Tbsp lemon juice
  • 1 tsp lemon extract
  • 1.5 cups confectioners' sugar

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 5 x 9 loaf pan
  • 1 parchment paper
  • 1 mixing bowl
  • 1 stand or hand mixer
  • 1 cooling rack
  • 1 hand or stand mixer

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Preheat oven to 350°F. Line the bottom of a 5 x 9 loaf pan with a piece of parchment paper. (With a pencil, trace the bottom of the pan on a piece of parchment paper and cut out with scissors.) Spray the pan, and parchment paper with non-stick baking spray. Set aside.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: In a mixing bowl, combine the all-purpose flour, instant lemon pudding mix, baking powder, baking soda, and salt. With a stand or hand mixer, combine the eggs, granulated sugar, softened unsalted butter, vanilla, lemon extract, lemon juice, vegetable oil and plain Greek yogurt. Mix until evenly combined. Gradually add the dry ingredients to the wet, stopping to scrape down the sides of the bowl. Add the lemon zest, and mix until just combined. Pour the batter into the prepared loaf pan. Bake for 55 minutes, or until center is fully set, and a toothpick inserted comes out crumb free.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: After baking, let cool in the pan for 5 to 10 minutes. Run a knife around the sides of the pan, invert and remove from the pan, removing the parchment paper from the bottom. Cool completely on a cooling rack.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Combine the butter, lemon juice and lemon extract with hand or stand mixer. Gradually add the confectioners' sugar, and beat until smooth and creamy. Evenly spread the frosting over the top of the loaf. Refrigerate to let frosting set completely before slicing. Refrigerate any leftovers in an airtight container.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text:
• https://lilluna.com/better-than-starbucks-lemon-loaf
  • https://www.thepancakeprincess.com/2022/05/25/best-lemon-loaf-bake-off/

docs.title: Naan
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 8 1.33 hours

docs.title: Ingredients - Dough
docs.text:
• 180 g all-purpose flour
  • 90 g bread flour
  • 142 g warm water
  • 71 g full-fat plain Greek yogurt
  • 28 g ghee or unsalted butter
  • 1.5 tsp instant yeast
  • 1 tsp granulated sugar
  • 2 tsp salt

docs.title: Ingredients - Topping
docs.text:
• 28 g ghee or butter
  • 2 tsp nigella seeds (optional)
  • 0.25 cup cilantro

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 large bowl
  • 1 cast iron pan

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Weigh your flour; or measure it by gently spooning it into a cup, then sweeping off any excess. In a large bowl or the bowl of a stand mixer, combine all-purpose flour, bread flour, warm water, full-fat plain Greek yogurt, melted ghee or unsalted butter, melted, instant yeast, granulated sugar, and salt and mix until shaggy. Knead the dough until it’s smooth, bouncy, and slightly tacky.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Place the dough in a greased bowl, cover, and let it rise until doubled, about 50 to 60 minutes.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Divide the dough into eight equal pieces (about 65 g each). Shape each into a ball, cover, and let rest for 20 minutes.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: While the dough is resting, preheat a cast iron pan over medium-high heat, or an electric griddle to medium-high.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: On a lightly floured surface, hand stretch or use a rolling pin to roll each ball into a 6” round or 7" oblong, for thicker naan; or an 8" round or 10” oblong, for thinner naan. Keep the other pieces covered while working.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Once the pan or griddle is hot, cook the naan for 30 to 40 seconds, until bubbles form on the top side and the underside browns. Flip it over to brown the other side for 40 to 50 seconds, checking regularly to ensure doneness.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Remove the bread from the pan, and brush with melted ghee or butter. Sprinkle with nigella seeds (optional) and cilantro, if desired. Repeat with the remaining pieces of dough. Keep the finished naan in a warm oven (200°F), or wrap in foil until ready to serve.

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text:
Store naan, well wrapped, at room temperature for two days; freeze for longer storage.

Tip

To make garlic naan: Mince 5 to 6 large cloves of garlic. Sprinkle each rolled-out dough circle with minced garlic, pressing it in firmly, before cooking.

Tip

To make stuffed naan: Roll (or preferably hand stretch) each ball into 5” rounds. Place 2 tablespoons of desired filling onto the center of each round; spiced mashed potato, grated cheese, or paneer are all good options. Pull the dough over the filling, pinching the two opposite edges together tightly to seal. Gently roll or hand stretch each ball into a 6” to 8” round before cooking as directed.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.kingarthurbaking.com/recipes/naan-recipe

docs.title: No-Knead Everything Bread
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 1 loaf 11.05 hours

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 660 g bread flour
  • 510 g cool water
  • 0.5 tsp instant yeast
  • 12 g salt
  • 18 g Everything Bagel Topping
  • 25 g olive oil
  • 1 Tbsp Everything Bagel Topping

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 large bowl
  • 1 plastic wrap
  • 1 14" to 15" long lidded stoneware baker or 9" to 10" round lidded baking crock

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Weigh your bread flour; or measure it by gently spooning it into a cup, then sweeping off any excess. Mix the cool water, instant yeast, salt, Everything Bagel Topping, and olive oil in a large bowl to make a sticky dough. Or beat in a stand mixer for 3 minutes.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Cover with plastic wrap, and let rest at room temperature overnight, or for at least 8 hours; the dough will become bubbly and rise quite a bit, so make sure it's in a large bowl.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Lightly grease a 14" to 15" long lidded stoneware baker or 9" to 10" round lidded baking crock. Our bread baking crock and bread pot are both great choices.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Turn the dough onto a generously floured surface; the dough will be slack. To shape the loaf, fold the dough over onto itself using a bench knife or well-floured hands. Because the dough is slightly sticky, it's best to work quickly.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Place the dough in the prepared pan, smooth-side up.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Cover and let rise at room temperature for about 2 hours, until a slight indentation remains when you poke it with your finger.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Just before baking, spritz or brush the dough with water and sprinkle with about 1 tablespoon Everything Bagel Topping over the dough. Using kitchen scissors, make several 1/2" deep cuts in a decorative pattern on the top of the dough to allow the bread to expand.

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text: Replace the lid on the pot and put it in a cold oven; set the temperature to 450°F.

docs.title: Step 9
docs.text: Bake the bread for 50 minutes (start the timer once the bread goes into the oven), then remove the lid and continue to bake for another 5 to 10 minutes, until it's deep brown in color, and a digital thermometer inserted into the center registers about 205°F.

docs.title: Step 10
docs.text: Remove the bread from the oven, turn it onto a rack, and cool before slicing.

docs.title: Step 11
docs.text: Store leftover bread in a plastic bag at room temperature for several days. For longer storage options, see our blog post, Freezing no-knead bread dough, for details.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text:
• https://www.kingarthurbaking.com/recipes/no-knead-everything-bread-recipe
  • https://youtu.be/0FhiJr6WCGI?si=BqYFNKnHrP-mtsrY

docs.title: Overnight Sourdough Baguettes
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 3 baguettes 1.15 days

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 315 g all-purpose flour
  • 78 g whole wheat flour
  • 325 g water1
  • 9 g salt
  • 0.25 tsp instant yeast
  • 24 g sourdough starter

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 lightly greased container
  • 1 bowl scraper

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: To make the dough: For best results, weigh your flour; this recipe was developed by metric weight. However, if you prefer to work with volume measurements, please be sure to measure your flour the King Arthur way: gently spoon the flour into a cup, then sweep off any excess.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: In a medium bowl, combine all-purpose flour, whole wheat flour, water1, salt, instant yeast, sourdough starter that has been fed within the last 24 hours, and stir to combine. Once the mass is mostly homogeneous, use a bowl scraper to further press and smear the dough, smoothing it slightly.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Transfer the dough to a lightly greased container (such as a 2-quart dough-rising bucket). The dough should measure between 74°F and 78°F. Cover the container and set a 30-minute timer.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: To fold the dough: After 30 minutes, perform a bowl fold: Lift the side of the dough, stretching upward, then press it down into the middle. Repeat this motion, working around the dough, for a total of 8 to 12 stretches and folds. After the last fold, turn the dough over so that it’s seam-side down in the container. Cover and let it rest for 30 more minutes.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: After the rest, mark the height of the dough in the container with a large rubber band or a piece of tape. Place the dough in the refrigerator to rise for 8 to 24 hours.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: After the cold rise, allow the dough to warm slightly at room temperature, anywhere between 1 and 2 hours. By this point, the dough should have risen in volume 1 1/2 to 2 times.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: To preshape the baguettes: Lightly sprinkle the surface of the dough in the container with whole wheat flour, then use a bowl scraper to release the sides of the dough so that it can turn out without pulling or tearing. Turn the dough out onto a lightly floured work surface. Lightly flour the top, then divide it into 3 equal pieces (about 250 g each).

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text: Use lightly floured hands to pat each piece of dough into a rough 6" square, pressing gently to pop any air bubbles. Starting with the first piece of dough you handled, shape it into a tube: Fold in the left side and the right side to meet in the middle then press to gently seal. Starting at the top, fold the rectangle towards yourself in 3 motions, pressing gently after each fold, to create a cylinder with the seam-side down. The entire time you work, apply flour as needed to make sure the dough is moving easily on the work surface, with no wet bits threatening to stick. Repeat this process with the other 2 pieces of dough. Cover the preshaped dough and let them rest for 15 minutes.

docs.title: Step 9
docs.text: To shape the baguettes: Move a piece of preshaped dough to the center of the lightly floured surface and stretch it gently to elongate on the east/west axis, then pat it lightly to remove any bubbles. Next, fold the dough from the top down 2/3 of the way and pat to gently seal. Rotate the dough 180° and again fold toward you to bring the dough 2/3 of the way down; pat gently to seal. Last, make a gentle east/west divot in the middle of the dough and then fold the top of the dough down to the bottom edge and press to seal with the heel of your hand.

docs.title: Step 10
docs.text: With the seam-side down, place a single palm in the middle of the dough and roll it gently back and forth. With light pressure, a depression will form, turning the log into a dog bone shape. Next, add your second hand and roll the dough side to side, pushing it back and forth so that it travels across the work surface; slowly move your hands apart and toward the tips of the baguette, adding pressure so that the ends taper. If the dough is resistant, go back to the middle and take another pass. Aim for your baguettes to be 16" to 18" in length so that they fit comfortably on your baking stone or steel (use a half-sheet of parchment as your guide).

docs.title: Step 11
docs.text: Once shaped, place the baguette seam-side up onto a baker’s couche or stiff cotton dish towel that’s been lightly dusted with whole wheat flour. Repeat with the remaining pieces of dough.

docs.title: Step 12
docs.text: Cover the baguettes and allow the loaves to rise until they're slightly puffy. The loaves should look lighter and less dense than when you first shaped them, but they will not have doubled in size. This should take about 45 to 60 minutes at room temperature (about 68°F); it could take as few as 30 minutes in a warm environment. Meanwhile, prepare your oven for baking.

docs.title: Step 13
docs.text: While the dough rises, preheat the oven to 500°F with a cast iron pan on the bottom of the oven, or on the lowest rack. (If you can fit two cast iron pans, even better; alternatively, use a 9" x 13" pan that you are comfortable reserving for this purpose; it may warp.) Place a baking steel or stone on the middle rack above the pans to preheat.

docs.title: Step 14
docs.text: Gently roll the proofed baguettes onto a transfer peel so that they're seam-side down, then nudge them onto a piece of parchment, still seam-side down. (If you don't have a transfer peel, roll the baguettes onto a piece of parchment placed on an inverted baking sheet.) For the easiest scoring, chill the baguettes for 10 minutes in the refrigerator.

docs.title: Step 15
docs.text: Using a baker's lame held at about a 30° to 45° angle, make 1, 3, or 5 long lengthwise cuts in each baguette.

docs.title: Step 16
docs.text: To bake the baguettes: Load the baguettes into the oven. Use a baker's peel, a rimless baking sheet, or an inverted baking sheet to transfer the baguettes, parchment and all, onto the hot steel or stone. Carefully pour about 1 cup of water into the cast iron pan(s) and quickly shut the oven door. The billowing steam created by the boiling water will help the baguettes rise and give them a lovely, shiny crust.

docs.title: Step 17
docs.text: Immediately reduce the oven temperature to 475°F.

docs.title: Step 18
docs.text: Bake the baguettes for 24 to 28 minutes, or until they're very deep golden brown. For the crispiest baguettes, turn off the oven, prop the door open about 2", and let the baguettes dry out for an additional 10 minutes. Remove baguettes from the oven and cool them on a rack. Serve slightly warm or at room temperature.

docs.title: Step 19
docs.text: Storage information: These overnight baguettes are best eaten fresh. Wrap the bread loosely and store any leftovers at room temperature for up to several days; freeze for longer storage.

docs.title: Source
docs.text:
• https://www.kingarthurbaking.com/recipes/overnight-baguettes-recipe

  1. For cooler months (air and flour temperature around 65°F), use 85°F to 95°F water. In warmer months (air and flour temperature around 75°F), use 65°F to 75°F water. ↩↩

docs.title: Pain Aux Raisins
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 12 3.17 hours

docs.title: Ingredients - Dough
docs.text:
• 350 g strong white bread flour
  • 250 g butter
  • 30 g caster sugar
  • 7 g fast-action dried yeast
  • 1 tsp salt
  • 125 ml whole milk
  • 50 ml warm water
  • 1 large egg

docs.title: Ingredients - Crème Pâtissière
docs.text:
• 50 g caster sugar
  • 2 large egg yolks
  • 20 g cornflour
  • 250 ml whole milk
  • 0.5 pod vanilla

docs.title: Ingredients - Filling
docs.text:
• 100 g raisins
  • 0.25 tsp cinnamon
  • 1 orange
  • 1 egg

docs.title: Ingredients - Icing
docs.text:
• 200 g confectioners' sugar
  • 1 orange juice

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 dough scraper
  • 1 mixing bowl
  • 1 wooden spoon
  • 1 baking paper
  • 1 rolling pin
  • 1 medium bowl
  • 1 balloon whisk
  • 1 small saucepan
  • 1 foil

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Make the dough. Put the strong white bread flour in a mixing bowl. Cut 25g of the butter into cubes, add these to the bowl and rub in the butter with your fingertips until the mixture resembles breadcrumbs. Add the caster sugar, fast-action dried yeast and salt and stir to combine.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Beat the whole milk, warm water and egg together in a separate bowl and pour the wet mixture into the flour mixture. Mix with a wooden spoon to bring the ingredients together, then turn out the mixture onto the work surface and knead it with a dough scraper for 5 minutes, until you have a slightly sticky dough. Wrap the dough and chill it for 1 hour.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Place the remaining block of chilled butter between 2 sheets of baking paper and flatten it out with a rolling pin to a rectangle measuring about 33 x 19 cm.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Lightly flour the work surface and roll out the chilled dough to a rectangle about 1 cm thick and measuring 50 x 20 cm. With a short end of the dough closest to you, lay the butter on top of the dough, so that it covers the bottom two thirds. Make sure that it is positioned neatly and almost reaches the sides.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Fold the exposed dough at the top (without the butter) down to cover half of the butter. Fold the bottom third of the dough (with butter) up over the dough – you will now have a sandwich of 2 layers of butter and 3 layers of dough. Pinch together the edges of the dough lightly to seal in the butter and turn the dough/butter parcel 90 degrees, so the long seam is on the left-hand side. Wrap the dough and chill it for 20 minutes to harden the butter.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: With the seam still on the left, roll out the dough on a lightly floured work surface to a rectangle, about 1 cm thick and 50 x 20 cm, as before. With a short end of the dough closest to you, fold the bottom one third of the dough up and then fold the top third down on top. Put the dough back in the fridge for 20 minutes.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Make the crème pâtissière. While the dough is in the fridge, in a medium bowl and using a balloon whisk, whisk the caster sugar with the egg yolks, cornflour and 1 tablespoon of the whole milk until pale and combined.

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text: Gently heat the remaining milk with the vanilla seeds in a small saucepan until it just comes to the boil. Pour the hot milk into the egg mixture and whisk until well combined. Return the mixture to the pan and heat it gently, whisking continuously, until the mixture thickens to a custard consistency. Pour the crème pâtissière into a bowl, cover the surface and leave it to cool. Then, chill it until set.

docs.title: Step 9
docs.text: Finish the pain aux raisins. Remove the dough from the freezer, unwrap it and roll it out on a lightly floured work surface to a rectangle about 1 cm thick and 50 x 20 cm, as before. With one of the short edges closest to you, fold the bottom one third of the dough up and then fold the top third down on top. Roll out the dough to a 30cm square.

docs.title: Step 10
docs.text: Spread the crème pâtissière over the dough, leaving a 2 cm border on the side furthest from you.

docs.title: Step 11
docs.text: Sprinkle the raisins, cinnamon and orange zest over the crème pâtissière, then starting from the edge furthest from you, roll the dough towards you into a spiralled sausage shape, keeping it as tight as possible – give the dough a gentle tug each time you roll to tighten it up and give it a little tension. When you reach the end, roll the sausage back and forth a few times to seal the join.

docs.title: Step 12
docs.text: Cut the roll into 12 equal slices, each about 2.5–3cm wide. Lay the slices, cut-side up and spaced apart to allow for rising, on the lined baking trays. Put each tray inside a proving bag and leave the dough to prove for 1 hour, until it has at least doubled in size.

docs.title: Step 13
docs.text: Heat the oven to 220°C/ 200°C fan/425°F/Gas 7. Brush the risen dough with beaten egg and bake the pains for 15 to 20 minutes, until golden brown and risen. If they look like they are over-browning, cover them with foil for the last 5 minutes of baking. Remove the pains from the oven and leave them to cool.

docs.title: Step 14
docs.text: Make the icing. Mix the confectioners' sugar and 2 tablespoons of the orange juice to make a stiff but pourable icing. Drizzle the orange icing over the cooled pain aux raisins, then leave them for a few minutes for the icing to set before serving.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://thegreatbritishbakeoff.co.uk/recipes/all/paul-hollywood-pain-aux-raisins/

docs.title: Pain de Campagne (Country Bread)
docs.text: Total Time 1.16 days

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
Serves 2 large loaves
  • 40 g sourdough starter
  • 100 g whole wheat flour
  • 800 g water
  • 20 g salt
  • 900 g bread flour
Serves 1 large loaf
  • 40 g sourdough starter
  • 50 g whole wheat flour
  • 400 g water
  • 10 g salt
  • 450 g bread flour

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 large bowl or extra large (6-quart) dough rising bucket
  • 1 parchment paper
  • 1 Dutch ovens

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Combine all the ingredients in a large bowl or extra large (6-quart) dough rising bucket. It's fine to use sourdough starter straight from the refrigerator if that's where you keep it, though it's best if you've fed it at least once in the past week.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Mix the whole wheat flour, water, salt, and bread flour by hand until the dough forms a shaggy mass and the bread flour is hydrated. Cover the bowl or bucket and let the dough rest at room temperature for 15 minutes.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Fold the dough by grabbing a section from one side with a wet hand, lifting it up, then pressing it down to the middle to seal. Repeat this with the remaining three sides of the dough. Cover and let it rest for 15 minutes.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Fold the dough two more times, giving it a 15-minute rest between the two, for a total of three sets of folds in 45 minutes. As you perform the folds you’ll notice that the dough smooths out, gaining strength and becoming elastic.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Cover the dough tightly after the final fold and leave it at room temperature (approximately 72°F) for about 12 hours. It's helpful to mark the height of the dough (use the markings on the bucket or a large rubber band around your bowl) to gauge how much it rises.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Turn the dough out onto a lightly floured or greased surface and divide it into two roughly equal pieces. Gently form the pieces into rounds, cover them, and let them rest seam-side down for 10 minutes.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Generously dust two lined brotforms or towel-lined large bowls with whole wheat flour.

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text: Shape the loaves into tight rounds (boules), place them seam-side up into the prepared brotforms or bowls, and cover them with a plastic bag or shower cap.

docs.title: Step 9
docs.text: If your dough doubled (or came close to doubling) during the 12-hour rise period, immediately place the boules into the refrigerator. But if your dough was a bit more sluggish, let the boules rest at room temperature for 30 to 60 minutes to give them a head start on the second rise.

docs.title: Step 10
docs.text: Let the boules rest in the refrigerator for 8 to 12 hours, depending on your schedule (not theirs!).

docs.title: Step 11
docs.text: When you're ready to bake, place two Dutch ovens or other lidded bread bakers onto a rack set in the lowest third of the oven. If you just have one Dutch oven or don't have room for two in your oven, you can certainly bake one loaf at a time, leaving the other in the refrigerator while the first one bakes. Preheat the oven (and Dutch ovens) to 500°F for 45 minutes (you'll want to ensure that they're tough enough to withstand preheating; not all are).

docs.title: Step 12
docs.text: Turn each loaf out onto a piece of parchment paper and slash them with a lame or sharp knife.

docs.title: Step 13
docs.text: Remove the preheated Dutch ovens from the oven. With the help of the parchment, carefully transfer the loaves to the Dutch ovens.

docs.title: Step 14
docs.text: Cover the Dutch ovens with their lids and place them in the oven.

docs.title: Step 15
docs.text: Immediately reduce the oven temperature to 450°F and bake the covered loaves for 20 minutes. Remove the lids from the Dutch ovens and bake the loaves for 20 to 25 minutes uncovered, until they're a deep golden brown.

docs.title: Step 16
docs.text: Remove the loaves from the oven and carefully turn them out of the Dutch ovens onto racks to cool completely. If you're baking one loaf at a time repeat the process with the second loaf, preheating the Dutch oven if necessary.

docs.title: Step 17
docs.text: Store leftover bread, loosely wrapped, for several days; freeze for longer storage.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.kingarthurbaking.com/recipes/pain-de-campagne-country-bread-recipe

docs.title: Parmesan Pull-Apart Bread
docs.text: Total Time 36 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 3 Tbsp butter
  • 0.5 cup Parmesan
  • 1 10-oz pkg buttermilk biscuit

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 loaf pan
  • 1 Spoon
  • 1 loaf pan
  • 1 serving platter

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Preheat oven to 350°F.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Brush 1 tsp of the butter over the bottom and sides of a loaf pan.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Spoon grated Parmesan into small bowl. Cut each refrigerated buttermilk biscuit into quarters.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: One at a time, dip each quarter into remaining batter, then into cheese.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: In loaf pan, layer the coated biscuit quarters with edges touching.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Bake until loaf is browned, 30 to 35 minutes.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Let stand in pan for 1 minute, then serve onto serving platter.

docs.title: Pita
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 8 1.53 hours

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 360 g all-purpose flour
  • 2 tsp instant yeast
  • 2 tsp King Arthur Easy Roll Dough Improver (optional)
  • 2 tsp granulated sugar
  • 9 g salt
  • 227 g water
  • 25 g vegetable oil

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 bowl
  • 1 baking sheet
  • 1 clean dishtowel
  • 1 airtight container or plastic bag

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Weigh your flour; or measure it by gently spooning it into a cup, then sweeping off any excess. Combine all-purpose flour, instant yeast, King Arthur Easy Roll Dough Improver (optional), granulated sugar, salt, water, vegetable oil, mixing to form a shaggy/rough dough.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Knead the dough, by hand (10 minutes) or by mixer (5 minutes) or by bread machine (set on the dough cycle) until it's smooth.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Place the dough in a lightly greased bowl, and allow it to rest for 1 hour; it'll become quite puffy, though it may not double in bulk. If you've used a bread machine, simply let the machine complete its cycle.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Turn the dough onto a lightly oiled work surface and divide it into 8 pieces.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Roll two to four of the pieces into 6" circles (the number of pieces depends on how many rolled-out pieces at a time can fit on your baking sheet).

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Place the circles on a lightly greased baking sheet and allow them to rest, uncovered, for 15 minutes, while you preheat your oven to 500°F. (Keep the unrolled pieces of dough covered. Roll out the next batch while the first batch bakes.)

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Place the baking sheet on the lowest rack in your oven, and bake the pitas for 5 minutes; they should puff up. (If they haven't puffed up, wait a minute or so longer. If they still haven't puffed, your oven isn't hot enough; raise the heat for the next batch.)

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text: Transfer the baking sheet to your oven's middle-to-top rack and bake for an additional 2 minutes, or until the pitas have browned.

docs.title: Step 9
docs.text: Remove the pitas from the oven, wrap them in a clean dishtowel (this keeps them soft), and repeat with the remaining dough.

docs.title: Step 10
docs.text: Store cooled pitas in an airtight container or plastic bag.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.kingarthurbaking.com/recipes/golden-pita-bread-recipe

docs.title: Potato Bread
docs.text: Total Time 5.03 hours

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
Serves 2 loaves
  • 1 Tbsp instant yeast
  • 99 g granulated sugar
  • 340 g lukewarm water or potato water
  • 170 g unsalted butter
  • 15 g salt
  • 2 large eggs
  • 198 g mashed potatoes
  • 780 g all-purpose flour
Serves 1 loaf
  • 2 tsp instant yeast
  • 50 g granulated sugar
  • 170 g lukewarm water or potato water
  • 85 g unsalted butter
  • 8 g salt
  • 1 large eggs
  • 99 g mashed potatoes
  • 390 g all-purpose flour

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 stand mixer
  • 1 lightly greased bowl
  • 1 9" x 5" loaf pan
  • 1 clear shower caps
  • 1 aluminum foil

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Weigh your flour; or measure it by gently spooning it into a cup, then sweeping off any excess. Beat together instant yeast granulated sugar, 283 g to 340 g lukewarm water or potato water, softened unsalted butter, salt, eggs, mashed potatoes (from about 1/2 pound potatoes), all-purpose flour, using the flat beater paddle of your stand mixer, or your bread machine set on the dough cycle. If you're using a stand mixer, beat the mixture for 4 to 5 minutes at medium-high speed, stopping the mixer to scrape down the sides and bottom of the bowl twice. The mixture should start to become smooth and a bit shiny.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Switch to the dough hook, and knead the dough at medium speed for 7 minutes, stopping to scrape the dough into a ball twice; it may or may not start to clear the sides of the bowl on its own. If you're using a bread machine, let it go through its entire kneading cycle, but don't let it rise; continue with step 3, below.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Scrape the dough into a ball, and place it in a lightly greased bowl or large (greased) plastic bag. Refrigerate overnight, or for up to 24 hours.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Remove the dough from the refrigerator, divide it in half, and shape it into two 9" logs. Place them each in a lightly greased 9" x 5" loaf pan.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Cover the pans with clear shower caps (first choice) or lightly greased plastic wrap, and allow the dough to rise until it's crowned about 1" over the rim of the pan. Since the dough is cold, this will take anywhere from 2 to 4 hours. Towards the end of the rising time, preheat the oven to 350°F.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Bake the loaves for 25 minutes. Tent with aluminum foil, and bake for an additional 15 to 20 minutes, until the bread is a deep golden brown, and a digital thermometer inserted into the center of one of the loaves registers at least 190°F.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Remove the bread from the oven, and place the pans on a rack. After 5 minutes, gently turn the loaves out onto the rack to cool completely.

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text: Store, tightly wrapped, at room temperature for several days, or up to a week in cool/dry weather; for longer storage, wrap well and freeze.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.kingarthurbaking.com/recipes/potato-bread-recipe

docs.title: Pull-Apart Sour Cream and Chive Rolls
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 24 3.37 hours

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text: Serves 1/2 Batch

docs.title: 1/2 Batch - Tangzhong
docs.text:
• 0.25 (57 g) cup whole milk
  • 21 g bread flour
  • 0.25 (57 g) cup water

docs.title: 1/2 Batch - Dough
docs.text:
• 1 Tbsp whole milk
  • 0.75 tsp active dry yeast
  • 1/2 cup (113 g) sour cream
  • 25 g granulated sugar
  • 2 tsp salt
  • 1 egg
  • 2 Tbsp (28 g) unsalted butter
  • 313 g bread flour
  • 1 Tbsp (14 g) unsalted butter
  • 0.25 cup chives
  • 1/2 egg
  • some flaky sea salt
  • some pepper
  • 1 Tbsp (14 g) unsalted butter
Serves 1 Batch

docs.title: 1 Batch - Tangzhong
docs.text:
• 0.5 (113 g) cup whole milk
  • 42 g bread flour
  • 0.5 (113 g) cup water

docs.title: 1 Batch - Dough
docs.text:
• 2 Tbsp whole milk
  • 1.5 tsp active dry yeast
  • 1 cup (227 g) sour cream
  • 50 g granulated sugar
  • 4 tsp salt
  • 2 egg
  • 4 Tbsp (57 g) unsalted butter
  • 625 g bread flour
  • 2 Tbsp (28 g) unsalted butter
  • 0.5 cup chives
  • 1 egg
  • some flaky sea salt
  • some pepper
  • 2 Tbsp (28 g) unsalted butter

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 small saucepan
  • 1 stand mixer
  • 1 large bowl
  • 1 plastic wrap or a silicone lid
  • 1 13 x 9 pan
  • 1 wheel cutter or bench scraper
  • 1 fork
  • 1 small bowl
  • 1 knife or an offset spatula

docs.title: Baking Schedule
docs.text:
Mix

9:00 a.m.

Bulk Fermentation

9:15 a.m.

Divide

10:45 a.m.

Shape

11:00 a.m.

Proof

11:15 a.m.

Bake

12:15 p.m.

Rest

12:45 p.m.

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text:
Make the tangzhong by whisking 1/2 cup whole milk, 1/3 cup bread flour (42 g), and 1/2 cup water in a small saucepan until smooth. Cook over medium heat, whisking constantly, until very stiff paste forms (it should resemble mashed potatoes), about 2 minutes. Remove from heat.

Tip
