Be sure to add the liquid to the dry ingredients to avoid clumping.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Scrape tangzhong into the bowl of a stand mixer fitted with the dough hook.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text:
Gently warm remaining 2 Tbsp whole milk in the same saucepan over low heat until lukewarm. Remove from heat, add active dry yeast, and whisk until dissolved. Let sit until the mixture is foamy, about 5 minutes.

Tip

If using instant yeast, this step may be skipped and the yeast may be added directly to the flour and salt. Add the additional 2 Tbsp of whole milk to the dough.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Add room temperature sour cream, granulated sugar, kosher salt, 2 eggs, 4 Tbsp room temperature unsalted butter, and remaining 5 cups bread flour (625 g) to tangzhong. Scrape in yeast mixture and mix on low speed until a shaggy dough forms. Increase speed to medium and mix, scraping down sides of bowl occasionally and adding more flour by the tablespoonful if sticky, until dough is smooth and supple, 8 to 10 minutes.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Scrape dough onto a work surface and form into a smooth ball.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Dust lightly with flour. Place inside a clean large bowl and cover with plastic wrap or a silicone lid. Let sit in a warm, draft-free spot until doubled in size, 1 to 1.5 hours.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Meanwhile, coat a 13 x 9 pan, preferably metal, with 2 Tbsp room temperature unsalted butter (it will be a generous layer, which is what you want). Uncover the dough and punch down lightly to expel some of the gas.

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text: Turn dough out onto a lightly floured surface and stretch into a square.

docs.title: Step 9
docs.text: Roll out, dusting with more flour as needed to prevent sticking, to a 12" square and sprinkle finely chopped chives evenly over dough.

docs.title: Step 10
docs.text: Starting at one end, loosely roll up dough. Flatten with the heel of your hands into a long rectangle. Roll out the dough again, dusting with more flour as needed, into a 16 x 6" rectangle.

docs.title: Step 11
docs.text: Using a wheel cutter or bench scraper, cut dough into twenty-four 2" squarish pieces (an 8 X 3 grid).

docs.title: Step 12
docs.text: Working with 1 piece of dough, gather all the corners and pinch together to form a teardrop shape. Place seam side down on work surface. Cup your hand over dough and drag across the surface, moving your hand in a rapid circular motion, to form dough into a tight ball. Do not add flour, as you want friction between the dough and the surface. Place the ball in the prepared pan and repeat with the remaining pieces of dough, spacing to make a 6 X 4 grid. Cover pan with plastic wrap and let sit in a warm, draft-free spot until rolls are nearly doubled in size, 45 to 60 minutes.

docs.title: Step 13
docs.text: Meanwhile, place a rack in the middle of the oven. Preheat to 375°F.

docs.title: Step 14
docs.text: Using a fork, whisk the remaining egg in a small bowl until no streaks remain. Uncover the pan and gently brush tops of rolls with egg, then sprinkle with flaky sea salt and pepper. Bake rolls until tops are deep golden brown, 25 to 30 minutes.

docs.title: Step 15
docs.text: Remove pan from oven and immediately brush tops with remaining 2 Tbsp unsalted butter. Let cool in the pan for 5 minutes. Slide a knife or an offset spatula around the sides of the pan to loosen rolls, then slide a metal spatula underneath to loosen the bottom. Slide the entire grid of rolls out and onto a wire rack. Serve warm or let cool.

docs.title: Step 16
docs.text: Rolls can be formed and arranged in pan 1 day ahead. Cover and chill. Let rise at room temperature before baking (this can take up to 3 hours). Rolls can be baked 3 days ahead. Let cool. Store airtight at room temperature.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text:
• https://chewingthefat.us.com/2021/01/claire-saffritz-pull-apart-sour-cream-and-chive-rolls.html
  • https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Wvk135WOAg0

docs.title: Pumpkin Bread
docs.text: Total Time 1.58 hours

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 285 g all-purpose flour
  • 1 tsp baking powder
  • 1 tsp cinnamon
  • 0.75 tsp salt
  • 0.5 tsp baking soda
  • 0.5 cup vegetable oil
  • 1 15-oz can pumpkin purée
  • 200 g granulated sugar
  • 165 g brown sugar
  • 2 large eggs
  • 0.25 cup sour cream
  • 1.5 tsp vanilla

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 8.5 or 9 inch loaf pan
  • 1 parchment
  • 1 large bowl
  • 1 cooling rack
  • 1 paring knife

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Heat the oven to 350°F. Oil an 8.5 or 9 inch loaf pan; line with parchment, leaving a 2 inch overhang on two sides.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: In a medium bowl, whisk together the all-purpose flour, baking powder, cinnamon, salt and baking soda. In a large bowl, whisk together the vegetable oil, pumpkin purée, granulated sugar, brown sugar, eggs, sour cream and vanilla. Fold the dry ingredients into the wet ingredients until fully combined. Transfer the batter to the prepared pan and smooth into an even layer.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Bake until the loaf is puffed and set, and a skewer inserted into the center comes out with moist crumbs attached, 60 to 75 minutes. Transfer the bread, in the pan, to a cooling rack to cool for 20 minutes. Use a paring knife to cut the two exposed sides of bread away from the pan, then use the parchment to transfer the cake to the rack. Let cool completely.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://cooking.nytimes.com/recipes/1020571-pumpkin-bread

docs.title: Pumpkin Coffee Cake
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 12 30 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients - Cake
docs.text:
• 170 g unsalted butter
  • 100 g granulated sugar
  • 50 g brown sugar
  • 2 large eggs
  • 240 g pumpkin puree
  • 2 Tbsp sour cream
  • 1.5 tsp vanilla
  • 156 g all-purpose flour
  • :nutmeg: 2 tsp pumpkin pie spice
  • 0.5 tsp cinnamon
  • 0.75 tsp baking powder
  • 0.75 tsp baking soda
  • 0.5 tsp salt

docs.title: Ingredients - Streusel
docs.text:
• 125 g all-purpose flour
  • 150 g brown sugar
  • 2 Tbsp granulated sugar
  • 0.5 tsp salt
  • 1.5 tsp cinnamon
  • 6 Tbsp unsalted butter

docs.title: Ingredients - Glaze
docs.text:
• 63 g confectioners' sugar
  • 3 Tsp milk
  • 0.25 tsp vanilla

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 9 x 9 baking pan
  • 1 parchment paper
  • 1 large bowl
  • 1 medium-sized bowl
  • 1 spatula
  • 1 fork

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C) and line a 9 x 9 baking pan with parchment paper or lightly grease the pan with baking spray.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Combine melted unsalted butter and granulated sugar and brown sugar in a large bowl and stir until well-combined.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Add eggs, stir well.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Stir in pumpkin puree, sour cream, and vanilla extract until well combined. Be sure to scrape down the sides and bottom of the bowl to ensure that all ingredients are well combined.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: In a separate, medium-sized bowl, whisk together all-purpose flour, pumpkin pie spice, cinnamon, baking powder, baking soda, and salt.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Using a spatula, gradually add dry ingredients and wet and stir gently until just combined — do not over-mix!

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Spread batter evenly into prepared pan. Set aside while you prepare the streusel topping.

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text: Prepare the crumble by whisking together all-purpose flour, brown sugar, granulated sugar, salt, and cinnamon.

docs.title: Step 9
docs.text: Pour the melted unsalted butter into the mixture and, using a fork, stir until crumbles form.

docs.title: Step 10
docs.text: Evenly sprinkle streusel topping over the top of your pumpkin batter.

docs.title: Step 11
docs.text: Transfer pan to oven and bake on 350°F (175°C) for 30 minutes, or until a toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean.

docs.title: Step 12
docs.text: Allow to cool before adding glaze.

docs.title: Step 13
docs.text: If desired, make glaze by whisking together confectioners' sugar and milk. Start with 2 teaspoons of milk and add a third if it isn't thin enough to drizzle. Stir in vanilla extract.

docs.title: Step 14
docs.text: Drizzle over cooled pumpkin crumb cake.

docs.title: Step 15
docs.text: Cut and serve. Enjoy!

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://sugarspunrun.com/pumpkin-coffee-cake/

docs.title: Rosca de Reyes
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 16 3.62 hours

docs.title: Ingredients - Dough
docs.text:
• 0.5 cup lukewarm water
  • 7 g yeast
  • 565 g all-purpose flour
  • 3 large eggs
  • 3 egg yolks
  • 150 g granulated sugar
  • 1.5 Tbsp orange extract
  • 1 orange zest
  • 0.5 tsp salt
  • 169 g unsalted butter

docs.title: Ingredients - Decoration
docs.text:
• 6 Tbsp margarine
  • 0.5 cup confectioners' sugar
  • 0.75 cup all-purpose flour
  • 1 egg yolk
  • 1 egg
  • 1 Tbsp milk or water
  • some dried figs, candied citron, quince paste stripes, orange peels or cherries

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 bowl
  • 1 fork
  • 1 plastic wrap
  • 1 large bowl
  • 1 greased rimmed baking sheet
  • 1 wire rack

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Pour lukewarm water into a bowl, and sprinkle with yeast. Stir with a fork until yeast has dissolved, then let stand until foamy, 5 to 10 minutes. Stir in a 60 g of the all-purpose flour, and cover bowl with plastic wrap. Let stand in a warm place until doubled in bulk, about 25 minutes.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: In the meantime, mix flour, eggs, egg yolks, granulated sugar, orange extract, orange zest, salt and unsalted butter in a large bowl. Mix until crumbly. Even though I have a stand mixer this time I kneaded the dough by hand since not everyone has a large mixer but you can do these steps in your Kitchen Aid.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Add yeast mixture to the bowl and mix. It will be very sticky but manageable, add flour if needed. Place on a lightly floured surface and start kneading until you have a smooth dough. It will take about 15 to 20 minutes to get this results. 7 minutes in your stand mixer. DO NOT add too much flour to your working area, the texture should be very soft, sort of wet but manageable. If you add more flour than needed your bread will be dry.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Once your dough is smooth and soft, place in a buttered bowl, and cover with buttered plastic wrap. The pictures don’t show the texture and feel of the dough, but it must be wet and elastic. Let dough stand in a warm place until doubled in volume, about 1.5 hours. Make sure your kitchen is warm to help your dough to rise. If the dough doesn’t double in volume after this time let it rest longer. The fermentation process develops flavor, so slower and longer is always best.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: While the dough is resting, mix the following ingredients for the decoration: margarine with the confectioners' sugar until it is creamy. Then add in the all-purpose flour and egg yolk. Until you have a smooth paste.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: After the first resting period. Turn dough out onto a lightly floured surface, and knead a few times, then shape into a round cushion and making a hole in the middle shape into a large ring. Transfer to a greased rimmed baking sheet, and loosely cover with buttered plastic wrap. Let rise in a warm place for 45 minutes or more until almost double in volume. Gather all your decorations and the egg wash. For the egg wash whisk remaining egg with milk or water.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Preheat oven at least 20 minutes before baking at 375°F, with rack in lower third.

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text: Brush the dough with the egg wash two times for a golden crust. Form strips with the confectioner sugar paste and decorate the dough. Place some of the dried figs, candied citron, quince paste stripes, orange peels or cherries, pressing them gently into the dough. Sprinkle with sugar and bake for 10 minutes. Reduce heat to 350°F and bake for 10 minutes more until bread is a nice golden brown color. Depending on your oven it will require more time. (Some readers had reported baking for 30 minutes)

docs.title: Step 9
docs.text: Transfer the bread to a wire rack to cool. After the bread has cooled insert the plastic baby dolls from the bottom of the bread. Do not forget to let your guests know that there is a baby toy inside the bread. Rosca de Reyes can be stored in an airtight container for up to 3 days.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.mexicoinmykitchen.com/three-kings-bread-recipe/

docs.title: Skillet Flatbread
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 12 1 hour

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 360 g all-purpose flour
  • 2 tsp baking powder
  • 3 tsp kosher salt
  • 35 g olive oil
  • 227 g ice water
  • 35 g vegetable oil

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 large bowl
  • 1 cast iron pan

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Place the flour, baking powder, and salt in a large mixing bowl and stir to combine.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Add the oil and ice water, and mix to make a soft, cohesive dough. Adjust with flour or water as needed. The dough should be moist but not sticky. Cover with plastic wrap, and let rest for 10 minutes.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Preheat a heavy-bottomed skillet on the stovetop. Add 1 tablespoon oil and heat until the oil starts to shimmer in the pan.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Divide the dough into 10 to 12 equal pieces. Each piece should weigh about 1 1/2 to 2 ounces, about the size of a large egg. Dredge each piece in flour, and roll to a rough circle or oval, about 1/4" thick. OR hand shape the pieces by flattening between your palms.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text:
Divide the dough into 10 to 12 equal pieces. Each piece should weigh about 1 1/2 to 2 ounces, about the size of a large egg. Dredge each piece in flour, and roll to a rough circle or oval, about 1/4" thick. OR hand shape the pieces by flattening between your palms.

Tip

Rye variation: Replace 1 cup of the all-purpose flour with 1 cup Perfect Rye Flour Blend and 2 teaspoons Deli Rye Flavor. All other ingredients remain the same. Serve with cream cheese, chives, tomato, thinly sliced onion and capers.

Tip

Pizza bread version: Add 2 teaspoons Pizza Dough Flavor and 2 teaspoons dried Italian herbs or Pizza Seasoning to the flour mixture. Serve with marinara sauce for dipping.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.kingarthurbaking.com/recipes/skillet-flatbreads-recipe

docs.title: Sourdough Crackers
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 100 crackers 55 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 227 g sourdough starter
  • 113 g whole wheat flour
  • 0.5 tsp flaky sea salt
  • 57 g butter
  • 2 Tbsp herbs (optional)

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 plastic wrap
  • 1 parchment
  • 1 rolling pin
  • 1 baking sheet
  • 1 fork

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Mix together the sourdough starter, whole wheat flour, flaky sea salt, butter, and herbs (optional) to make a smooth (not sticky), cohesive dough.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Divide the dough in half, and shape each half into a small rectangular slab. Cover with plastic wrap, and refrigerate for 30 minutes, or up to a couple of hours, until the dough is firm.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Preheat the oven to 350°F.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Working with one piece of dough at a time, very lightly flour a piece of parchment, your rolling pin, and the top of the dough.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Place the dough onto the floured parchment and roll it about 1/16" thick. It'll have ragged, uneven edges; that's OK. Just try to make it as even as possible.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Transfer the dough and parchment together onto a baking sheet. Lightly brush with oil and then sprinkle the salt over the top of the crackers.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Cut the dough into 1 1/4" squares; a rolling pizza wheel works well here.

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text: Prick (dock) each cracker a couple of times with a fork; this will help keep them from puffing up like little pitas as they bake.

docs.title: Step 9
docs.text: Roll and cut the second piece of dough following the directions above.

docs.title: Step 10
docs.text: Bake the crackers for 20 to 25 minutes, until they're starting to brown around the edges. Midway through, rotate the baking sheets both top to bottom and front to back; this will help the crackers brown evenly.

docs.title: Step 11
docs.text: When fully browned, remove the crackers from the oven and place the pans on a rack to cool.

docs.title: Step 12
docs.text:
Store crackers, well wrapped, at room temperature for up to a week; freeze for longer storage.

Tip

Up to 2 tablespoons (18 g) aromatic seeds (a mix of fennel, mustard, and caraway seeds is particularly nice with rye crackers); or Everything Bagel Topping

Tip

Up to 2 tablespoons dried herbs, or 1/4 cup (11 g) finely chopped fresh herbs

Tip

4 teaspoons (9g) Pizza Dough Flavor, especially good with cheesy crackers (see below)

Tip

About 1 tablespoon of your favorite garam masala blend

Tip

Add 1/4 to 1/3 cup (28 g to 38 g) finely grated hard cheese (Parmesan, Asiago, extra-sharp aged cheddar) along with the dry ingredients. The more assertive the cheese, the more evident its flavor in the crackers.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text:
• https://www.kingarthurbaking.com/recipes/sourdough-crackers-recipe
  • https://www.kingarthurbaking.com/blog/2020/08/24/sourdough-crackers
  • https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4aZ7xAPCa50

docs.title: Sourdough Crumpets
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 4 8 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 227 g sourdough starter
  • 1 tsp granulated sugar
  • 0.5 tsp salt
  • 0.38 tsp baking soda

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 medium-sized bowl
  • 4 English muffin rings

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Place the sourdough starter in a medium-sized bowl. Stir in the granulated sugar and salt, then the baking soda. The batter should rise up and bubble a bit, becoming almost billowy.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Heat your griddle over medium-low heat; 300°F is perfect. Lightly grease the surface with cooking oil (if your pan isn't non-stick), then melt a pat of butter atop the oil.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Lightly grease four English muffin rings (1" high and 4" across) and place on the griddle. Divide the batter evenly among the rings. Each ring will take a generous 1/4 cup of batter; a generously heaped muffin scoop is the perfect tool for this task. Cook for about 5 minutes, until the tops are set and full of small holes. Carefully flip the crumpets over, remove the rings (they should pop right off), and continue to cook for about 3 minutes, until they're golden on the bottom. Enjoy the crumpets warm, split and spread with butter and jam. Or toast to brown and crisp them before serving.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Store any leftovers at room temperature for several days. Freeze, well wrapped, for longer storage.

docs.title: Source
docs.text:
• https://www.kingarthurbaking.com/recipes/sourdough-crumpets-recipe
  • https://youtube.com/watch?v=MhHGfafYmJs

docs.title: Sourdough English Muffins
docs.text: Total Time 1.11 days

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
Serves 2 dozen large muffins
  • 25 g granulated sugar
  • 454 g warm water
  • 1 Tbsp active dry yeast or instant yeast
  • 227 g sourdough starter
  • 840 g all-purpose flour
  • 56 g dry milk
  • 57 g unsalted butter
  • 18 g salt
  • 0.25 tsp citric acid (sour salt), (optional)
  • some cornmeal or semolina (optional)
Serves 1 dozen large muffins
  • 13 g granulated sugar
  • 227 g warm water
  • 2 tsp active dry yeast or instant yeast
  • 114 g sourdough starter
  • 420 g all-purpose flour
  • 28 g dry milk
  • 28 g unsalted butter
  • 9 g salt
  • 0.125 tsp citric acid (sour salt), (optional)
  • some cornmeal or semolina (optional)

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 lightly greased bowl
  • 1 baking sheets
  • 1 plastic wrap

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Weigh your flour; or measure it by gently spooning it into a cup, then sweeping off any excess. Combine granulated sugar, warm water (110°F - 115°F), active dry yeast or instant yeast, sourdough starter, ripe or discard, all-purpose flour, dry milk, unsalted butter, at room temperature, salt, citric acid (sour salt), (optional); for enhanced sour flavor, except the cornmeal/semolina, in a large bowl.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Mix and knead — by hand, electric mixer, or bread machine — to form a smooth dough. The dough should be soft and elastic, but not particularly sticky; add additional flour if necessary.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Place the dough in a lightly greased bowl, cover, and set it aside to rise for about 1.5 hours, or until it's noticeably puffy. For most pronounced sour flavor, cover the bowl, and immediately place it in the refrigerator (without rising first). Let the dough chill for 24 hours; this will develop its flavor.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Gently deflate the dough, turn it out onto a lightly floured work surface, cover it, and let it sit for a few minutes, to relax the gluten. Divide the dough in half. Working with one piece at a time, roll 1/2" thick, and cut in 3" rounds. Re-roll and cut any remaining scraps. Repeat with the remaining half of dough.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Alternatively, divide the dough into 24 pieces (total). Shape each piece into a round ball, then flatten each ball into a 3" round. For a somewhat more even rise as the muffins cook, flatten each ball slightly larger than 3", and trim edges with a 3" cutter (or trim all around the edge with a pair of scissors). Muffins with cut (rather than flattened) sides will rise more evenly.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Place the rounds, evenly spaced, onto cornmeal or semolina (optional) sprinkled baking sheets (12 per sheet). Sprinkle them with additional cornmeal or semolina, cover with plastic wrap, and let them rise until light and puffy, about 45 to 60 minutes. If the dough has been refrigerated overnight, the rise time will be about 2 hours.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Carefully transfer the rounds (as many as a time that will fit without crowding) right-side up to a large electric griddle preheated to 350°F, or to an ungreased frying pan that has been preheated over medium-low heat.

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text: Cook the muffins for about 5 minutes on their first side; then lay a cake pan, cookie sheet, or similar flat (though not overly heavy) object atop them to help keep them flat. Continue cooking for about 7 minutes or so; then remove the pan, turn the muffins over, and finish cooking without the pan on top for a total of about 10 to 12 minutes or when the center of a muffin registers 190°F on a digital thermometer. If you're having trouble getting muffins to cook all the way through on the stovetop, cook until golden brown on both sides, then transfer to a preheated 350°F oven and bake until the muffins' interior shows no sign of wet dough, about 10 minutes or so.

docs.title: Step 9
docs.text: Remove the muffins from the griddle, and cool on a rack. Store tightly wrapped at room temperature for 4 or 5 days; freeze for longer storage.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.kingarthurbaking.com/recipes/sourdough-english-muffins-recipe

docs.title: Sourdough Pizza Crust
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 2 12" pizzas or 1 14" round pizza 5.23 hours

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 227 g sourdough starter
  • 300 g all-purpose flour
  • 141 g lukewarm water
  • 1 tsp salt
  • 0.5 tsp yeast
  • 4 tsp Pizza Dough Flavor (optional)

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 large mixing bowl
  • 1 lightly greased container
  • 1 14" round pizza pan or 18" x 13" half-sheet pan

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text:
Stir any liquid on top of your refrigerated sourdough starter back into it before measuring 1 cup (227 g) into a large mixing bowl.

Note

This is a good opportunity to feed the remainder of your starter, if necessary.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: To make the dough: Weigh your all-purpose flour; or measure it by gently spooning it into a cup, then sweeping off any excess. In your large mixing bowl or bowl of your stand mixer, combine the lesser amount of lukewarm water, the flour, salt, yeast, and Pizza Dough Flavor (optional) with the sourdough starter.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Mix to combine, adding the remaining water 1 tablespoon at a time if the dough looks dry. Knead for about 7 minutes using a stand mixer with its dough hook, until the dough cleans the sides of the bowl.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Place the dough in a lightly greased container, cover, and let rise until almost doubled in bulk. Depending on the vitality of your starter, this will take between 2 and 4 hours. For a faster rise, place the dough in a warm spot (or double the yeast).

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: For two thin-crust pizzas: Divide the dough in half and shape each into a flattened disk. Drizzle two 12" round pizza pans with olive oil, and brush to coat the pan evenly.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Place the dough in the pans, cover, and let rest for 15 minutes. After this rest, gently press each piece of dough toward the edge of its pan. If it starts to shrink back, cover and let rest for 15 minutes before continuing.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: For a thicker, large pizza: Oil a 14" round pizza pan or 18" x 13" half-sheet pan. Place the dough in the pan and press it out to the edges, again giving it a 15 minute rest before continuing if it starts to snap back.

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text: Cover the pan(s) and let the dough rise until it's as thick as you like.

docs.title: Step 9
docs.text: Toward the end of the rise, preheat your oven to 450°F.

docs.title: Step 10
docs.text: Sauce and top each pizza as you like, but don't add cheese yet (this ensures a crispy crust). Bake thin-crust pizzas for 5 minutes before removing from the oven and adding cheese. For thick-crust pizza, bake for 10 minutes before removing from the oven and adding cheese. Return to the oven and bake for 5 to 7 minutes more, until the cheese is melted.

docs.title: Step 11
docs.text: Remove the pizza from the oven and enjoy hot.

docs.title: Step 12
docs.text: Storage information: Store leftover pizza, well wrapped, in the refrigerator for up to five days.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.kingarthurbaking.com/recipes/sourdough-pizza-crust-recipe

docs.title: Sourdough Pretzels
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 12 2.53 hours

docs.title: Ingredients - Pretzels
docs.text:
• 198 g water
  • 227 g sourdough starter
  • 360 g bread flour
  • 28 g dry milk
  • 14 g granulated sugar
  • 18 g non-diastatic malt powder (alternative)
  • 1 Tbsp unsalted butter or vegetable oil
  • 9 g salt
  • 2 tsp instant yeast

docs.title: Ingredients - Topping
docs.text:
• 14 g granulated sugar
  • 18 g non-diastatic malt powder (alternative)
  • 28 g water
  • some pretzel salt
  • 28 g melted unsalted butter

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 bowl
  • 1 baking sheet
  • 1 clean dishtowel
  • 1 airtight container or plastic bag

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Prepare a baking sheet by spraying it with vegetable oil spray, or lining it with parchment paper. If you're not using King Arthur Flour's brand, grease the parchment with vegetable oil spray to make double-sure the pretzels won't stick.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Weigh your flour; or measure it by gently spooning it into a cup, then sweeping off any excess. Mix and knead the dough ingredients — by hand, mixer, or bread machine — to make a cohesive, fairly smooth dough. It should be slightly sticky; if it seems dry, knead in an additional tablespoon or two of water.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Cover the dough and let it rest for 45 minutes. It will rise minimally. Towards the end of the rising time, preheat the oven to 350°F.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Turn the dough out onto a lightly greased work surface, fold it over a few times to gently deflate it, then divide it into 12 pieces, each weighing about 2 1/4 to 2 1/2 ounces.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Roll each piece of dough into an 18" rope. Shape each rope into a pretzel.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Dissolve the malt in the water. Brush the pretzels with the solution, and sprinkle lightly with coarse pretzel salt.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Alternatively, in a large pot, boil together 6 cups of water and 2 tablespoons baking soda. Put 4 pretzels at a time into the boiling water, and cook for 1 minute. Transfer boiled pretzels to the prepared baking sheet.

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text:
Bake the pretzels for 25 to 30 minutes, until they're a light golden brown.

Note

This is correct; there's no need to let the shaped pretzels rise before baking.

docs.title: Step 9
docs.text: Remove the pretzels from the oven, and brush with melted butter.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text:
• https://www.kingarthurbaking.com/recipes/sourdough-pretzels-recipe
  • https://www.kingarthurbaking.com/blog/2011/04/28/soft-scrumptious-and-sourdough-pretzels-from-your-discard-starter

docs.title: Texas Roadhouse Rolls
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 24 2.33 hours

docs.title: Ingredients - Dough
docs.text:
• 340 g whole milk
  • 50 g granulated sugar
  • 0.25 oz active dry yeast
  • 3 large eggs
  • 4 Tbsp butter
  • 4 tsp salt
  • 810 g all-purpose flour

docs.title: Ingredients - Cinnamon-Honey Butter
docs.text:
• 1 Tbsp confectioners’ sugar
  • 1 tsp honey
  • 1 tsp salt
  • 0.75 tsp cinnamon
  • 0.75 cup butter

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 small saucepan
  • 1 stand mixer
  • 1 lightly oiled bowl
  • 1 plastic wrap
  • 1 baking sheets
  • 1 parchment
  • 1 sharp knife or pizza cutter
  • 1 dish towel
  • 1 large bowl

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: In a small saucepan over medium heat, heat whole milk until warm to the touch, between 100°F to 110°F. In the large bowl of a stand mixer fitted with the dough hook, combine warm milk, granulated sugar, and active dry yeast. Let sit until yeast is dissolved and foamy, about 10 minutes.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Add eggs, butter, and kosher salt and beat on low speed until just combined. Add all-purpose flour and continue to beat on low speed until dough comes together, about 5 minutes.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Turn out dough onto a lightly floured surface and knead until smooth, about 5 minutes. Transfer dough to a lightly oiled bowl, cover with plastic wrap, and let rise at room temperature until doubled in size, about 1 hour.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Line 2 baking sheets with parchment. Return dough to lightly floured surface and roll to a 1" thick rectangle. Using a sharp knife or pizza cutter, cut dough into 2" squares. Transfer squares to prepared sheets, spacing about 1/2" apart. Cover each sheet with a dish towel and let rise until doubled in size, about 45 minutes.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: In a large bowl, whisk confectioners’ sugar, honey, kosher salt, cinnamon, and 1 stick butter until thoroughly combined and fluffy.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Preheat oven to 375°F. Melt remaining 1/2 stick butter in the microwave or in a small pot. Brush each square with butter.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Bake rolls until golden brown and risen, about 15 minutes.

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text:
Brush rolls with more melted butter and sprinkle with sea salt, if using. Serve with cinnamon-honey butter alongside.

Make Ahead

Rolls can be made 1 month ahead. Let cool, tightly wrap in foil, then in plastic wrap, and freeze. When ready to eat, let rolls thaw at room temperature overnight. Remove plastic wrap and loosen foil, then bake at 300°F for 10 minutes to heat through. Cinnamon-honey butter can be made 7 days ahead. Store in an airtight container and refrigerate. Bring to room temperature before serving.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.delish.com/cooking/recipe-ideas/a41901752/copycat-texas-roadhouse-rolls-recipe/

docs.title: The Best Cornbread
docs.text: Total Time 35 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients - Cornbread
docs.text:
• 0.5 cup (69 g) cornmeal
  • 1.5 cup (180 g) all-purpose flour
  • 0.67 cup (132 g) granulated sugar
  • 1 Tbsp baking powder
  • 0.5 tsp salt
  • 0.33 cup (66 g) vegetable oil
  • 3 Tbsp (42 g) butter, melted
  • 2 large eggs, beaten
  • 1.25 cup (284 g) milk

docs.title: Ingredients - Honey Butter
docs.text:
• 0.5 cup honey
  • 1 cup unsalted butter
  • 0.5 cup marshmallow fluff

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 large bowl
  • 1 rubber spatula
  • 1 electric mixer

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Preheat the oven to 350°F. Lightly grease an 8 x 8 or 9 x 9 inch baking pan (I always use metal; glass pans will bake differently).

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: For the cornbread, in a large bowl, whisk together the cornmeal, all-purpose flour, granulated sugar, baking powder, and salt. Add the oil, butter, melted, eggs, beaten, and milk and stir with a whisk or rubber spatula until just combined. The batter will be runny.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Spread the batter evenly in the prepared pan. Bake for 30 to 35 minutes until a toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean or with a few moist crumbs.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: For the honey butter, whip the honey, unsalted butter, and marshmallow fluff together with an electric mixer. Best served at room temperature so it is soft and spreadable.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text:
• https://www.melskitchencafe.com/the-cornbread-and-fluffy-honey-butter/
  • https://www.thepancakeprincess.com/2019/11/24/best-sweet-cornbread-bake-off/

docs.title: The Best Pumpkin Bread
docs.text: Total Time 1.42 hours

docs.title: Ingredients - Bread
docs.text:
• 1 15-oz can pumpkin puree
  • 0.5 cup vegetable oil
  • 3 large eggs
  • 330 g granulated sugar
  • 1.5 tsp baking powder
  • 0.75 tsp baking soda
  • 0.75 tsp salt
  • 0.75 tsp cinnamon
  • 0.25 heaped tsp nutmeg
  • 0.25 heaped tsp ginger
  • 2 pinches ground cloves
  • 295 g all-purpose flour

docs.title: Ingredients - Topping
docs.text:
• 1 Tbsp granulated sugar
  • 1 tsp cinnamon

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 6 cup loaf pan
  • 1 large bowl
  • 1 spoon
  • 1 small dish

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Heat oven to 350°F. Butter a 6 cup loaf pan or coat it with nonstick spray.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: In a large bowl, whisk together pumpkin puree, vegetable oil, eggs and granulated sugar until smooth. Sprinkle baking powder, baking soda, salt, cinnamon, nutmeg, ginger and ground cloves over batter and whisk until well-combined. Add all-purpose flour and stir with a spoon, just until mixed. Scrape into prepared pan and smooth the top. In a small dish, or empty measuring cup, stir granulated sugar and cinnamon together. Sprinkle over top of batter.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Bake bread for 65 to 75 minutes until a tester poked into all parts of cake (both the top and center will want to hide pockets of uncooked batter) come out batter-free, turning the cake once during the baking time for even coloring.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: You can cool it in the pan for 10 minutes and then remove it, or cool it completely in there. The latter provides the advantage of letting more of the loose cinnamon sugar on top adhere before being knocked off.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Cake keeps at room temperature as long as you can hide it. I like to keep mine in the tin with a piece of foil or plastic just over the cut end and the top exposed to best keep the lid crisp as long as possible.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text:
• https://smittenkitchen.com/2016/10/pumpkin-bread/
  • https://www.thekitchn.com/pumpkin-bread-recipe-reviews-23085203

docs.title: The Bread Code Sourdough
docs.text:
Serves Total Time 1 loaf 14.85 hours

The Sourdough Calculator may be used to generate a recipe.

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 400 g (80%) bread flour
  • 100 g (20%) whole wheat flour
  • 325 g (65%) water
  • 100 g (20%) starter
  • 10 g (2%) salt

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 bowl
  • 1 cylindrical shaped container
  • 1 Dutch oven
  • 1 cooling rack

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: At night, mix bread flour, whole wheat flour, and water in a bowl, fully hydrating the flour. Let it rest, covered, at room temperature over night for 12 hours. Make sure that there are no crumbly parts of flour left.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: The next morning, add the active starter to the main dough. Add the salt to the main dough. Mix until everything is nicely homogenized (very important). For me this takes around 1 minute. It might take you up to 5 minutes. You want to make sure the sourdough starter has been evenly spread across the dough.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Let the dough sit for another 15 minutes covered and check for the window pane effect

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Now remove the dough and place it on your bench (no flour!) and knead.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Extract a small sample from the dough and place it in a cylindrical shaped container. A shot glass works, or anything else that has a cylindrical shape. This sample will tell us exactly when the dough is done bulk fermenting. Mark the dough with a rubber band or a marker. This way we can see the size increase.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Let the dough sit for another 15 minutes covered.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Proceed with kneading the dough on the bench. It’s important that you have no flour on the surface. Pull the dough as far out as you can, without tearing it. Fold over the dough to glue itself together.

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text: Repeat once from each side.

docs.title: Step 9
docs.text: Drag the dough over the surface using your hands at a 45° angle. This only works because the dough is stuck on the surface. Your dough ball should become nice and round.

docs.title: Step 10
docs.text: Wait a minute, repeat the same process 3 times.

docs.title: Step 11
docs.text: Add dough to container and wait 2 hours or until the dough has doubled in size.

docs.title: Step 12
docs.text: Slightly wet hands with cold water. Release dough from sides of container.

docs.title: Step 13
docs.text: Using a very light touch, do a coil fold. Do 2 opposite sides, then 3rd side pull dough under and then 4th side roll it over.

docs.title: Step 14
docs.text: Return to container and cover and wait until the dough doubles in size. This can take anywhere between 4 and 12 hours. Every 2 hours, do the coil fold.

docs.title: Step 15
docs.text: Prepare your banneton (if using) and very lightly flour counter/surface.

docs.title: Step 16
docs.text: Flip dough out onto it. Do letter fold and stick dough together. Pinch ends closed (for oval loaf). Pinch bottom seam together, for more tension (for boule).

docs.title: Step 17
docs.text: Lightly sprinkle flour over top (and rice flour along sides of banneton, to prevent sticking).

docs.title: Step 18
docs.text: Will take 2 to 4 hours at room temperature (until the finger poke test is passed). Place shortly before the finger poke test passes in the freezer for 45 minutes to make scoring easier.

docs.title: Step 19
docs.text: Or - place for 1 hour at room temperature, then another 6 to 24 hours in the fridge. This way your bread will be ready directly for breakfast.

docs.title: Step 20
docs.text: Preheat oven at 450°F for maximum for at least 30 minutes.

docs.title: Step 21
docs.text: If using Dutch oven, heat it in the oven for about 30 minutes (lid separated). If baking on sheet or stone, heat stone and sheet while heating oven. Also heat the container (e.g. cast iron skillet) at the bottom of the oven to use to create steam).

docs.title: Step 22
docs.text: Place inverted baking tray (with sides) on uppermost rack of oven after putting in bread, to catch the steam. At 30 minutes, remove this tray and the water container.

docs.title: Step 23
docs.text: Gently turn dough out of banneton onto parchment, or directly into hot dutch oven (careful!).

docs.title: Step 24
docs.text: Score dough to control where you will have oven spring. This takes a few attempts. You can practice this when you initially kneaded and made a smooth ball.

docs.title: Step 25
docs.text: Place in Dutch oven or on baking stone or sheet.

docs.title: Step 26
docs.text: Bake for 30 minutes covered. Remove lid of Dutch oven or remove top inverted tray and water container (if using). This makes sure we no longer have steam. That way you will develop a nice crust.

docs.title: Step 27
docs.text: Bake for 15 to 20 minutes more until your bread has your personal desired color. It is ready when the core temperature reached 203°F.

docs.title: Step 28
docs.text: Let the bread cool on a cooling rack for at least 2 hours.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.the-bread-code.io/recipe/2020/12/22/the-last-sourdough-recipe.html

docs.title: The Easiest Loaf of Bread You'll Ever Bake
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 2 loaves 3.35 hours

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 540 g bread flour
  • 1 Tbsp granulated sugar
  • 2.25 tsp instant yeast
  • 2.5 tsp salt
  • 379 g lukewarm (90-110°F) water
  • some vegetable oil or cooking spray
  • some cornmeal

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 large bowl
  • 1 sturdy spoon
  • 1 plastic wrap
  • 1 baking sheet
  • 1 cast-iron frying pan
  • 1 sieve

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Stir together 540 g to 600 g bread flour, granulated sugar, instant yeast, salt, and lukewarm (90-110°F) water in a large bowl, starting with 540 g of the flour. Use a sturdy spoon, or your stand mixer equipped with the beater paddle. Mix until everything comes together in a rough, shaggy mass of dough.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: If you’re kneading the dough by hand, turn it out onto a lightly floured surface, using some of the additional 1/2 cup of flour called for. Fold the far edge of the dough back over on itself towards you, then press it away from you with the heels of your hands. Rotate the dough 90°. Repeat this fold-press-rotate process with a rhythmic, rocking motion for about 6 minutes. When fully kneaded, the dough will be bouncy and smooth.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: If you’re using your stand mixer, switch to the dough hook and knead the dough at medium speed for about 7 minutes, until it’s smooth, elastic, and feels a bit bouncy. If the dough doesn’t form a ball that clears the sides of the bowl, sprinkle in just enough of the additional flour to make this happen.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Place the dough in a bowl that’s been lightly greased with vegetable oil or cooking spray; the bowl you started with is fine. Cover the bowl with plastic wrap or another airtight cover, and let the dough rise at room temperature until it's doubled in size, about 1 to 2 hours. If your kitchen is particularly cold (below 65°F), place the bowl of dough in your turned-off oven with the oven light on.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Gently deflate the dough and cut it in half. Pat each half into a rough 6” x 8” oval.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Working with one piece of dough at a time, grab a short side and fold the dough like a business letter (one short side into the center, the other short side over it). Use the heel of your hand to press the open edge of the “letter” closed. Gently pat and roll the dough into a log about 10” long. Repeat with the remaining piece of dough.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Place the loaves, seam-side down, on a baking sheet (lined with parchment if desired). Sprinkle the pan (or parchment) generously with cornmeal; this will keep the bread from sticking and give it a crunchy bottom crust.

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text: Let the loaves rise, lightly covered with greased plastic wrap, for 45 minutes. They should become nicely puffy. Gently poke your index finger into the side of one of the loaves; if the indentation remains, your bread is ready to bake.

docs.title: Step 9
docs.text: Towards the end of the rising time, preheat the oven to 450°F.

docs.title: Step 10
docs.text: For extra-crusty crust and a great rise, add steam to your oven as follows: While the oven is preheating, place an empty cast-iron frying pan on the lowest rack. Bring 1 cup of water to a boil in the microwave or on the stovetop.

docs.title: Step 11
docs.text: When your bread is risen, use a sieve to dust the loaves with a thin coat of flour. Then make three or four 1/2” deep diagonal slashes in each loaf; these slashes will help the bread rise evenly as it bakes. Place the bread in the oven and pour the boiling water into the frying pan below. Quickly shut the oven door. Wear good oven mitts during this process to shield your hands and arms from the steam.

docs.title: Step 12
docs.text: Bake the bread for 20 to 25 minutes, until the crust is golden brown and a loaf sounds hollow to the touch when you tap it on the bottom. The interior temperature of the bread should register at least 190°F on a digital thermometer.

docs.title: Step 13
docs.text: Turn the oven off, crack the door open, and allow the bread to remain inside for an additional 5 minutes; this helps keep the crust crisp. Remove the bread from the oven and cool it on a rack. It’s best not to cut into the bread until it’s cooled down a bit; cutting into hot bread can negatively affect its texture.

docs.title: Step 14
docs.text: Store the bread, well-wrapped, at room temperature for a couple of days. Freeze for longer storage.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.kingarthurbaking.com/recipes/the-easiest-loaf-of-bread-youll-ever-bake-recipe

docs.title: Vermont Sourdough
docs.text:
Serves Total Time 1 loaf 14.85 hours

The Sourdough Calculator may be used to generate a recipe.

docs.title: Ingredients - Liquid Levain
docs.text:
• 135 g all-purpose flour
  • 170 g cool water
  • 14 g ripe sourdough starter

docs.title: Ingredients - Dough
docs.text:
• 660 g all-purpose flour
  • 93 g whole wheat flour
  • 440 g water
  • all of the levain
  • 18 g salt

docs.title: Sun-dried Tomato & Capers
docs.text:
• 116 g sun-dried tomato, not oil packed
  • 145 g capers, strained & patted dry
  • 1 Tbsp dried oregano

docs.title: Rosemary & Roasted Garlic
docs.text:
• 2 Tbsp Rosemary
  • 2 garlic heads

docs.title: Lemon & Thyme
docs.text:
• 2 Tbsp Thyme
  • 2 Tbsp lemon zest

docs.title: Jalapeño Cheddar
docs.text:
• 210 g sharp cheddar cheese
  • 67 g jalapeño pepper
  • 34 g honey

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 bowl
  • 1 cylindrical shaped container
  • 1 Dutch oven
  • 1 cooling rack

docs.title: Baking Schedule
docs.text:
Levain

9:00 p.m.

Autolyse

9:00 a.m.

Mix

9:30 a.m.

Bulk Fermentation

10:30 a.m.

Fold

11:15 a.m.

Divide

12:00 p.m.

Shape

12:20 p.m.

Proof

12:45 p.m.

Bake

2:45 p.m.

Rest

3:30 p.m.

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: To make the liquid levain starter: Mix all of the ingredients in a medium-sized mixing bowl, or the bowl of a stand mixer. Cover and let sit for 12 to 16 hours at room temperature. The mixture should bubble and expand.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Add all of the dough ingredients (except the salt) to the bowl with the levain. Mix briefly, just to combine. If you’re using a stand mixer, use the dough hook on first speed, mixing just until everything is incorporated.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Cover the dough and let it rest for 20 to 30 minutes. This resting period is known as the autolyse, and gives the flour a chance to absorb the water, making the resulting dough easier to work with.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text:
Sprinkle the salt over the dough. Mix it in and continue to mix for several minutes. The dough won’t be smooth and elastic, but it should be cohesive and starting to feel a bit springy. Using a stand mixer and dough hook at medium speed this will take about 2 to 3 minutes.

Tip

Other mix ins can be incorporated at this step.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Cover the bowl with plastic wrap or a reusable cover and let it rest and rise for 1 hour.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: After 1 hour uncover the bowl and, using a bowl scraper or spatula, run the scraper or spatula down the inside far wall of the bowl. Bring the dough up from the bottom of the bowl, and fold it over on top of itself. Turn the bowl 90° and repeat; repeat twice more (for a total of four times), turning the bowl 90° each time. This process, which helps develop the dough, is called a fold. Re-cover the bowl, and let the dough rise for another 90 minutes, adding another fold after 45 minutes if the dough doesn’t seem elastic and strong enough.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Gently deflate the dough and divide it into two pieces; each will weigh about 750 g. Shape each piece into a rough ball, cover, and let rest for about 20 minutes; this rest will make the loaves easier to shape.

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text: After the rest, shape the two pieces of dough into rounds or oblong loaves. Place them on a piece of parchment or a lightly greased baking sheet. If the dough seems very soft, for added support turn the loaves (seam side up) into two floured brotforms, or into two bowls lined with floured smooth cotton dish towels.

docs.title: Step 9
docs.text: Cover the loaves and let them rise for 1 1/2 to 2 hours at room temperature (68°F to 78°F is ideal). Or refrigerate the covered loaves overnight.

docs.title: Step 10
docs.text: When you’re ready to bake, preheat the oven to 450°F for at least 45 minutes before baking. At the same time, place two lidded oven-safe baking pans (such as a cloche, Dutch oven, or long covered baker) into the oven to preheat. Make sure the baker you choose is safe to be preheated empty, without anything inside.

docs.title: Step 11
docs.text: When the oven is fully preheated, carefully transfer the loaves to your chosen bakers. Slash them several times across the top to allow for expansion.

docs.title: Step 12
docs.text: Cover the bakers and place them in the oven. Bake the bread for 30 minutes. Remove the covers and bake 10 to 15 minutes more, or until the bread is golden brown. Its internal temperature should register about 210°F on a digital thermometer.

docs.title: Step 13
docs.text: Remove the bread from the oven and turn it out of the pans onto a rack to cool completely.

docs.title: Step 14
docs.text: Store the bread at room temperature, loosely wrapped, for up to 5 days; freeze for longer storage.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.kingarthurbaking.com/recipes/vermont-sourdough-recipe

docs.title: Whole Wheat Bread
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 1 loaf 5.17 hours

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 397 g whole wheat flour
  • 255 g water
  • 50 g vegetable oil
  • 85 g honey, molasses, or maple syrup
  • 2.5 tsp instant yeast
  • 28 g King Arthur Baker's Special Dry Milk or nonfat dry milk
  • 8 g salt

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 large bowl
  • 1 lightly greased bowl
  • 1 8 1/2" x 4 1/2" loaf pan
  • 1 plastic wrap or a reusable cover
  • 1 aluminum foil

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Weigh your whole wheat flour; or measure it by gently spooning it into a cup, then sweeping off any excess.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: In a large bowl or the bowl of your stand mixer, combine 1 to 1 1/8 cups (227 g to 255 g) lukewarm water*, vegetable oil, honey, molasses, or maple syrup, instant yeast, King Arthur Baker's Special Dry Milk or nonfat dry milk, salt and stir just until the dough starts to leave the sides of the bowl. Let it rest for 20 to 30 minutes; this gives the flour a chance to absorb some of the liquid and the bran to soften, making the dough easier to knead.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: If kneading by hand, transfer the dough to a lightly greased surface, oil your hands, and knead it for 6 to 8 minutes, or until it's smooth and supple. If kneading in a stand mixer, attach the dough hook and knead for 5 to 7 minutes at low speed, until the dough is soft and smooth. Adjust its consistency with additional flour or water, if necessary.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Transfer the dough to a lightly greased bowl, cover it, and let it rise until puffy though not necessarily doubled in bulk, 1 to 2 hours.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Gently deflate the dough, transfer it to a lightly oiled work surface, and shape it into an 8" log. Place the log in a lightly greased 8 1/2" x 4 1/2" loaf pan and cover the pan loosely with lightly greased plastic wrap or a reusable cover.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Let the bread rise for 1 to 2 hours, or until the center has crowned about 1" above the rim of the pan. Towards the end of the rising time, preheat the oven to 350°F.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Uncover the bread, place it in the oven, and bake for 35 to 40 minutes, tenting it lightly with aluminum foil after 20 minutes to prevent over-browning. A digital thermometer inserted into the loaf's center should register at least 190°F.

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text: Remove the bread from the oven and turn it out of the pan onto a rack to cool. For a soft, flavorful crust, rub the top of the warm bread with a stick of butter. Cool completely before slicing.

docs.title: Step 9
docs.text:
Store the bread, well wrapped, at room temperature for several days; freeze for longer storage.

Tip

Want to make this bread with the help of your bread machine? Place the dough ingredients into your machine in the order listed and choose the dough or manual cycle. When the cycle is done, remove the risen dough and shape and bake as directed in the recipe above. Note: Due to the many brands of bread machine on the market and their different features, we can’t guarantee you can bake this bread start to finish in your own machine; please use the dough or manual cycle instead.

Tip

The liquid sweetener you choose makes a difference. Molasses produces the darkest loaf, one with old-fashioned flavor. Honey yields a lighter, milder loaf. Maple syrup makes a less-sweet loaf — unless you use real maple syrup, in which case it'll be similar to a loaf made with honey, albeit with a faint hint of maple.

Tip

If you're someone who tends to taste whole wheat as somewhat bitter, try substituting 1/4 cup of orange juice for 1/4 cup of the water in this recipe. A bit of orange juice tones down whole wheat's somewhat tannic taste.

Tip

Want to prolong the shelf life of this bread? Try the tangzhong technique, an Asian method for increasing the softness and shelf life of yeast bread. Begin by measuring out the flour and water you’ll be using in the recipe. Now take 3 tablespoons of the measured flour and 1/2 cup of the water; put them in a saucepan set over medium-high heat. Cook the mixture, whisking constantly, until it forms a thick slurry; this will take about 1 1/2 to 2 1/2 minutes. Transfer the cooked mixture to a bowl, let it cool to lukewarm, then combine it with the remaining flour, the remaining water (+ 2 additional tablespoons), and the other dough ingredients. Proceed with the recipe as directed. Well-wrapped and stored at room temperature, your finished loaf should stay soft and fresh at room temperature for at least several days.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.kingarthurbaking.com/recipes/classic-100-whole-wheat-bread-recipe

docs.title: 1-Bowl Carrot Apple Muffins
docs.text: Total Time 51 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 1.5 Tbsp flaxseed meal
  • 4 Tbsp water
  • 0.33 cup mashed banana
  • 0.25 cup agave or maple syrup
  • 0.25 cup olive oil
  • 0.5 cup unsweetened applesauce
  • 0.5 cup brown sugar
  • 1.5 tsp baking soda
  • 0.5 tsp salt
  • 0.5 tsp cinnamon
  • 0.5 cup almond milk
  • 1 heaping cup grated carrot
  • 0.67 cup oats
  • 0.5 cup almond meal
  • 1 heaping cup gluten-free flour blend
  • 0.25 cup walnuts (optional)

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 large mixing bowl
  • 1 muffin tin
  • 1 liners
  • 1 whisk
  • 1 toothpick

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Prepare flax eggs in a large mixing bowl by mixing flaxseed meal and water and let rest for a few minutes. Preheat oven to 375°F (190 C).

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Prepare muffin tin with liners or lightly grease them.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: To the flax eggs, add mashed banana, agave or maple syrup, olive oil and whisk to combine.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Next add unsweetened applesauce, brown sugar, baking soda, salt, cinnamon, and whisk to combine.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Add almond milk and stir.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Add grated carrot and stir.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Add oats, almond meal, and gluten-free flour blend and stir.

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text: Divide evenly among 12 muffin tins, filling them all the way up to the top, and top with crushed walnuts (optional).

docs.title: Step 9
docs.text: Bake for 32 to 36 minutes, or until deep golden brown and a toothpick inserted into the center comes out clean. When you press on the top it shouldn’t feel too spongy, so don’t be afraid of over baking! The gluten-free blend just takes longer to bake.

docs.title: Step 10
docs.text: Remove from oven and let set in the pan for 15 minutes. Then flip on their sides still in the pan to let cool completely.

docs.title: Step 11
docs.text: If you try to unwrap them too quickly, they have a tendency to stick to the wrappers.

docs.title: Step 12
docs.text: Once cooled, store in a covered container or bag at room temp to keep fresh. Freeze after that to keep fresh.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://minimalistbaker.com/one-bowl-carrot-apple-muffins-vegan-gf/

docs.title: Apple Cider Doughnuts
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 10 3.50 hours

docs.title: Ingredients - Dough
docs.text:
• 485 g apple cider
  • 128 g apple butter
  • 113 g sour cream
  • 2 tsp vanilla
  • 455 g all-purpose flour
  • 1 tsp kosher salt
  • 2.5 tsp baking powder
  • 0.5 tsp baking soda
  • 1 tsp cinnamon
  • 0.13 tsp nutmeg
  • 53 g brown sugar
  • 50 g granulated sugar
  • 2 eggs
  • 56 g melted unsalted butter

docs.title: Ingredients - Coating
docs.text:
• 198 g granulated sugar
  • 1 Tbsp cinnamon
  • some vegetable oil

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 medium saucepan
  • 1 medium bowl
  • 1 whisk
  • 1 medium bowl
  • 1 stand mixer
  • 1 parchment
  • 1 rimmed baking sheet
  • 1 plastic wrap
  • 1 small bowl
  • 1 3.25 inch round cookie cutter
  • 1 1.25" cutter
  • 1 wire rack
  • 1 large pot
  • 1 deep-fry thermometer

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Bring apple cider to a boil in a medium saucepan over medium-high heat and cook until liquid is thick, syrupy, and reduced to about ½ cup. This will take about 20 minutes. Scrape into a medium bowl and whisk in apple butter, sour cream, and vanilla until incorporated; set aside.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Whisk all-purpose flour, kosher salt, baking powder, baking soda, cinnamon, and nutmeg, in a medium bowl.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Using an electric hand beater or stand mixer, beat 1/4 cup brown sugar, 1/4 cup granulated sugar and 2 eggs on medium-high speed, until light and fluffy, about 3 to 4 minutes. Add melted unsalted butter and mix for another 1 minute.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Reduce mixer speed to low and add dry ingredients in 2 additions, alternating with cider mixture in 2 additions, starting with dry ingredients and ending with cider mixture (dough will be very soft and sticky).

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Scrape dough onto a parchment lined rimmed baking sheet thoroughly dusted with flour (about 1/3 cup). Dust hands and top of dough with more flour, then gently pat dough to into a 3/4" thick rectangle. Dust with more flour and tightly cover with plastic wrap; chill dough at least 3 hours, or up to overnight.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Make cinnamon sugar: Whisk 1 cup granulated sugar and 1 Tablespoon cinnamon in a small bowl until no lumps remain.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: While dough is chilling, cut 10 squares of parchment paper, each about 4 inches square. This will make transferring donuts into hot oil much easier. Working on baking sheet, punch out as many rounds as you can with the donut cutter or 3.25 inch round cookie cutter. Dip cutter into bowl of flour before each cut. If you used the 3¼ inch round cookie cutter, you will need to use the 1.25" cutter to punch out center of each round. Place each donut on a 4 inch square of parchment paper.

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text: Gather doughnut scraps, reserving holes, and gently re-roll without overworking dough; repeat until all dough has been used (you should have 10 doughnuts).

docs.title: Step 9
docs.text: Set a wire rack inside a paper towel-lined rimmed baking sheet. Fit a large pot with deep-fry thermometer and pour in vegetable oil to a depth of 3". Heat over medium-high until thermometer registers 350°F. Working in batches, fry doughnuts until deep golden brown, about 3 minutes per side. Transfer to prepared rack and let cool slightly. Fry doughnut holes until deep golden brown, about 2 minutes per side. Transfer to prepared rack and let cool slightly. Toss warm doughnuts and doughnut holes in cinnamon sugar.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dVCYAqcTvVc

docs.title: Apple Pie Overnight Oats
docs.text: Total Time 6.22 hours

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 0.75 cup chopped apples
  • 0.75 tsp cinnamon
  • 2 Tbsp maple syrup
  • 1 pinch salt
  • 0.75 cup almond milk
  • 1 Tbsp chia seeds
  • 0.5 tsp cinnamon
  • 2 Tbsp cashew or almond butter
  • 1 tsp vanilla
  • 0.5 cup rolled oats

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 small saucepan
  • 1 small bowl
  • 2 small mason

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: APPLES: To a small saucepan, add chopped apples, 3/4 tsp cinnamon, maple syrup, and salt and mix to evenly distribute the cinnamon.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Turn heat on low and cover. Cook, stirring occasionally, for about 10 minutes or until the apples are soft and tender. Remove the lid, turn the heat up to medium, and cook for 2 to 3 minutes more, stirring constantly, to evaporate some of the juices and create a nice syrup around the apples. Once most of the liquid is gone, turn off the heat and set aside.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: OATS: In a small bowl or liquid measuring cup, mix the almond milk, chia seeds, maple syrup, 1/2 tsp cinnamon, cashew or almond butter, and vanilla. Add the rolled oats and stir until well-combined.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Get two small mason jars or small bowls with lids. Place about a quarter of the cooked apple mixture into the bottom of each container, add half the oat mixture to each as your middle layer, then divide and place the rest of the cooked apples on top of the oats. Place in the refrigerator overnight, or for at least 6 hours.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Enjoy chilled or at room temperature. Overnight oats will keep in the refrigerator for 2-3 days, though best within the first 12-24 hours in our experience. Not freezer friendly.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://minimalistbaker.com/apple-pie-overnight-oats/

docs.title: Apricot Honey Oatmeal
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 4 5 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 3.5 cups water
  • 0.33 cup chopped dried apricots
  • 0.25 cup honey
  • 0.5 tsp cinnamon
  • 2 cups oats

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text: • 1 3 quart saucepan

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: In 3 quart saucepan, bring water, chopped dried apricots, honey and cinnamon to a boil.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Stir in oats; return to boil.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Reduce heat to medium; cook about 1 minute for quick oats (or 5 minutes for old fashioned oats) or until most of liquid is absorbed, stirring occasionally. Remove from heat.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Let stand until of desired consistency.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.quakeroats.com/cooking-and-recipes/apricot-honey-oatmeal

docs.title: Belgian Waffles
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 12 1.50 hours

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 3 cups warm milk
  • 2.25 tsp active dry yeast
  • 170 g unsalted butter
  • 99 g sugar
  • 3 egg yolks
  • 2 tsp vanilla
  • 1.5 tsp salt
  • 480 g all-purpose flour
  • 3 egg whites
  • some confectioners' sugar

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 waffle iron
  • 1 large bowl
  • 1 large
  • 1 plastic wrap

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Preheat a waffle iron. Whisk together in a large bowl warm milk (105° to 115°F) and active dry yeast.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Let stand until the yeast is dissolved, about 5 minutes, then stir until smooth. Whisk in melted unsalted butter, sugar, egg yolks, vanilla, and salt.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Add in 3 additions, beating with a large spoon until smooth after each addition all-purpose flour.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Cover tightly with plastic wrap and let rise at room temperature until doubled in volume, 1 to 1.5 hours. Stir to deflate the batter. Beat until soft peaks form, then fold into the batter egg whites.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Cook and sprinkle with confectioners' sugar.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • Joy of Cooking

docs.title: Breakfast Potatoes
docs.text: Total Time 14 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 1.5 lbs red potatoes
  • 4 Tbsp butter
  • 0.5 tsp garlic powder
  • 1 tsp salt
  • 0.5 tsp pepper

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 electric skillet
  • 1 microwave

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Heat skillet to medium or an electric skillet to 350°F.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Bake red potatoes in microwave for 5 to 6 minutes. Quarter cooked potatoes, and place butter 1 Tbsp at a time onto hot skillet.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Once all potatoes are in the skillet, spray the top with olive oil and season with half of the garlic powder, salt, and pepper.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: After about 4 minutes, flip potatoes and repeat the spray and seasoning process and cook 4 minutes more.

docs.title: Breakfast Tofu Scramble
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 4 12 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 120 g onion
  • 1 clove garlic
  • 120 g green pepper
  • 120 g red pepper
  • 180 g mushrooms
  • 16 oz extra-firm tofu
  • 0.25 tsp turmeric
  • 1 tsp cumin
  • some pepper
  • some salt

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Add 1/4 cup of water to large saute pan. Once heated, add onion.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: When the aroma releases from the onion and starts to become translucent, add garlic. Cook for 2 minutes, add green pepper, red pepper and mushrooms and add more water if vegetables are sticking to the pan. Cook for about 4 minutes or until vegetables are tender.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Crumble extra-firm tofu with hands and add to pan along with turmeric, mixing well. Add cumin, pepper, and salt, then cook for another 4 to 6 minutes until everything is cooked through.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Serve with whole-grain toast or on a warm corn tortilla.

docs.title: Brown Sugar Honey Butter Toast
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 2 slices 18 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 40 g unsalted butter
  • 40 g light brown sugar
  • 20 g honey
  • 1 pinch salt
  • 2 slices Japanese Milk Bread

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 small bowl
  • 1 miniature spatula
  • 1 sheet pan
  • 1 parchment

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Preheat the oven to 350°F.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Mix the soft unsalted butter, light brown sugar, honey, and salt in a small bowl.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Cut 1 to 1.5 inch slices of Japanese Milk Bread.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Spread the butter mixture all over the slices of bread with a miniature spatula, including the crust.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text:
Bake the bread on a sheet pan lined with parchment for 16 to 18 minutes, flipping halfway through.

Tip

It's best to use 1 day old bread so that it's firm.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jVTRLQJQAxo

docs.title: Buttermilk Pancakes
docs.text: Total Time 15 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 1 pancakes
  • 0.5 tsp baking soda
  • 1 tsp baking powder
  • 1.5 cups buttermilk

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Prepare pancakes as directed. Add 1/2 tsp baking soda to the dry ingredients.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Decrease the baking powder to 1 tsp. Substitute buttermilk for the milk.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • Joy of Cooking

docs.title: Buttermilk Whole Wheat Waffles
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 2 0 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• some strawberries
  • some raspberries
  • some blackberries
  • some blueberries
  • 1 lemon
  • some sugar
  • 0.5 cup whole wheat flour
  • 0.5 cup all-purpose flour
  • 1 Tbsp cornmeal
  • 0.25 tsp salt
  • 1 tsp baking soda
  • 1 egg
  • 1 cup buttermilk
  • 2.5 Tbsp butter
  • some milk
  • some maple syrup

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 waffle iron
  • 1 medium bowl
  • 1 medium bowl

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Combine strawberries, raspberries, blackberries, and blueberries and then toss gently with a little lemon juice, lemon zest and then sprinkle with a little sugar to taste. Set aside to macerate while mixing up the waffle ingredients.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Preheat waffle iron.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: In a medium bowl, whisk together the whole wheat flour, all-purpose flour, cornmeal, salt, and baking soda.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: In another medium bowl, whisk the egg. Add the buttermilk and the cooled melted butter and whisk again. Gradually add to the dry ingredients to form a batter and mix gently with a spoon until combined. Thin batter with a little 2% milk if needed.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Lightly oil the waffle grill and spoon batter into the waffle iron. Cook until golden brown. Serve immediately with butter, maple syrup and berries. Also, the waffles freeze well.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.bobsredmill.com/recipes/how-to-make/buttermilk-whole-wheat-waffles/

docs.title: Chocolate Cake Doughnuts
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 12 0 minutes

docs.title: Doughnuts
docs.text:
• 2.25 cups all-purpose flour
  • 1 cup unsweetened cocoa powder
  • 1 tsp baking powder
  • 0.5 tsp baking soda
  • 0.75 tsp salt
  • 4 Tbsp butter
  • 1 cup sugar
  • 1 large egg
  • 1.5 cup sour cream
  • 3 qts vegetable oil

docs.title: Glaze
docs.text:
• 3 cups confectioners' sugar
  • 0.5 cup whole milk
  • 0.25 cup unsweetened cocoa powder

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 bowl
  • 1 stand mixer
  • 1 rolling pin
  • 1 3-inch doughnut cutter
  • 1 wire rack
  • 1 paper towels
  • 1 large Dutch oven
  • 1 slotted spoon or wire skimmer

Note

Use a Dutch oven that holds 6 quarts or more. If you don't have a 3-inch doughnut cutter, use a 3-inch round biscuit cutter and stamp out the holes with a 1.5-inch biscuit cutter.

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Whisk all-purpose flour, unsweetened cocoa powder, baking powder, baking soda, and salt together in bowl; set aside. Using stand mixer fitted with paddle, beat butter and sugar on medium-high speed until pale and fluffy, about 3 minutes. Add egg and beat until combined. Add sour cream and beat until smooth. Reduce speed to low and add flour mixture in 3 additions, scraping down bowl as needed. Stir batter once or twice with rubber spatula to ensure no dry streaks remain. Transfer batter to lightly greased bowl, cover with plastic wrap, and refrigerate for 1 hour.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Transfer batter to floured counter and roll with heavily floured rolling pin into 10-inch round, about ½ inch thick. Using heavily floured 3-inch doughnut cutter, stamp out dough rings and holes, reflouring cutter between cuts. Gather scraps and gently press into disk; repeat rolling and stamping process until all dough is used. Transfer doughnuts and holes to lightly floured rimmed baking sheet, cover, and refrigerate for 30 minutes.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Set wire rack in second rimmed baking sheet and line with triple layer of paper towels. Add vegetable oil to large Dutch oven until it measures about 2 inches deep and heat over medium-high heat to 375°F. Carefully place 3 doughnuts and 3 doughnut holes into hot oil and fry until golden brown, about 45 seconds per side for holes and 60 seconds per side for doughnuts. Adjust burner, if necessary, to maintain oil temperature between 350°F and 375°F. Using slotted spoon or wire skimmer, transfer doughnuts to prepared rack. Return oil to 375°F and repeat with remaining doughnuts and holes in 3 batches; let cool slightly.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Whisk confectioners' sugar, whole milk, and unsweetened cocoa powder in bowl until combined. Once doughnuts are cool enough to handle, remove paper towels from rack. Dip both sides of each doughnut and doughnut hole into glaze, shaking off any excess, and return to wire rack. Let sit until glaze has set, about 10 minutes. Serve.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • Cook's Illustrated

docs.title: Chocolate Chip Muffins
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 12 1.72 hours

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 320 g all-purpose flour
  • 200 g granulated sugar
  • 2.5 tsp baking powder
  • 0.5 tsp baking soda
  • 0.5 tsp salt
  • 1.5 cups mini semi sweet chocolate chips
  • 2 large eggs
  • 65 g sour cream or full fat Greek yogurt
  • 2 tsp vanilla
  • 2 Tbsp maple syrup
  • 2 Tbsp vegetable oil
  • 113 g unsalted butter
  • 255 g buttermilk
  • 3 Tbsp coarse sugar

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 large mixing bowl
  • 1 bowl
  • 1 plastic wrap
  • 1 muffin (or cupcake) tin
  • 1 paper liners
  • 1 ice cream scoop
  • 1 cooling rack

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: In a large mixing bowl, whisk together the all-purpose flour, granulated sugar, baking powder, baking soda, salt, and 1 cup of mini semi sweet chocolate chips.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: In a separate bowl, whisk together the eggs and sour cream or full fat Greek yogurt until completely smooth.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Then mix in the vanilla, maple syrup, and vegetable oil followed by the unsalted butter and then buttermilk.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Pour the wet ingredients into the bowl of dry ingredients and gently whisk to combine. Stop right when the batter is fully combined – careful not to over mix.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Cover the bowl with plastic wrap and let it rest at room temperature for 1 hour. This will give the leaveners a head start, so each muffin bakes with a tall muffin top in the oven. If you’re in a rush, you can bake the batter right away. They just won’t be as domed on top.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: After 1 hour, preheat the oven to 425°F and line a muffin (or cupcake) tin with 12 paper liners.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Using an ice cream scoop, gently run the scoop through the bowl of batter. You’ll notice the batter is very fluffy, so be careful not to disrupt this as you scoop. Just run the scoop through the bowl and pull out the batter. Don’t mix it around or bother it too much.

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text: Over fill each liner just a smidge. You may have about 1 scoop of batter leftover which is to be expected.

docs.title: Step 9
docs.text: Top each muffin with a sprinkle of coarse sugar and a pile of mini chocolate chips. Really lay on those chocolate chips as they’ll disperse and spread as the muffins grow.

docs.title: Step 10
docs.text: Bake at 425°F for 8 minutes. Then, with the oven door still closed, reduce the oven temperature to 350°F and bake for another 8 to 10 minutes. You do not need to wait for the temperature to reach 350°F to continue baking, simply just adjust the temperature down to 350°F and set a timer for 8 to 10 minutes.

docs.title: Step 11
docs.text: Quickly test a muffin with a toothpick to see if they’re ready, but try not to keep the oven door open for too long as you do not want the hot air to escape.

docs.title: Step 12
docs.text: Remove the muffins and let them cool for 10 minutes. Then, carefully transfer each muffin to a cooling rack. The muffins may stick to the pan around the bottom edges, so just use a knife to pop them loose if needed.

docs.title: Step 13
docs.text: Let the muffins cool for another 10 to 15 minutes. They’re best served warm so enjoy!

docs.title: Sources
docs.text:
• https://butternutbakeryblog.com/best-chocolate-chip-muffins/
  • https://www.thepancakeprincess.com/best-chocolate-chip-muffin-bake-off/

docs.title: Chocolate Muffins
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 9 jumbo muffins 25 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients - Muffins
docs.text:
• 113 g unsalted butter
  • 1 cup granulated sugar
  • 0.5 cup canola oil
  • 1 Tbsp vanilla
  • 3 large eggs
  • 1 3.9-oz box dry chocolate pudding
  • 1.5 cups cake flour
  • 1 tsp baking soda
  • 1.5 tsp baking powder
  • 1.5 tsp kosher salt
  • 0.5 cup dark cocoa powder
  • 1 cup sour cream
  • 0.33 cup buttermilk
  • 1.5 cups semi-sweet chocolate chunks

docs.title: Ingredients - Ganache
docs.text:
• 1.25 cups bittersweet chocolate chips
  • 1 14-oz can condensed milk
  • 0.25 tsp vanilla

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 6-ounce muffin cups
  • 1 paper muffin liners
  • 1 stand mixer
  • 1 paddle attachment
  • 1 small saucepan
  • 1 pastry bag
  • 1 paring knife

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Preheat your oven to 400°F.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Line jumbo, 6-ounce muffin cups with paper muffin liners.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: In the large bowl of a stand mixer with the paddle attachment, beat the unsalted butter, granulated sugar and canola oil until light and creamy. Add the vanilla extract and beat until combined.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Add the eggs one at a time and beat just until combined.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Beat in the dry chocolate pudding mix until blended.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: In a separate bowl, whisk together the cake flour, baking soda, baking powder, kosher salt and dark cocoa powder to ensure there are no lumps.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: On low speed, add the dry ingredients into the butter mixture in two installments, alternating with the sour cream. Beat just until combined and no flour streaks are visible. Next, beat in the buttermilk until just combined. Fold in the 1 1/2 cups of semi-sweet chocolate chunks.

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text: Scoop the batter into the lined muffin cups. You want them pretty full and a nice dome shape. I like to add a few more chocolate chunks on the top before baking.

docs.title: Step 9
docs.text: Place the muffins in the oven on 400°F for 5 minutes, then leave the muffins in the oven and lower the temperature to 325°F for approximately 20 minutes, or until a toothpick comes out of the center clean.

docs.title: Step 10
docs.text: In a small saucepan, add the bittersweet chocolate chips and condensed milk. Head over medium heat, stirring constantly until the chips are melted. Whisk in the vanilla extract and then pour the ganache into a pastry bag.

docs.title: Step 11
docs.text: Using a paring knife, remove about a 1 inch round section of the center of each muffin. Pipe some of the ganache into each muffin hole and enjoy!

docs.title: Sources
docs.text:
• https://abcnews.go.com/GMA/Food/paris-olympics-viral-chocolate-muffin-recipe-recreate-norwegian/story?id=112478502
  • https://www.thepancakeprincess.com/best-chocolate-muffin-bake-off/

docs.title: Cindy's Banana Overnight Oats
docs.text: Total Time 6.00 hours

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 2 cups almond milk
  • 3 bananas
  • 2.5 cup rolled oats
  • some salt

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 immersion blender
  • 1 mason jar

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: With an immersion blender, blend almond milk and bananas.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: To a mason jar or small bowl with a lid, add the almond milk and banana mixture and rolled oats and stir a few more times. Then press down with a spoon to ensure all oats have been moistened and are immersed in almond milk.

docs.title: Step 3
