  • 1 electric mixer
  • 1 wire racks
  • 1 bowl

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Preheat the oven to 350°F (175°C). Grease two baking sheets with nonstick spray or line them with parchment paper.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: In a large bowl, beat the unsalted butter, softened, brown sugar, and granulated sugar with an electric mixer at medium speed until light and fluffy, about 5 minutes. Beat in the egg, vanilla, and pumpkin purée.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Sift the all-purpose flour, cinnamon, baking soda, baking powder, and salt in a separate bowl. Gradually pour the dry ingredients into the butter-sugar mixture and gently mix until well combined. Gently mix in the chopped walnuts (optional).

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Drop scoops of cookie dough onto the prepared baking sheets, allowing for a 2 inch space in between.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Bake for 8 to 10 minutes or until the edges are lightly browned. Cool on wire racks.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Meanwhile, make the frosting. In a bowl, beat the unsalted butter, softened, vanilla, and cream cheese, softened until smooth and lump-free. Gradually add the confectioners' sugar and beat until smooth and creamy.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Spread frosting over the cooled cookies. Serve and enjoy!

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://insanelygoodrecipes.com/pumpkin-cookies-with-cream-cheese-frosting/

docs.title: Salted Caramel Chocolate Macarons
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 36 60 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients - Macarons
docs.text:
• 170 g ground almonds
  • 160 g confectioners' sugar
  • 45 g unsweetened cocoa powder
  • 144 g egg whites (Split into 72 g each)
  • 210 g granulated sugar
  • 70 ml cold water

docs.title: Ingredients - Salted Caramel Chocolate Ganache
docs.text:
• 220 g granulated sugar
  • 212 g heavy cream
  • 75 g 54 percent cocoa chocolate
  • 0.75 tsp flaked sea salt
  • 15 g unsalted butter

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Make french macarons using 170 g ground almonds, 160 g confectioners' sugar, 45 g unsweetened cocoa powder, 144 g egg whites (Split into 72 g each), 210 g granulated sugar, and 70 ml cold water. The cocoa is to be added to the ground almond and confectioners' sugar mixture.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Make the salted caramel chocolate ganache filling by making a dry caramel minus the butter using 220 g of granulated sugar and 212 g of heavy cream.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Separate the caramel into 3/4 for ganache and 1/4 for salted caramel.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Add 54 percent cocoa chocolate to the 3/4 caramel to make the ganache.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Add flaked sea salt and unsalted butter to 1/4 caramel to make the dry salted caramel.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Pop both in fridge and chill for 1 hour.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Assemble the macarons by piping a ring of the chocolate ganache on the cookie and then filling the ring with the salted caramel.

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text: After assembly, refrigerate overnight or for a full 24 hours so that the filling solidifies.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QgTBX1LUEZc

docs.title: Salted Peanut Butter
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 12 22 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 1.75 cups light brown sugar
  • 2 large eggs
  • 0.5 tsp vanilla
  • 1.75 cups creamy peanut butter
  • some sea salt

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 rimmed sheet pan
  • 1 parchment paper
  • 1 medium bowl
  • 1 spatula

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Preheat the oven to 350°F. Line a rimmed sheet pan with parchment paper.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: In a medium bowl, vigorously whisk together the light brown sugar and eggs until incorporated. Whisk in the vanilla extract. Add the creamy peanut butter and mix with a spatula until smooth and completely incorporated, and until no ribbons of peanut butter can be seen. You know the dough is ready when it has the consistency of Play-Doh.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Using a scoop or a spoon, form the dough into 12 approximately 2 inch (2 to 2.25 ounce) balls and place them on the prepared rimmed sheet pan. For smaller cookies, use a heaping tablespoon.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Sprinkle the dough balls lightly with coarse-grained sea salt just before baking. Bake for 20 to 22 minutes, turning the rimmed sheet pan once halfway through baking (for smaller cookies, bake for 16 to 18 minutes). When finished, the cookies will be lightly golden and cracked on top. Let cool completely before serving.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: You can bake these cookies as soon as the dough is prepared, but they will retain their shape better if you freeze them for 15 minutes before baking.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text:
• https://oven.ly/blogs/recipes/salted-peanut-butter-cookies
  • https://www.thekitchn.com/peanut-butter-cookie-recipe-reviews-23029502

docs.title: Samoas
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 14 2 hours 15 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients - Cookie
docs.text:
• 1 cup unsalted butter
  • 0.5 cup granulated sugar
  • 2 cups all-purpose flour
  • 0.25 tsp baking powder
  • 0.5 tsp salt
  • 2 Tbsp milk
  • 0.5 tsp vanilla

docs.title: Ingredients - Coconut Topping
docs.text:
• 3 cups coconut
  • 20 oz caramels
  • 4 Tbsp milk
  • 12 oz dark chocolate

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 stand mixer
  • 1 bowl
  • 1 plastic wrap
  • 1 doughnut cutter
  • 1 baking sheet
  • 1 parchment paper
  • 1 wire rack
  • 1 double boiler
  • 1 large bowl
  • 1 piping bag or fork

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Preheat the oven to 350°F.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: In the bowl of a stand mixer with a paddle attachment, cream the unsalted butter and granulated sugar until light and fluffy.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: In a separate bowl, stir together the all-purpose flour, baking powder, and salt.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Add the flour mixture to the butter, in a few additions, and beat until combined. Stop to scrape the sides and the bottom of the bowl a few times.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: After that, add the milk and vanilla and mix to combine.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Remove the dough from the mixer and separate it into two equal halves. Press each half into a disk and wrap it in plastic wrap. Chill in the fridge for about 1 hour.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Lightly flour a flat surface and once the dough has chilled, roll it out on the floured surface into a 1/8 inch thick circle.

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text: Using a doughnut cutter, cut out as many cookies as possible. Also, you can use a larger and a smaller glass, to cut the cookies and also the hole in the center.

docs.title: Step 9
docs.text: Arrange the cookies on a baking sheet lined with parchment paper 1 inch apart.

docs.title: Step 10
docs.text: Bake for 10 to 15 minutes or until they are pale golden brown.

docs.title: Step 11
docs.text: Transfer the cookies onto a wire rack to cool completely before adding the topping.

docs.title: Step 12
docs.text: In the meantime, spread the coconut onto a baking sheet lined with parchment paper.

docs.title: Step 13
docs.text: Bake it for 10 to 15 minutes at 350°F until toasted, stirring frequently.

docs.title: Step 14
docs.text: Once done, remove from the oven to cool.

docs.title: Step 15
docs.text: Melt the caramels and milk in a double boiler over medium-low heat and stir until melted.

docs.title: Step 16
docs.text: Remove from heat, and in a large bowl combine half of the melted caramel with the toasted coconut. Stir until fully combined.

docs.title: Step 17
docs.text: Spread the remaining caramel into a thin layer onto the cookies.

docs.title: Step 18
docs.text: Next, using your hands, press the coconut mixture onto the caramel. Let the cookie cool.

docs.title: Step 19
docs.text: Melt the dark chocolate in a double boiler and dip the bottom of the cookies into the chocolate and place them on a wax paper-lined baking sheet.

docs.title: Step 20
docs.text: Use a piping bag or fork to drizzle the remaining chocolate on top of the cookies.

docs.title: Step 21
docs.text: Let the cookies sit until the chocolate hardens before serving.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://sweetandsavorymeals.com/samoas-cookies-or-caramel-delites-recipe/

docs.title: Shortbread
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 20 cookies 55 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 0.75 lb (340 g) unsalted butter
  • 1 cup granulated sugar
  • 1 tsp vanilla
  • 3.5 cup all-purpose flour
  • 0.25 tsp salt
  • 7 oz (198 g) semi-sweet chocolate

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 electric mixer
  • 1 medium bowl
  • 1 ungreased baking sheet
  • 1 parchment paper
  • 1 wooden spoon
  • 1 glass bowl

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Preheat the oven to 350°F.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: In the bowl of an electric mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, mix together the unsalted butter and 1 cup of granulated sugar until they are just combined. Add the vanilla. In a medium bowl, sift together the all-purpose flour and salt, then add them to the butter-and-sugar mixture. Mix on low speed until the dough starts to come together. Dump onto a surface dusted with flour and shape into a flat disk. Wrap in plastic and chill for 30 minutes.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Roll the dough 1/2-inch thick and cut with a 3 by 1 inch finger shaped cutter. Place the cookies on an ungreased baking sheet and sprinkle with sugar. Bake for 20 to 25 minutes, until the edges begin to brown. Allow to cool to room temperature.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: When the cookies are cool, place them on a baking sheet lined with parchment paper. Put 3 ounces of the chocolate in a glass bowl and microwave on high power for 30 seconds. (Don't trust your microwave timer; time it with your watch.) Stir with a wooden spoon. Continue to heat and stir in 30 second increments until the chocolate is just melted. Add the remaining chocolate and allow it to sit at room temperature, stirring often, until it's completely smooth. Stir vigorously until the chocolate is smooth and slightly cooled; stirring makes it glossier.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Drizzle 1/2 of each cookie with just enough chocolate to coat it.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text:
• https://www.foodnetwork.com/recipes/ina-garten/shortbread-cookies-recipe-1945855
  • https://www.thekitchn.com/shortbread-cookie-recipe-showdown-23480965

docs.title: Simple Sugar Cookies
docs.text: Total Time 18 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 0.5 cup vegetable shortening
  • 0.67 cup sugar
  • 0.25 cup buttermilk
  • 1 Tbsp vanilla
  • 0.13 tsp nutmeg
  • 2 cups flour
  • 0.5 tsp baking soda
  • 0.25 tsp salt

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 large bowl
  • 1 parchment-lined baking sheet
  • 1 cookie scoop

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Preheat the oven to 350°F.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: In a large bowl, beat together the vegetable shortening and sugar until smooth. Add the buttermilk and vanilla, again beating until well combined. The mixture may look a bit curdled, which is OK. Add the nutmeg, flour, baking soda, and salt to the wet ingredients and beat until the mixture forms a cohesive dough.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Drop the dough in round balls onto a parchment-lined baking sheet. They should be a bit bigger than a Ping-Pong ball, a bit smaller than a golf ball. Using a cookie scoop (or a small ice cream scoop that holds about 2 level tablespoons of liquid) makes this task extremely simple. Leave about 2 between the dough balls, as they’ll spread as they bake. If you want a crisp cookie, flatten the cookies as described above. If you like a chewier center, leave them as is.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Bake the cookies for 16 to 18 minutes, until they’re just beginning to brown around the bottom edges. Remove them from the oven and cool on a rack. As they cool, they’ll become crisp. If you want them to remain crisp, store them in an airtight container when they’re totally cool. If you want them to get a bit chewy, store them in a bag with a slice of apple.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • The King Arthur Baking Company All-Purpose Baker's Companion

docs.title: Snickerdoodles
docs.text: Total Time 3.04 days

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 1 cup (226 g) unsalted butter
  • 2.5 cups (300 g) all-purpose flour
  • 2 tsp cream of tartar
  • 1 tsp baking soda
  • 0.75 tsp salt
  • 0.5 cup (107 g) light brown sugar
  • 1 cup (198 g) granulated sugar
  • 1 vanilla bean
  • 2 large eggs
  • 1 Tbsp cinnamon
  • 2 Tbsp (25 g) granulated sugar

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 medium bowl
  • 1 electric mixer
  • 1 large bowl
  • 1 rimmed baking sheet
  • 1 parchment paper
  • 1 medium bowl

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Melt and cool the unsalted butter slightly.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Whisk all-purpose flour, cream of tartar, baking soda, and salt in a medium bowl. Using an electric mixer on medium speed, beat unsalted butter, light brown sugar, and 1 cup granulated sugar in a large bowl, scraping down sides, until incorporated. Scrape in seeds from vanilla bean; reserve pod for another use.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Add eggs and continue to beat until mixture is pale yellow, begins to thicken, and falls from beaters in a ribbon-like stream, about 3 minutes. Reduce mixer speed to low. Gradually add dry ingredients and continue to beat, scraping down sides and bottom of bowl, until just combined. Cover and chill for at least 24 hours to age.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Arrange a rack in center of oven; preheat to 375°F. Line a rimmed baking sheet with parchment paper. Whisk cinnamon and remaining 2 Tbsp granulated sugar in a medium bowl.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Using a 1 oz (30 g) ice cream scoop (scoop number 40) or a generous, heaping tablespoonful, portion cookies and roll into small balls with your hands. Toss in cinnamon-sugar until coated all over. Transfer to prepared sheet, spacing about 3" apart. Do not flatten; cookies will spread as they bake.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text:
Bake cookies until edges are lightly browned and firm but centers are puffed and soft, 8 to 10 minutes (mine was 9 minutes). Let cool on sheets 10 minutes, then transfer to a wire rack and let cool completely.

Do Ahead

Do Ahead: Cookie dough can be made 3 days ahead; cover and chill. Let dough come to room temperature before portioning and coating in cinnamon-sugar.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text:
• https://www.bonappetit.com/recipe/best-snickerdoodles
  • https://www.thekitchn.com/snickerdoodle-recipe-reviews-22969541

docs.title: Soft White Chocolate Chip Cranberry Cookies
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 24 1.32 hours

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 170 g unsalted butter
  • 150 g dark brown sugar
  • 50 g granulated sugar
  • 1 large egg
  • 2 tsp vanilla
  • 250 g all-purpose flour
  • 2 tsp cornstarch
  • 1 tsp baking soda
  • 0.5 tsp salt
  • 135 g white chocolate chips
  • 140 g dried cranberries

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 stand mixer
  • 1 bowl
  • 1 large baking sheets
  • 1 parchment paper or silicone baking mats

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: In a large bowl using a hand-held mixer or stand mixer with paddle attachment, beat the unsalted butter, dark brown sugar, and granulated sugar together on medium speed until combined and creamy, about 2 minutes. Beat in the egg and vanilla. Scrape down the sides and bottom of the bowl and beat again as needed to combine.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: In a separate bowl, whisk the all-purpose flour, cornstarch, baking soda and salt together. On low speed, slowly mix into the wet ingredients until combined. The cookie dough will be soft and thick. Add the white chocolate chips and dried cranberries and beat on low speed until combined. Cover dough tightly and chill in the refrigerator for at least 1 hour and up to 3 to 4 days. Chilling is imperative to prevent the cookies from over-spreading.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Remove cookie dough from the refrigerator. If the cookie dough chilled longer than 3 to 4 hours, let it sit at room temperature for about 30 minutes. This makes the firm cookie dough easier to scoop and roll.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Preheat oven to 350°F (177°C). Line large baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone baking mats. Set aside.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: As the oven preheats, scoop and roll dough, about 1.5 Tablespoons (30 g) of dough each, into balls. The dough may be slightly crumbly, but will come together as you work it with your hands. Arrange dough balls 3 inches apart on the prepared baking sheets.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Bake for 11 to 12 minutes or until lightly browned around the edges. The centers will still look soft. If cookies didn’t spread much, lightly bang the baking sheets on the counter a couple times while the cookies are still warm. They’ll stretch and deflate.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Allow cookies to cool on the baking sheet for 5 minutes. During this time, press extra white chocolate chips and dried cranberries into the warm tops. This is optional and only for looks. After 5 minutes, transfer to a wire rack to cool completely.

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text: Cookies stay fresh covered at room temperature for up to 1 week.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/soft-baked-white-chocolate-chip-cranberry-cookies/

docs.title: Tante Myrn's Sugar Cookies
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 4 dozen 60 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 1 cup (226 g) butter
  • 1 cup (114 g) confectioners' sugar
  • 1 cup (198 g) granulated sugar
  • 2 eggs
  • 1 cup (198 g) vegetable oil
  • 2 tsp vanilla
  • 1 tsp baking soda
  • 1 tsp cream of tartar
  • 0.5 tsp salt
  • 5 cups (600 g) flour

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 medium bowl
  • 1 baking sheet

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Preheat oven to 350°F.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: In medium bowl, cream butter with confectioners' sugar and 1 cup granulated sugar. Beat in eggs until smooth. Slowly stir in vegetable oil, vanilla, baking soda, cream of tartar, salt, and flour.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Chill for easy handling. Shape into walnut size balls. Dip in sugar. Place on baking sheet and press down. Bake for 10 to 12 minutes.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • Tante Myrna Seccia

docs.title: The Best Sugar Cookies
docs.text: Total Time 2.25 hours

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 281 g all-purpose flour
  • 0.5 tsp baking powder
  • 0.25 tsp salt
  • 170 g unsalted butter
  • 150 g granulated sugar
  • 1 large egg
  • 2 tsp vanilla
  • 0.5 tsp almond extract
  • some royal icing (optional)

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 medium bowl
  • 1 hand mixer or a stand mixer
  • 1 large baking sheets
  • 1 parchment paper or silicone baking mats

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Whisk the all-purpose flour, baking powder, and salt together in a medium bowl. Set aside.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: In a large bowl using a hand mixer or a stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the unsalted butter and granulated sugar together on high speed until completely smooth and creamy, about 2 minutes. Add the egg, vanilla, and almond extract (if using) and beat on high speed until combined, about 1 minute. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl and beat again as needed to combine.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Add the dry ingredients to the wet ingredients and mix on low until combined. Dough will be relatively soft. If the dough seems too soft and sticky for rolling, add 1 more Tablespoon of flour.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Divide the dough into 2 equal parts. Place each portion onto a piece of lightly floured parchment paper or a lightly floured silicone baking mat. With a lightly floured rolling pin, roll the dough out to about 1/4 inch thickness. Use more flour if the dough seems too sticky. The rolled-out dough can be any shape, as long as it is evenly 1/4 inch thick.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Lightly dust one of the rolled-out doughs with flour. Place a piece of parchment on top. (This prevents sticking.) Place the 2nd rolled-out dough on top. Cover with plastic wrap or aluminum foil, then refrigerate for at least 1 to 2 hours and up to 2 days.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text:
Once chilled, preheat oven to 350°F (177°C). Line 2 to 3 large baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone baking mats. Carefully remove the top dough piece from the refrigerator. If it’s sticking to the bottom, run your hand under it to help remove it. Using a cookie cutter, cut the dough into shapes. Re-roll the remaining dough and continue cutting until all is used. Repeat with 2nd piece of dough.

Note

It doesn’t seem like a lot of dough, but you get a lot of cookies from the dough scraps you re-roll.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Arrange cookies on baking sheets 3 inches apart. Bake for 11 to 12 minutes or until lightly browned around the edges. If your oven has hot spots, rotate the baking sheet halfway through bake time. Allow cookies to cool on the baking sheet for 5 minutes then transfer to a wire rack to cool completely before decorating.

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text: Decorate the cooled cookies with royal icing or easy cookie icing. Feel free to tint either icing with gel food coloring. See post above for recommended decorating tools. No need to cover the decorated cookies as you wait for the icing to set. If it’s helpful, decorate the cookies directly on a baking sheet so you can stick the entire baking sheet in the refrigerator to help speed up the icing setting.

docs.title: Step 9
docs.text: Enjoy cookies right away or wait until the icing sets to serve them. Once the icing has set, these cookies are great for gifting or for sending. Plain or decorated cookies stay soft for about 5 days when covered tightly at room temperature. For longer storage, cover and refrigerate for up to 10 days.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/best-sugar-cookies/

docs.title: The New York Times Chocolate Chip Cookies
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 18 1.02 days

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 30 Tbsp (225 g) cake flour
  • 1.66 cups (199 g) bread flour
  • 1.25 tsp baking soda
  • 1.5 tsp baking powder
  • 1.5 tsp salt
  • :butter; 1.25 cups (283 g) unsalted butter
  • 1.25 cups (266 g) light brown sugar
  • 18 Tbsp (223 g) granulated sugar
  • 2 eggs
  • 2 tsp vanilla
  • 3.33 cups (566 g) 60% cocoa dark chocolate chips
  • some sea salt

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 large bowl
  • 1 rubber spatula
  • 1 baking sheet
  • 1 parchment paper or a nonstick baking mat

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Sift together the cake flour, bread flour, baking soda, baking powder and salt into a large bowl and set aside.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Cream together the unsalted butter, light brown sugar, granulated sugar on medium speed until very light, about 5 minutes. Add the eggs one at a time, mixing well after each addition, then add the vanilla. Reduce the mixer speed to low, gradually add the dry ingredients and mix until just combined, 5 to 10 seconds. Using a rubber spatula, fold in the 60% cocoa dark chocolate chips.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Press plastic wrap against the dough and refrigerate for at least 24 hours, up to 72 hours.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: When ready to bake, preheat oven to 350°F. Line a baking sheet with parchment paper or a nonstick baking mat.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Scoop 3 Tbsp (60 g) of dough, roll into a rough ball (it should be the size of a large golf ball) and place on the baking sheet. Repeat until you have six mounds of dough on the cookie sheet. Sprinkle lightly with sea salt and bake until golden brown but still soft, 18 to 20 minutes. Transfer the parchment or silicone sheet to a wire rack for 10 minutes, then transfer the cookies onto another cooling rack to cool a bit more, until just warm or at room temperature. Repeat with remaining dough (or keep some of the dough refrigerated for up to 3 days, and bake cookies at a later time). Store leftover cookies in an airtight container at room temperature for up to 3 days.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.browneyedbaker.com/the-new-york-times-chocolate-chip-cookies/

docs.title: Traditional Italian Biscotti
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 60 1.42 hours

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 56 g unsalted butter
  • 46 g vegetable shortening
  • 147 g granulated sugar
  • 3 large eggs
  • 1 tsp vanilla
  • 1 Tbsp aniseed
  • 1 tsp lemon extract
  • 1 tsp baking powder
  • 0.75 tsp salt
  • 360 g all-purpose flour
  • 168 g almonds or hazelnuts

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 baking sheets
  • 1 parchment
  • 1 large bowl
  • 1 serrated knife

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Preheat the oven to 375°F.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Lightly grease one or two baking sheets, or line them with parchment.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: In a large bowl, beat together the unsalted butter, vegetable shortening, and granulated sugar, then add the eggs one at a time, beating well after each addition and scraping down the bowl midway through. Beat in the vanilla, aniseed, lemon extract, baking powder, and salt. Mix in the all-purpose flour 1 cup at a time to make a cohesive, well-mixed dough. Add the almonds or hazelnuts, mixing until they're distributed throughout the dough.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Transfer the dough to a lightly floured or lightly greased work surface. Divide it into three fairly equal pieces and shape each piece into a rough 12 inch log. Transfer each log to the prepared baking sheet, leaving about 3 inches between them; you may need to use two baking sheets. Wet your fingers and pat the logs into smooth-topped rectangles 12 inches long x 2.5 inches wide and 7/8 inches thick.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Bake the logs for 20 to 25 minutes, until they're beginning to brown around the edges. Remove them from the oven and let rest for 20 minutes. Lower the oven temperature to 300°F.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Gently transfer the logs to a cutting surface and use a serrated knife to cut them on the diagonal into 1/2 inch wide slices. Because of the nuts and the nature of the dough, the biscotti at this point are prone to crumbling; just be sure to use a slow, gentle sawing motion and accept the fact that some bits and pieces will break off. Carefully transfer the slices, cut sides up, to a parchment-lined or ungreased baking sheet. You can crowd them together, as they won't expand; about 1/4 inch breathing space is all that's required.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Return the biscotti to the oven and bake them for 20 minutes. Remove from the oven, quickly turn them over, and bake for an additional 20 minutes, or until they're very dry and beginning to brown. Remove them from the oven, cool completely, and store in an airtight container.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • The King Arthur Baking Company All-Purpose Baker's Companion

docs.title: Twix
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 15 cookies 65 minutes

docs.title: Caramel
docs.text:
• 125 g sweetened condensed milk
  • 23 g brown sugar
  • 40 g Treacle or golden syrup
  • 45 g unsalted butter
  • 1 pinch salt

docs.title: Cookie
docs.text:
• 240 g all-purpose flour
  • 70 g powdered sugar
  • 180 g unsalted butter
  • 1 egg yolk

docs.title: Chocolate Coating
docs.text:
• 250 g compound milk or semi-sweet chocolate
  • some flaky salt

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 small saucepan
  • 1 large bowl
  • 1 parchment paper
  • 1 cookie cutter
  • 1 wire rack

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Combine sweetened condensed milk, brown sugar, Treacle or golden syrup, unsalted butter, and salt in a small saucepan and bring to a boil.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Simmer over medium heat until the sugar has completely dissolved and the mixture has thickened slightly.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Remove from the heat and place in the fridge to chill completely.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Combine the all-purpose flour and powdered sugar in a large bowl.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Add the chilled unsalted butter and rub it into the dry mixture with your fingers until it forms a sand-like texture.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Add the egg yolk and begin to knead the dough until it forms a shaggy dough.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Transfer the cookie dough to your work surface and continue to knead until it comes together to form a ball.

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text: Place the dough between two sheets of parchment paper and roll it out to 1/4 inch / 6 mm in thickness.

docs.title: Step 9
docs.text: Place the dough into the fridge to chill for a minimum of 1 hour.

docs.title: Step 10
docs.text: Preheat the oven to 170°C/340°F, fan forced, and line an oven tray with parchment paper.

docs.title: Step 11
docs.text: Once chilled remove the baking paper and cut out medium-sized rounds with a cookie cutter.

docs.title: Step 12
docs.text: Place the cookies on the lined tray and bake for 15 minutes, or until lightly golden brown.

docs.title: Step 13
docs.text: Remove and cool completely.

docs.title: Step 14
docs.text: Transfer the caramel to a piping bag fitted with a small round tip.

docs.title: Step 15
docs.text: Pipe a dollop of caramel on top of each cookie, leaving a 1 cm / 1/3 inch border around the edge of the cookie (this gives the caramel some space to spread)

docs.title: Step 16
docs.text: Melt the chocolate over a hot water bath or in the microwave until smooth

docs.title: Step 17
docs.text: Place the cookies on a wire rack and pour the melted compound milk or semi-sweet chocolate over the cookies to coat

docs.title: Step 18
docs.text: Carefully transfer the coated cookies onto an oven tray lined with baking paper and sprinkle with flaky salt

docs.title: Step 19
docs.text: Leave the cookies at room temperature for 30 minutes to set.

docs.title: Step 20
docs.text: Enjoy!

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://zhangcatherine.com/twix-cookies/

docs.title: Vanilla Bean Sables
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 36 3.37 hours

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 67 g granulated sugar
  • 2 vanilla bean
  • 226 g unsalted butter
  • 40 g confectioners’ sugar
  • 0.5 tsp fine sea salt
  • 1 egg yolk
  • 272 g all-purpose flour
  • 1 egg
  • some sanding or granulated sugar

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 stand mixer
  • 1 baking sheet
  • 1 parchment paper

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Put the granulated sugar and vanilla bean pulp in the bowl of a stand mixer or in a large bowl in which you can use a hand mixer. Using your fingertips, rub the vanilla into the sugar until it’s fragrant.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Add the unsalted butter, confectioners’ sugar and fine sea salt to the bowl and, using the paddle attachment, beat on low speed until the mixture is smooth and creamy (you don’t want it to get light and fluffy), scraping down the sides and bottom of the bowl as needed. Drop in the egg yolk and beat for 1 minute. Add the all-purpose flour all at once. Mix on low speed just until the flour has disappeared (or do this last little bit by hand with a flexible spatula).

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Turn the dough out onto a work surface and divide it in half. (You can use a scale to get two equal halves if you wish.) Shape each half into a log about 9 inches long. Wrap the logs in parchment or plastic film and refrigerate for at least 3 hours.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: When you’re ready to bake: Preheat the oven to 325°F. Line a baking sheet with parchment paper or a silicone baking mat. Add a splash of cold water to the yolk (or the reserved egg white) and mix with a fork to blend. Brush each log with this egg wash and roll it in the sanding or granulated sugar until it’s evenly coated. Using a sturdy knife, trim the ends of the logs if they’re ragged, then cut the dough into 1/2 inch thick rounds. Place as many cookies as will fit on the baking sheet, spacing them about 2 inches apart.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Bake cookies for 18 to 22 minutes, rotating the pan halfway. The cookies are baked when they are brown around the edges and golden on the bottom. Let cool briefly on sheet pan, then carefully transfer them to a cooling rack and cool to room temperature. These really shouldn’t be eaten warm; they need time to cool so that their texture will set properly. Repeat the baking with the remaining dough.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://alexandracooks.com/2016/10/26/vanilla-bean-sables/

docs.title: Vanilla Wafers
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 100 wafers 50 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 1 stick (113 g) butter
  • 7 oz (198 g) confectioners' sugar
  • 3 large egg whites
  • 1 large egg
  • 6 oz (170 g) all-purpose flour
  • 2 tsp vanilla
  • 0.25 tsp salt

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 large bowl
  • 1 piping bag
  • 1 medium pastry tip

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Preheat oven to 350°F (150°C). For this recipe, I did fan as there will be multiple trays in the oven and you will want them to bake evenly.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: In a large bowl, cream together the softened butter and confectioners' sugar until light and fluffy and there are no lumps.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Slowly add in the egg whites and mix until smooth. Add the remaining whole egg and mix until fully incorporated. If the mix curdles don't worry, just give it a good whisk to bring it back together.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Once combined, add the all-purpose flour, vanilla, and salt and mix until it just comes together. Do not overmix.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: The batter will be somewhat soft. Place batter in a piping bag fitted with a medium pastry tip. Pipe it in even mounds onto a cookie sheet (roughly 2 teaspoons). Keep cookies about 1.5 inches apart as the batter will spread when baked.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Place in oven and bake for approximately 18 to 20 minutes or until golden.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Once cooled store in an airtight for up to 7 days. Use for a cookie crust or for a classic banana pudding.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.biggerbolderbaking.com/vanilla-wafers-nilla/

docs.title: Weight Watchers Double Oatmeal Cookies
docs.text: Total Time 14 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 1.5 cups all-purpose flour
  • 3 cups quick oats
  • 1 tsp baking soda
  • 0.5 tsp salt
  • 2 tsp cinnamon
  • 1 tsp ginger
  • 0.5 tsp cloves
  • 1 cup unsalted butter
  • 1.5 cups light brown sugar
  • 0.5 cup granulated sugar
  • 2 egg whites
  • 0.25 cup mini chocolate chips

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 large bowl
  • 1 stand mixer

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Preheat oven to 350°F.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Whisk the all-purpose flour, quick oats, baking soda, salt, cinnamon, ginger, and cloves in a large bowl.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Cream room temperature unsalted butter, light brown sugar, and granulated sugar for a few minutes in a stand mixer.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Add the egg whites to the mixer and mix for a few minutes.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Slowly fold in the dry ingredients into the batter.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Fold in the mini chocolate chips.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Chill for 24 hours. Bake for 11 to 14 minutes.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text:
• Weight Watchers
  • Recipe Box

docs.title: White Chocolate Chip Macadamia Nut
docs.text: Total Time 28 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 0.75 cup (170 g) butter
  • 1 cup (213 g) brown sugar
  • 0.5 cup (99 g) granulated sugar
  • 2 eggs
  • 2 tsp vanilla
  • 2.25 cup (270 g) all-purpose flour
  • 1 tsp baking soda
  • 1 tsp salt
  • 1 cup (170 g) white chocolate chips
  • 1 cup (149 g) macadamia nuts

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 parchment paper
  • 1 cookie sheets

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Preheat your oven to 350°F.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Cream together your butter, brown sugar, and granulated sugar until it’s light and fluffy. Add in the eggs and vanilla, mixing thoroughly. Beat in the all-purpose flour, baking soda and salt.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: When that is done, fold in the white chocolate chips and macadamia nuts by hand, and prepare to put them on some parchment paper lined cookie sheets.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Drop by rounded teaspoonful onto the baking sheets OR if you want to make huge cookies, use an ice cream scoop sized cookie scoop and drop them on the sheet, 6 to a sheet, well spaced apart.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Bake for 10 to 12 minutes, until golden brown and slightly underdone for the small cookies. Bake for 15 to 16 minutes for the large, checking to make sure that the edges are baked completely and the middle is almost baked through but not quite. Cool on the sheets completely.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.thekitchenmagpie.com/thick-chewy-white-chocolate-chip-macadamia-nut-cookies/

docs.title: White Chocolate Cranberry Cookies
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 4 dozen 2.40 hours

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 345 g all-purpose flour
  • 1 tsp baking soda
  • 1 tsp salt
  • 230 g unsalted butter
  • 200 g light brown sugar
  • 100 g granulated sugar
  • 2 large eggs
  • 2 tsp vanilla
  • 270 g white chocolate chips
  • 145 g dried cranberries

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 large mixing bowl
  • 1 stand mixer
  • 1 large baking sheets
  • 1 parchment paper

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: In a large mixing bowl, whisk together the all-purpose flour, baking soda, and salt. Set aside.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: In the bowl of a stand mixer fitted with the paddle attachment, or in a large mixing bowl using an electric mixer, mix the unsalted butter, light brown sugar, and granulated sugar together for 1 to 2 minutes or until well combined. Mix in the eggs one at a time, then mix in the vanilla extract.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Slowly add in the dry ingredients and continue mixing until just combined, making sure to scrape down the sides of the bowl as needed. Then mix in the white chocolate chips and dried cranberries until thoroughly combined.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Cover the cookie dough tightly and transfer to the refrigerator to chill for at least 2 hours.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Once the dough is almost chilled, preheat the oven to 350°F (180°C). Line large baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone baking mats and set aside.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Remove the cookie dough from the refrigerator. Using a 3 tablespoon (60 g) cookie scoop, scoop the cookie dough and drop onto the prepared baking sheets. Make sure to leave a little room between each ball of cookie dough as they will spread a little while they bake.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Bake in separate batches at 350°F (180°C) for 12 to 14 minutes or until the edges of the cookies are lightly browned and the top is set. Remove from the oven and cool on the baking sheet for 5 to 10 minutes, then transfer the cookies to a wire rack to cool completely.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.livewellbakeoften.com/soft-and-chewy-white-chocolate-cranberry-cookies/

docs.title: World's Best Brownies
docs.text: Total Time 60 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 245 g dark chocolate
  • 200 g butter
  • 175 g granulated sugar
  • 125 g light brown sugar
  • 4 large eggs
  • 2 tsp vanilla
  • 115 g all-purpose flour
  • 1 pinch salt
  • 100 g dark chocolate chunks (optional)

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 30 x 23cm cake tin
  • 1 baking parchment
  • 1 large heatproof bowl
  • 1 balloon whisk
  • 1 wooden spoon
  • 1 wire rack

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Preheat the oven to 350°F. Grease and line a 30 x 23cm cake tin with baking parchment.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Put the roughly chopped dark chocolate and butter into a large heatproof bowl set over a pan of gently simmering water (don’t let the bottom of the bowl touch the water underneath) and leave until melted, stirring occasionally.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Remove from the heat and cool the chocolate down by whisking in the granulated sugar and light brown sugar using a balloon whisk. Add the eggs and vanilla extract and mix in with a wooden spoon until combined. Sift over the all-purpose flour and salt and stir again until smooth and combined. Pour into the prepared tin, smoothing the top level.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Bake for 35 to 40 minutes, until cracked around the edges and soft in the middle (it will firm up as it cools), rotating the tin halfway through baking.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: If you are adding the dark chocolate chunks (optional), take the brownie out of the oven after 20 minutes and vigorously throw the chunks of chocolate at the half-baked brownie so they break the surface. Return to the oven for the remaining cooking time.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Transfer the brownie to a wire rack and leave it to cool in the tin, then cut into squares before serving. Once cooled, the brownies will keep in an airtight container for up to a week. Alternatively, cool the cooked brownie in the tin for 10 minutes, then cut into squares and serve warm with a dollop of thick cream.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.gordonramsayrestaurants.com/recipes/worlds-best-brownies/

docs.title: World Piece Cookies
docs.text: Total Time 3.25 hours

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 170 g all-purpose flour
  • 28 g unsweetened cocoa powder
  • 0.5 tsp baking soda
  • 155 g unsalted butter
  • 50 g granulated sugar
  • 134 g light brown sugar
  • 0.25 tsp salt
  • 1 tsp vanilla
  • 142 g bittersweet chocolate pieces

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 stand mixer
  • 1 baking sheets
  • 1 parchment paper or silicone baking mats
  • 1 sharp knife

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Sift the all-purpose flour, unsweetened cocoa powder and baking soda together.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Working with a stand mixer fitted with the paddle attachment, or in a large bowl with a hand mixer, beat the unsalted butter, granulated sugar and light brown sugar together on medium speed until soft, creamy and homogeneous, about 3 minutes. Beat in the salt and vanilla. Turn off the mixer, add all the dry ingredients and pulse a few times to start the blending. When the risk of flying flour has passed, turn the mixer to low and beat until the dough forms big, moist curds. Toss in the bittersweet chocolate pieces and mix to incorporate. This is an unpredictable dough (see above). Sometimes it’s crumbly and sometimes it comes together and cleans the sides of the bowl. Happily, no matter what, the cookies are always great.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Turn the dough out onto a work surface and gather it together, kneading it if necessary to bring it together. Divide the dough in half. Shape the dough into logs that are 1.5 inches in diameter. Don’t worry about the length — get the diameter right, and the length will follow. (If you get a hollow in the logs, just start over.) Wrap the logs in plastic wrap and freeze them for at least 2 hours or refrigerate them for at least 3 hours.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: When you’re ready to bake: Center a rack in the oven and preheat it to 325°F. Line two baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone baking mats.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Working with one log at a time and using a long, sharp knife, slice the dough into 1/2 inch thick rounds. (The rounds might crack as you’re cutting them - don’t be concerned, just squeeze the bits back onto each cookie.) Arrange the rounds on the baking sheets, leaving about 2 inches between them. (If you’ve cut both logs, keep one baking sheet in the fridge while you bake the other.)

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Bake the cookies for 12 minutes - don’t open the oven, just let them bake. When the timer rings, they won’t look done, nor will they be firm, and that’s just the way they should be. Transfer the baking sheet to a cooling rack and let the cookies rest until they are only just warm, at which point you can munch them, or let them reach room temperature (I think the texture’s more interesting at room temperature).

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Bake the remaining dough.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text:
• https://doriegreenspan.com/recipe/world-peace-cookies-the-newest-version-from-dories-cookies-sneak-peek/
  • https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CXAGViXspMk

docs.title: Crème Bavaroise
docs.text: Total Time 30 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients - Crème Anglaise
docs.text:
• 4 egg yolks
  • 125 g granulated sugar
  • 500 ml whole milk
  • 1 vanilla bean

docs.title: Ingredients - Crème Bavaroise
docs.text:
• 10 g agar agar
  • 4 Tbsp unsweetened cocoa powder (optional)
  • 400 ml heavy cream

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 saucepan
  • 1 bowl
  • 1 sieve

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Put stand mixer bowl, heavy cream, and whisk into freezer.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Boil the agar agar in water for 5 minutes.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Make a crème anglaise with 4 egg yolks, 125 g granulated sugar, 500 ml whole milk and 1 vanilla bean.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text:
Dissolve the agar agar into the creme anglaise.

Optional

Chocolate crème bavaroise may be made by adding 2 to 4 Tbsp of unsweetened cocoa powder to the warm custard with agar agar.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: The custard may be cooled by pouring it into a bowl in a tray of ice cubes. The custard may also be cooled in the fridge until it reaches 20°C (68°F)

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Create a creamy whipped cream by creaming 400 ml of heavy cream.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Add the same amount of cream as custard in weight and whisk together.

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text: As soon as it's done, immediately pour into a mold or into a cocktail glass and chill. Serve with fruit as a garnish.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=q8uS3VI86-w

docs.title: Crème Brûlée
docs.text: Total Time 3.92 hours

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 250 ml whole fat milk
  • 250 ml heavy whipping cream
  • 1 vanilla bean
  • 4 egg yolks
  • 91 g granulated sugar
  • 53 g brown sugar

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 medium saucepan
  • 1 medium-sized mixing bowl
  • 1 wire mesh sieve
  • 1 ramekins
  • 1 baking tray
  • 1 parchment paper or aluminum foil

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Preheat the oven to 100℃ (210℉) and use a thermometer to verify the oven temperature – this is the key to a good creme brûlée.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Add the whole fat milk (1 C/250 ml) and heavy whipping cream (1 C/250 ml) into a medium saucepan on low heat.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Add pure vanilla extract (1 tablespoon) or 1 vanilla bean. If you are using a vanilla bean, be sure to split the bean down the middle, scrape the seeds from inside and add everything (bean and seeds) to the milk/heavy whipping cream.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Bring the milk/cream/vanilla mixture to a boil while stirring well, and then immediately turn off the heat. Set the saucepan aside to cool for 10 to 15 minutes.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Double-check to verify oven temperature is 100℃ (210℉).

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Separate the four egg yolks and add them to a medium-sized mixing bowl along with the granulated sugar (1/3 cup plus 2 Tbsp). Mix together the egg yolks and sugar gently with a wooden spoon. Do not use a whisk. We do not want foaming. When all of the sugar is incorporated with the yolks you will get a "slight yellow color" to the yolks.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: When the milk/cream/vanilla mixture has cooled to “lukewarm,” place a wire mesh sieve over the yolk/sugar mixing bowl. Gently mix everything together with a wooden spoon until the sugar has completely dissolved. (There is no heat involved here.)

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text: When the sugar has dissolved, pour in the remaining mixture through the sieve and mix gently, but thoroughly. You do not want to create "foaming."

docs.title: Step 9
docs.text: Now, carefully sieve/pour the crème mixture again into a measuring cup for easy pouring into your ramekins.

docs.title: Step 10
docs.text: Place your ramekins on a sturdy baking tray lined with parchment paper or aluminum foil. Pour equal amounts of crème through the fine wire mesh sieve and into each ramekin. Using the sieve is especially important if you’re using vanilla beans (isolates the black seeds).

docs.title: Step 11
docs.text: Cook the crèmes for 45 to 60 minutes on the sturdy baking tray in the oven on the lower rack at 100℃ (210℉) (There's no water bath.). If you are using large ramekins (bigger than 4 inches/10 cm), your cook time can be up to an hour. The crèmes are cooked when they are firm on the outer edge and just slightly wobbly in the center.

docs.title: Step 12
docs.text: Tap Test: gently tap the side of the ramekins with your finger to see if the center of the creme wobbles. If there’s only a slight wobble, it’s done. When the crèmes pass the tap test, remove the tray from the oven and allow the ramekins to cool to room temperature. After 30 to 40 minutes, move them into the refrigerator for at least 2 hours to set (overnight is best).

docs.title: Step 13
docs.text: When the custard is ready and just before serving, take the crème brûlées out of the refrigerator and sprinkle a layer of brown sugar on top of the custard, as evenly as possible. Each 4 ounce ramekin will need between 1 teaspoon and 1 tablespoon of brown sugar (depending on the size of the ramekins and your own taste).

docs.title: Step 14
docs.text: There are three different tools used to caramelize the sugar and create the crunchy sweet caramel crust on top of the crème brûlée:

docs.title: Step 15
docs.text: Culinary Blowtorch (available at kitchen supply and hardware stores – torch the brown sugar until melted, bubbling and brown. * Be sure to follow the manufacturer’s safety instructions on the blowtorch.)

docs.title: Step 16
docs.text: The Broiler (in your oven on High with tray on the top rack. Watch carefully because brown sugar can go from underdone to black burnt in seconds)

docs.title: Step 17
docs.text: Flambé Method (a little brandy or rum poured on top of the brown sugar and lit with a flame then blown out when melted, bubbling and brown.)

docs.title: Step 18
docs.text: The ideal result is to caramelize the top of the crème brûlée without heating up the custard filling below. In any case, make sure you do not burn the brown sugar/crème.

docs.title: Step 19
docs.text: After caramelizing the brown sugar, the crème brûlée is ready to serve.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.thefrenchcookingacademy.com/recipes/creme-brulee

docs.title: Crème Chiboust
docs.text: Total Time 30 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• some crème pâtissière
  • some italian meringue
  • 7 g Gelatin (optional)

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text: • 1 bowl

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Combine equal amounts of crème pâtissière and italian meringue by folding one third of the hot meringue into the warm pastry cream and then the rest of the meringue.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text:
Gelatin may be added to the custard to thicken it.

Note

Please remember that the Crème Chiboust is very delicate and can become "dangerous" since the pastry cream is left at room temperature for some time, during which bacteria could form in it.

Note

To avoid risks while you prepare the meringue, you can cover the bowl with plastic film on the pastry cream and additionally you could also place temporarily the bowl on a bain-marie: this will keep the cream at safe temperatures and prevent the formation of bacteria.

Note

If the cream needs to be baked (e.g. to fill tarts), you can omit the gelatin.

Note

It might be necessary to let the cream set a few minutes in the fridge before it can used in a piping bag.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.roadtopastry.com/blog/recipes/creams-custards-sauces/recipe-creme-chiboust-chiboust-cream

docs.title: Crème Diplomat
docs.text: Total Time 10 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 10 g confectioners' sugar (optional)
  • 800 g heavy cream
  • 810 g crème pâtissière

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Add confectioners' sugar (optional) to heavy cream with a 1 to 80 ratio by weight.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Create a whipped cream using equal weight whipped cream to crème pâtissière ratio.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Fold the whipped cream into the crème pâtissière.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • Cupcake Jemma

docs.title: Crème Pâtissière
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 8 inch tart 45 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 533 g whole milk
  • 128 g granulated sugar
  • 9 egg yolks
  • 48 g cornstarch
  • 0.5 tsp salt
  • 108 g unsalted butter
  • 1 vanilla pod (optional)

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 large pot
  • 1 bowl
  • 1 whisk
  • 1 plastic wrap

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: In a large pot over medium heat, bring the whole milk and half of the granulated sugar to a boil, slowly stirring to prevent the mixture from burning on the bottom of the pot. If you’re using the vanilla bean (optional), add the seeds as well as the pod. Remove the milk mixture from the heat. Remove the vanilla bean.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text:
In a bowl, whisk together the other half of the sugar with the egg yolks. (Do this immediately to prevent the yolks from “burning” on contact with the sugar.) Stir in the cornstarch and salt until smooth then slowly whisk in 1/2 cup of the warm milk and sugar mixture, stirring until evenly combined.

Tip

This process is called tempering, a cooking technique in which you gradually raise the temperature of a cold or room-temperature ingredient (in this case, eggs) by adding small amounts of a hot liquid, to prevent the cold ingredient from cooking too quickly or too much. If you add all of the hot liquid into the eggs at once, you’re going to end up with lumpy scrambled eggs in your pastry cream.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text:
While stirring, pour the egg mixture back into the pot of milk. On low to medium heat, while stirring constantly, heat the mixture up until it noticeably thickens. It takes about 3 minutes or so to thicken and a further 2 minutes more, once thickened, to cook out the raw taste from the cornstarch. It will continue to thicken as it cools, so remove it from the heat before you evaporate off too much water.

Tip

Look for the foam on the top of the custard to start disappearing. This is a sign that the custard is almost finished cooking.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text:
Remove from heat and allow the custard to cool to room temperature, whisking occasionally. Add in the cubed unsalted butter and whisk until evenly combined. A good pastry cream is rich and smooth, with a pale yellow color and a glossy, velvety texture.

Tip

Strain through a fine mesh sieve to help remove any lumps.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Cover with plastic wrap directly pressed onto the surface and let cool in the fridge.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • Dominique Ansel

docs.title: 4 Ingredient Chocolate Mousse
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 4 5 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 2 boxes silken tofu
  • 4 Tbsp cacao powder
  • 1 cup date paste
  • 1 tsp vanilla

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text: • 1 blender

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Blend two 12.3 oz boxes of silken tofu, cacao powder, date paste and vanilla in a blender until well blended.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Chill before serving, and it will get even thicker.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://nutritionstudies.org/recipes/dessert/4-ingredient-chocolate-mousse/

docs.title: Banana Pudding
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 8 6 hours

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 2 cup milk
  • 0.5 cup sugar
  • 2 Tbsp butter
  • 1 pinch salt
  • 1 vanilla bean
  • 3 Tbsp cornstarch
  • 1 large egg
  • 3 large egg yolks
  • 1 box (80 wafers) vanilla wafers
  • 1.5 cups heavy whipping cream
  • 4 banana

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 medium saucepan
  • 1 small bowl
  • 1 shallow container
  • 1 strainer
  • 1 rubber spatula
  • 1 plastic wrap
  • 8 jars

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: In a medium saucepan, bring the milk, 1/4 cup of the sugar, butter, salt, and vanilla bean, split lengthwise, to a gentle boil. Remove from the heat.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: In a small bowl, whisk together the cornstarch and the remaining 1/4 cup of sugar. Add the egg and egg yolks to the cornstarch and mix into a smooth paste.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Slowly, and in small amounts, whisk a little of the hot milk mixture into the egg mixture. This is called tempering the eggs, which you need to do to get them to the same temperature of the hot milk in the pan, so they won’t curdle.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Once the egg mixture is warm to the touch, pour it back into the milk in the pan. Return the custard to the stove and bring to a boil, whisking continuously, and continue to whisk and cook until smooth and glossy, 2 to 3 minutes. The pastry cream will thicken almost immediately but it is important to cook out the starch so that it isn’t grainy and so your pastry cream won’t separate.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Strain the pastry cream into a shallow container and discard the vanilla bean. Because the pastry cream is so thick, you will need to press it through the strainer with a rubber spatula. Cover with plastic wrap pressed directly on the surface of the cream to prevent a skin from forming. Set the container in an ice bath or in the freezer for 15 minutes (this cools down the eggs quickly) and then refrigerate for up to a few days.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Place a layer of the vanilla wafers in the bottom of each jar (so you can see the layers).

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Make whipped creaming using heavy whipping cream whipped to stiff peaks.

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text: Set aside some whipped cream and banana slices for the top of the puddings, then fold the remaining whipped cream into the pastry cream. Spoon in one-third of the lightened pastry cream over the cookies. Top with half of the banana slices. Add a layer of wafers and repeat with another one-third of pastry cream, remaining bananas, and another layer of wafers (you may not need to use the whole box).

docs.title: Step 9
docs.text: Finish with the remaining pastry cream. Cover and refrigerate for about 5 hours.

docs.title: Step 10
docs.text: When ready to serve, top with the reserved whipped cream and bananas.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://magnolia.com/blog/recipe/d2aa51dc-e630-48f4-8581-2d1d39ddb254/banana-pudding/

docs.title: Brandy Snaps
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 36 7 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients - Cookies
docs.text:
• 0.33 cup dark corn syrup
  • 0.25 lb unsalted butter, cut into pieces
  • 0.5 cup granulated sugar
  • 0.5 cup all-purpose flour

docs.title: Ingredients - Whipped Cream
docs.text:
• 1 cup heavy cream
  • 0.25 cup confectioners' sugar
  • 1 Tbsp brandy
  • 0.125 tsp salt
  • 0.5 tsp vanilla

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 baking sheets
  • 1 electric mixer

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Put dark corn syrup, unsalted butter, cut into pieces and granulated sugar into heavy-bottomed pan. Heat mixture over low heat, stirring, until butter has melted and mixture is smooth. Don’t let mixture boil. Remove from heat and vigorously stir in all-purpose flour, beating until smooth. (Rotary beater will do this easily.)

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Drop batter by 1/2 teaspoons on greased baking sheets. Try doing only 5 cookies at a time, until you see how much they spread. Bake at 350°F until cookies turn nice medium caramel color, about 5 to 7 minutes. Cookies should spread into about 2.5 inch rounds, or little larger, and bubble.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Remove from oven and cool until cookies are firm enough to lift off baking sheet with spatula. Roll with fingers or around clean broom handle into tubes about 3/4 inch around.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: If cookies get too firm to manage, return to oven 1 to 2 minutes to soften. If batter in pan gets too stiff to use, heat, stirring, until melted enough to drop from teaspoon.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: To make the brandy whipped cream, add the heavy cream, salt, vanilla, and confectioners' sugar to the bowl of an electric mixer fitted with a whisk attachment and whip until it forms soft peaks. Add the brandy and mix in.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Pipe the brandy whipped cream into the rolled cookies.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text:
• https://www.latimes.com/archives/la-xpm-1996-01-11-fo-23229-story.html
  • https://www.thekitchn.com/marion-cunninghams-brandy-snaps-recipe-review-from-the-kitchn-181552
  • https://www.foodnetwork.com/recipes/ree-drummond/brandy-whipped-cream-2258854

docs.title: Bread Pudding
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 8 1.50 hours

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 75 g raisins
  • some water or rum
  • 45 g unsalted butter
  • 2 large eggs
  • 1 egg yolk
  • 100 g granulated sugar
  • 375 g milk
  • 250 g whipping cream
  • 1 tsp vanilla
  • 0.25 tsp nutmeg
  • 1 pinch salt
  • 4 cups bread
  • some cinnamon sugar

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 6 to 8 cups (1.5 - 2 L) baking dish
  • 1 separate bowl
  • 1 potato masher or slotted spoon

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Soak the raisins in water or rum.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Preheat the oven to 350°F (180°C). Brush a 6 to 8 cups (1.5 - 2 L) baking dish with melted unsalted butter, and pour 3 Tbsp (45 g) over the day-old bread and toss in a large bowl.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: In a separate bowl, whisk the eggs, egg yolk and granulated sugar and then whisk in the milk, whipping cream, vanilla, nutmeg and salt. Pour this over the day old bread, toss to coat, and let sit for about 15 minutes, stirring once or twice. It may look like a lot of liquid, but it all balances out.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: After sitting for the required time, use a potato masher or slotted spoon to break down the bread pieces a bit.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Drain the soaking raisins and stir them into the pudding mixture. Pour this into the buttered baking dish and sprinkle with cinnamon sugar. Bake, uncovered, for about 60 minutes, until the pudding soufflés a little and the top turn a golden brown.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Allow the pudding to cool for at least 15 minutes before serving.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: The bread pudding can be served warm or chilled.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gbhlieL2i4E

docs.title: Buckeyes
docs.text: Total Time 4.00 hours

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 1 cup creamy peanut butter
  • 4 Tbsp butter
  • 0.5 tsp salt
  • 2 cups confectioners' sugar
  • 2 cups semisweet chocolate
  • 2 Tbsp coconut oil or vegetable shortening

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 large bowl
  • 1 electric mixer
  • 1 parchment-lined baking sheet
  • 1 small heatproof bowl
  • 1 toothpick

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: In a large bowl, using an electric mixer on high speed, cream creamy peanut butter, butter, and salt until smooth. Reduce mixer speed to low and blend in confectioners' sugar until batter is smooth and homogeneous.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Using a tablespoon measuring spoon, scoop batter and roll into balls about 1" in diameter. Arrange on a parchment-lined baking sheet and refrigerate until firm, 1 to 2 hours.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: In a small heatproof bowl, microwave semisweet chocolate and coconut oil or vegetable shortening in 20 second intervals, stirring between each, until melted and smooth.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Using a toothpick, dip chilled peanut butter balls into melted chocolate, leaving a small circle uncovered at the top. Return to parchment-lined sheet, remove toothpick, and smooth over hole.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text:
Refrigerate buckeyes until firm, 1 to 2 hours more.

Make Ahead

Undipped buckeyes can be made 1 day ahead. Transfer to an airtight container and refrigerate. Dipped buckeyes can be made up to 1 month ahead. Freeze individually on baking sheet until firm, then transfer to an airtight container and keep frozen.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.delish.com/cooking/recipe-ideas/a41020334/buckeyes-recipe/

docs.title: Buttermilk Panna Cotta
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 6 4.17 hours

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 2 Tbsp water
  • 1.5 tsp unflavored gelatin
  • 1 cup whipping cream
  • 1 tsp lemon peel
  • 0.5 cup granulated sugar
  • 2 cups buttermilk
  • 2 tsp vanilla
  • some berry compote (optional)

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 small bowl
  • 1 3/4 cup ramekins or custard cups
  • 1 nonstick spray
  • 1 medium saucepan

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Pour 2 tablespoons water into small bowl; sprinkle unflavored gelatin over. Let stand until gelatin softens, about 10 minutes. Lightly spray six 3/4 cup ramekins or custard cups with nonstick spray.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Heat whipping cream, lemon peel, and granulated sugar in medium saucepan over medium-high heat, stirring constantly until sugar dissolves. Increase heat and bring just to low boil, stirring occasionally. Add gelatin mixture; remove from heat. Stir until gelatin dissolves. Cool mixture to lukewarm, stirring often. Stir in buttermilk and vanilla; divide mixture among prepared ramekins. Refrigerate panna cotta until set, about 4 hours.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: DO AHEAD: Can be made 2 days ahead. Cover and keep chilled.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Using small sharp knife, cut around panna cotta in each ramekin. Place plate atop each ramekin and invert, allowing panna cotta to settle onto plate. Top with berry compote (optional) and serve chilled.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/buttermilk-panna-cotta-240370

docs.title: Cannoli
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 18 1.07 hours

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 2 cups all-purpose flour
  • 2 Tbsp sugar
  • 0.25 tsp salt
  • 3 Tbsp butter
  • 1 large whole egg
  • 1 egg yolk
  • 0.5 cup marsala wine
  • 16 oz ricotta
  • 0.5 cup confectioners' sugar
  • 1 tsp vanilla

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 food processor
  • 1 lightly oiled bowl
  • 1 large pot or Dutch oven
  • 1 4 inch cookie cutter
  • 1 large bowl
  • 1 hand mixer

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Add the all-purpose flour, sugar, and salt to the food processor and pulse until just combined. Then add in the cold butter and pulse until you have small crumbles. You can also make the dough by hand the same way you would make pie crust.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Add the whole egg, egg yolk, and marsala wine and pulse until the dough comes together into a shaggy ball.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Turn the dough out onto a clean surface and knead for 2 to 4 minutes until you have a smooth ball. Place the dough in a lightly oiled bowl, cover, and rest for 1 hour.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: While the dough is resting, add about 2 inches of vegetable oil to a large pot or Dutch oven over medium heat until it reaches 350°F.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Roll out the dough as thin as possible (1/8th to 1/16th inch thick) and use a 4 inch cookie cutter to cut into rounds. For mini cannoli use a 2 inch cookie cutter.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Lightly brush the cannoli forms with vegetable oil and then wrap the cannoli dough around each form. Brush the edge where the ends meet with egg white and press gently to seal.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Fry the shells at 350°F for about 1 minute on each side until golden brown and crispy. Only fry 4-5 at a time so as not to crowd the pan.

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text: Use tongs to transfer the cannoli to a paper towel to drain. Immediately remove the form from the cannoli (you can use the tongs and a paper towel to gently wiggle it off the form, just be careful!).

docs.title: Step 9
docs.text: Let the forms cool fully and repeat the process with the remaining dough circles. Let the cannoli shells cool fully before filling.

docs.title: Step 10
docs.text: While the cannoli are cooling, make the filling.

docs.title: Step 11
docs.text: Add the strained ricotta, confectioners' sugar, and vanilla to a large bowl. Using a hand mixer, whip the ricotta until it's fully combined and smooth. If desired, fold in chopped nuts or chocolate chips!

docs.title: Step 12
docs.text: When ready to use transfer to a piping bag, snip the tip off and fill the shells. Then press on desired toppings!

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.barleyandsage.com/homemade-cannoli/

docs.title: Chia Pudding
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 6 20 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 2 cups sweetened coconut milk
  • 6 Tbsp unsweetened coconut milk
  • 1 Tbsp agave nectar
  • 0.5 tsp vanilla extract
  • 0.25 tsp cinnamon
  • 1 pinch salt
  • 0.25 cup chia seeds
  • 0.5 cup strawberries (optional)
  • some toasted coconut (optional)
  • some boba pearls (optional)

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text: • 1 bowl

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Whisk together sweetened and sweetened coconut milk, unsweetened coconut milk, agave nectar, vanilla extract, cinnamon, and salt in a bowl; stir in chia seeds. Allow mixture to soak until thickened, at least 20 minutes, or cover the bowl with plastic wrap and refrigerate overnight.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text:
Stir pudding and top with strawberries (optional), toasted coconut (optional), and boba pearls (optional).

Tip

You can substitute stevia or sugar for agave.

Tip

You can substitute milk, soy milk, or almond milk for coconut milk. However, this will change the flavor.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text:
• https://www.allrecipes.com/recipe/237469/chia-coconut-pudding-with-coconut-milk/
  • Applied Kitchen

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 1 pkg chocolate pizzelle cookies
  • 1 container fudge ripple ice cream
  • some peanuts
  • some chocolate

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Microwave the chocolate pizzelle cookies, one at a time, for 45 seconds until pliable. Let them cool in a taco holder (or just hold them with your hands for 30 seconds until they set).

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Fill your shells with fudge ripple ice cream. I found a piping bag to be easiest here.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Roll your tacos in chopped peanuts.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Dip the top of your taco in melted chocolate. Freeze until set.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.americastestkitchen.com/articles/5983-how-to-make-a-diy-choco-taco

docs.title: Chocolate Mousse
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 6 4.47 hours

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 142 g semisweet chocolate
  • 568 g heavy cream
  • 5 egg yolks
  • 0.25 cup (28 g) confectioners' sugar
  • 57 g Kahlua
  • 57 g Grand Marnier or orange liquor
  • 1 orange zest
  • 5 egg whites
  • 0.25 cup (28 g) confectioners' sugar

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 double boiler
  • 1 stainless steel bowl
  • 1 spatula
  • 1 pastry bag or a spoon

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Cool down mixer bowl and paddle in the refrigerator.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Melt semisweet chocolate over a double boiler or in the microwave oven and cool slightly.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Whip heavy cream to medium stiff peaks and reserve in refrigerator.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: In a stainless steel bowl, place the egg yolks, ¼ cup confectioners' sugar, Kahlua, Grand Marnier or orange liquor and whisk together until well blended. Place bowl over a double boiler with simmering water and whip until light and thick about 7 to 8 minutes (the consistency of a soft whipped cream, the eggs should double or triple in volume). Add the orange zest. Pour melted chocolate into whipped yolks and the mixture cool for about 15 to 20 minutes.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Using a spatula and very gently add in the about ¾ of the whipped cream. The remaining whipped cream can be used for the topping of each glass.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: In another bowl place egg whites whip until soft peak then add the confectioners' sugar and whip until a meringue medium soft peak. Again very carefully, fold in the egg whites to the chocolate and cream mixture.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Using a pastry bag or a spoon, fill glasses and let set in refrigerator for a 2 to 4 hours.

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text: Top the dessert with freshly whipped cream. Sprinkle with shaved chocolate!!!

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://chefjeanpierre.com/recipes/dessert/chocolate-mousse/

docs.title: Chocolate Soufflé
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 3 to 4 40 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 6 oz (170 g) semisweet or bittersweet chocolate
  • 6 Tbsp (85 g) unsalted butter
  • 2 Tbsp rum, coffee, or water
  • 3 large egg yolks
  • 4 large egg whites
  • 0.25 tsp cream of tartar
  • 0.25 cups (50 g) sugar
  • some confectioners' sugar

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 7-inch or 1/2-quart soufflé mold
  • 1 skillet
  • 1 large rubber spatula

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Unlike most chocolate soufflés, this is made without milk or starch. It is light yet moist, with an exceptional chocolate taste.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Position a rack in the lower third of the oven. Preheat the oven to 375°F. Prepare a 7-inch or 1/2-quart soufflé mold.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Combine in a heatproof bowl chopped semisweet or bittersweet chocolate unsalted butter and rum, coffee, or water.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Set the bowl in a skillet of hot, but not simmering, water and stir until the mixture is smooth. Let cool for 10 minutes, then whisk in egg yolks.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Beat in a large bowl on medium speed until foamy 4 large egg whites, at room temperature

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Add and beat on high speed until soft peaks form 1/4 teaspoon cream of tartar

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Gradually beat in 1/4 cup sugar.

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text: Beat until the peaks are stiff but not dry. Using a large rubber spatula, stir one-third of the egg whites into the chocolate mixture, then fold in the remaining whites. Pour the batter into the prepared soufflé mold, tap the mold to remove air bubbles, and smooth the top. Run a finger around the lip to remove a little bit of the batter. (The soufflé can be set aside at room temperature, covered with an inverted bowl, for up to 1 hour; or cover with plastic wrap and refrigerate for up to 24 hours before baking.)

docs.title: Step 9
docs.text: Bake until the soufflé is risen and set, 25 to 30 minutes. Dust with confectioners' sugar. Serve at once.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • Joy of Cooking

docs.title: Chocolate Whoopie Pies with Vanilla Buttercream Filling
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 16 15 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients - Cookies
docs.text:
• 1.75 cup all-purpose flour
  • 0.5 tsp salt
  • 0.75 cup unsweetened cocoa powder
  • 1.5 tsp baking soda
  • 0.5 tsp baking powder
  • 0.5 cup butter
  • 1 cup sugar
  • 1 large egg
  • 1 cup buttermilk
  • 1 tsp vanilla

docs.title: Ingredients - Filling
docs.text:
• 0.5 cup butter
  • 4 cup confectioners' sugar
  • 0.25 cup milk
  • 0.5 tsp vanilla

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 baking pans
  • 1 parchment paper
  • 1 electric mixer
  • 1 1-ounce ice cream scoop
  • 1 disposable pastry bag

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Preheat oven to 400°F. Sift together all-purpose flour, salt, unsweetened cocoa powder, baking soda, and baking powder. Set aside. Line 2 baking pans with parchment paper. In the bowl of an electric mixer fitted with the paddle attachment, cream butter and sugar until light and fluffy. Add egg, buttermilk, and vanilla. Beat until well combined. Slowly add dry ingredients. Mix until combined.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Using a 1-ounce ice cream scoop, place dough onto a parchment-lined baking pan, 12 per pan. Bake for 10 to 12 minutes. Remove to a rack to cool. Repeat with remaining batter.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: In the bowl of an electric mixer fitted with the paddle attachment, cream butter until smooth and creamy, 2 to 3 minutes. With mixer on low speed, add 3 cups confectioners' sugar, milk, and vanilla; mix until light and fluffy. If necessary, gradually add remaining cup sugar to reach desired consistency.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Transfer buttercream to a disposable pastry bag and snip the end. When cookies have cooled completely, pipe 2 tablespoons buttercream onto the flat side of half the cookies. Sandwich with remaining cookies, pressing down slightly so that the filling spreads to the edge of the cookies.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.marthastewart.com/1164907/chocolate-whoopie-pies-vanilla-buttercream-filling

docs.title: Classic Crème Brûlée
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 2 1.33 hours

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 0.75 cup heavy cream
  • 0.25 tsp vanilla
  • 2 egg yolks
  • 1 Tbsp white sugar
  • 1 Tbsp raw cane sugar

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 bowl
  • 1 crème brûlée molds

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Preheat the oven to 200°F.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Bring the heavy cream and vanilla to a simmer on the stovetop.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: In a bowl, whisk the egg yolks with the white sugar until pale in color (about 1 minute).

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Slowly pour the hot cream over the egg mixture while continuously stirring.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Pour the custard into crème brûlée molds and bake for 50 minutes, until the egg mixture is no longer liquid.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Cool the crème brûlée down in the refrigerator for 30 minutes.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Pour the raw cane sugar over the custard and caramelize with a torch.

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text: Serve immediately.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.tastingtable.com/874689/classic-creme-brulee-recipe/

docs.title: Classic Fudge
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 117 pieces 3.08 hours

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 3 cups granulated sugar
  • 0.75 cup butter
  • 0.67 cup evaporated milk
  • 1 tsp instant espresso powder
  • 1 7-oz jar marshmallow creme
  • 1 tsp vanilla
  • 1 cup nuts (optional)
  • some sprinkles (optional)

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 saucepan
  • 1 13 X 9 inch pan
  • 1 parchment paper

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Combine the granulated sugar, butter, evaporated milk, and instant espresso powder in a saucepan and bring to a boil over medium heat, stirring occasionally.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Allow the mixture to boil for exactly 5 minutes.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Remove the mixture from the heat and stir in the chocolate chips until they have melted.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Stir the marshmallow creme and vanilla extract into the chocolate mixture. If using, fold in chopped nuts (optional).

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Grease a 13 X 9 inch pan with cooking spray or line with wax or parchment paper.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Pour the mixture into the prepared pan and spread it evenly. Top with sprinkles (optional) if desired.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Allow the fudge to cool and set completely (at least 3 hours) before cutting it into 1 inch squares.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.tastingtable.com/912358/classic-fudge-recipe/

docs.title: Coconut Macaroons
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 24 25 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 1 14-oz can sweetened condensed milk
  • 1 14-oz bag sweetened coconut
  • 1 tsp vanilla
  • 2 egg whites
  • 0.5 tsp salt

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Preheat oven to 325°F.

docs.title: Step 2
