docs.text: • Tante Myrna Seccia

docs.title: Almond Cotija
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 2 cups 10 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 1.5 cups blanched almonds
  • 0.25 tsp dulse flakes or granules
  • 2 Tbsp lemon juice
  • 1 tsp salt

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 large, dry nonstick or cast-iron pan
  • 1 food processor

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Place the blanched almonds in a large, dry nonstick or cast-iron pan.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Place the pan over medium-low heat and toast, shaking the pan frequently, until the almonds are just fragrant, 8 to 10 minutes.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Transfer the almonds to a plate to cool completely.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: In a food processor, add the cooled toasted almonds and the dulse flakes or granules and process until finely ground.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Add the lemon juice and salt and process briefly to combine.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Taste and adjust the seasoning.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Store in an airtight jar for up to 1 week.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • The Gracias Madre Cookbook

docs.title: Almond Flour
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 1 lb 15 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text: • 1 lb blanched almonds

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 cookie sheet
  • 1 food processor

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Preheat the oven to 350ºF.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: When the blanched almonds have all been forcibly removed from their jackets, spread them out on a cookie sheet and roast in the oven until they are quite dry. This will take between 10 and 15 minutes. Watch closely to make sure they don’t brown too much, although, depending on the recipe you’re intending to use them for, a darker, more roasted taste may be desirable. If you have time to let them sit, turn off the oven and let them sit there all night to dry out even more.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: When the almonds are toasted and quite dry, blend them in a food processor. Do not overfill the food processor; it’s good to only fill the bowl about half full. Grind in short, quick bursts until the meal is a fine texture. Depending on your food processor and how dry the almonds are, this may not get to the finest flour consistency. If it begins to clump together or turn to butter, it has been over-ground.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.thekitchn.com/recipe-diy-almo-14350

docs.title: Almond Paste
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 375 g 5 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 168 g almond flour
  • 170 g confectioners' sugar
  • 1 large egg white
  • 0.25 tsp salt
  • 1.5 tsp almond extract

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 food processor
  • 1 plastic wrap

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Combine the almond flour and confectioners' sugar in the work bowl of a food processor or in the bowl of a stand mixer. Process or mix to blend briefly, just to combine.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Add the egg white, salt, and 1 to 1.5 tsp of almond extract, processing or mixing until the mixture comes together and forms a malleable ball.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Remove the almond paste from the processor or mixer, scraping any residue from the sides of the bowl.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Shape the paste into a log or round. Double wrap it in plastic wrap and refrigerate until ready to use.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Store almond paste, tightly wrapped, for up to 1 month in the refrigerator, or up to 3 months in the freezer.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.kingarthurbaking.com/recipes/diy-almond-paste-recipe

docs.title: Apple Butter
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 1 cup 45 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 24 oz unsweetened applesauce
  • 5.5 lbs sweet apples (alternative)
  • 0.5 tsp cinnamon
  • 0.25 tsp nutmeg
  • 0.25 tsp allspice
  • 0.25 tsp cardamom
  • 0.25 tsp cloves
  • 0.25 tsp ginger
  • 0.25 tsp mace (optional)
  • some white or brown sugar, maple sugar, maple syrup, honey, or other sweetener (optional)

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 bottomed saucepan
  • 1 slow cooker (alternative)
  • 1 splatter guard
  • 1 blender

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Put the unsweetened applesauce and cinnamon, nutmeg, allspice, cardamom, cloves, ginger, and mace (optional) into a heavy bottomed saucepan. You want a heavy pot because that will help prevent the thick apple butter from scorching on the bottom of the pan as it cooks. Stir to combine everything and bring up to a boil.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text:
Cook at a medium boil, stirring often, for about 30 to 45 minutes, until the butter is nice and thick. Be careful, the mixture will sputter in the beginning,

Note

I use a splatter guard. You don't have to stir constantly, but keep an eye on it for scorching and stir often. I also like to use a silicone 'spoonula' because it makes it easy to scrape the sides and bottom of the pan.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: When it is ready, you will be able to drag a spoon across the bottom of the pan and leave a trail that will not fill in immediately. The butter will continue to thicken as it cools.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: For a silky apple butter, blend in a blender until smooth.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text:
Put the apple butter into a jar and refrigerate. It will last several weeks. To freeze, be sure to leave 1/2 inch headspace at the top of the jar to allow for expansion.

Note

If fresh apples are to be used, slice apples into 1/4" pieces and add to slow cooker with sugar and spices and cook for 10 hours on low. Puree with immersion blender until smooth. Add vanilla and cook for additional 2 hours uncovered, stirring occasionally.

Note

If you use unsweetened apple sauce and want to sweeten your butter, add white or brown sugar, maple sugar, maple syrup, honey, or other sweetener (optional) to taste. Add your sweetener along with the spices to the pan at the very beginning.

Note

There are many flavored apple sauces on the market, and you can use those, too.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://theviewfromgreatisland.com/how-to-make-apple-butter-from-apple-sauce/

docs.title: Aquafaba Whipped Cream
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 16 6 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 0.75 cup (170 g) aquafaba
  • 0.25 tsp cream of tartar
  • 1 Tbsp vanilla
  • 0.67 cup (76 g) confectioners' sugar
  • 2 Tbsp neutral oil

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text: • 1 mixer

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Drain and save the liquid from a can of chickpeas or white beans (aquafaba).

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Pour 3/4 cup of the liquid in a medium-sized mixing bowl.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Use a mixer and beat the liquid until it starts to get foamy.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Add 1/4 tsp cream of tartar and continue to mix for 5 minutes on high until it becomes very fluffy and forms stiff peaks.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Add 1 Tbsp vanilla and continue to beat for 1 minute. (It will turn light brown for a minute, but then turn white again as it beats in).

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Slowly add 2/3 cup confectioners' sugar while continuing to mix on high until all vanilla and sugar are mixed in and the mixture if very fluffy. Mix for a total of 9-10 minutes for whipped cream that will hold it's fluffiness the longest.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Turn off mixer and add 2 Tbsps of your choice of neutral oil. (Melted if using coconut oil).

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text: Turn on mixer to low and beat for 5 to 10 seconds to get the oil distributed. (Do NOT over mix once the oil has been added or you will lose the fluffiness)!

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://thehiddenveggies.com/aquafaba-whipped-cream-vegan-cool-whip/

docs.title: Aquafaba
docs.text: Total Time 2.00 hours

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 1 cup dry chickpeas
  • some filtered water

docs.title: Best Ways to Use Aquafaba
docs.text:
If you’re wondering how to use aquafaba, let us get you started with some basics—the most common uses. Aquafaba is almost essential for everyday baking—especially for vegans—because it’s a great binder and can fluff up and trap air and serve as an excellent alternative to eggs. Here are the most common uses:

  • Egg Replacement – Use 3 tablespoons of liquid per egg in any recipe.
  • Meringues and Macarons – Yay! These fancy little desserts are accessible to vegans again. Whip your aquafaba into impossibly stiff peaks with a hand mixer or standing mixer and a pinch of cream of tartar. This might take 10 minutes or more, but it’s totally worth it.
  • Aquafaba Whipped Cream – Light fluffy vegan whipped cream made from chickpea water? Sounds preposterous, but it’s perfection!
  • Crusty Layer – Brush onto potatoes or the tops of pies before baking for a little added crispiness.
  • Egg White Substitute – Beaten into semi-stiff peaks (for about 5 minutes), this mixture is wonderful for adding into waffles or other baked items.
  • Chocolate Mousse – A marvelous mousse can be made with only whipped aquafaba, sugar and dark chocolate. So creamy and thick, you won’t believe your eyes. This recipe from Lazy Cat Kitchen is really dreamy.
  • Buttercream Frosting – Aquafaba makes a great base for buttercream that forms the most terrific texture. I like this recipe by Geeky Cakes. A bit more involved, but it produces a truly professional frosting.
  • Vegan Marshmallows or ‘Marshmallow’ Fluff – You can make your own vegetarian marshmallows from scratch using aquafaba!
  • Vegan Cheese – This recipe from Avocados and Ales is pretty popular and provides the most mouthwatering and meltable results for a plant-based mozzarella cheese.

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Soak 1 cup of dry chickpeas overnight in filtered water.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: The next day, drain and rinse the beans thoroughly.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Add beans to a pot and cover with several inches of water.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Bring to a boil on high heat, lower heat, and simmer for 1.5 – 2 hours.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Drain bean water into another pot or large mason jar to cool.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Save the cooked beans to use later.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Pressure Cooker Method: Soak 1 cup of dry chickpeas overnight in filtered water.

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text: The next day, drain and rinse the beans thoroughly.

docs.title: Step 9
docs.text: Place beans into the Instant Pot (or your favorite pressure cooker) and add just enough liquid to cover the beans completely.

docs.title: Step 10
docs.text: Pressure cook on HIGH for 15 to 18 minutes. The longer you let them cook, the softer they will get.

docs.title: Step 11
docs.text: Quick release and drain off the bean liquid into a large mason jar or other container.

docs.title: Step 12
docs.text: Save the cooked beans to use later.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.worldofvegan.com/aquafaba/

docs.title: Beurre Manié
docs.text: Total Time 5 minutes

docs.title: Ratio (Weight)
docs.text: butter  all-purpose flour 2 1

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• some softened butter
  • some all-purpose flour

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text: • 1 fork

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Simply mix equal parts of softened butter and all-purpose flour together in a small bowl, and use your fingers or a fork to form a smooth paste. Then roll teaspoon-size amounts of the paste into balls.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Note: You can also make large amounts of beurre manie in a food processor and store the balls in the freezer, bringing them to room temperature before use.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: When simmering a sauce, whisk in one ball at a time as needed. Allow the mixture to return to a boil, and cook for at east 1 minute to thicken. If your sauce is not as thick as you'd like, add a bit more beurre manie. The butter-coated flour particles will melt and quickly thicken the sauce as it simmers, and the additional butter will add a sleek luster, similar to the effect of mounting a sauce with cold butter.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.saveur.com/article/Techniques/saveur-100-beurre-manie/

docs.title: Bisquick
docs.text: Total Time 5 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 1 cup all-purpose flour
  • 1.5 tsp baking powder
  • 0.25 tsp salt
  • 1 Tbsp butter

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text: • 1 bowl

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Sift all-purpose flour into a bowl; add baking powder and salt and whisk until fully incorporated.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Cut butter into flour mixture using a pastry cutter until evenly combined.

docs.title: Source

docs.title: Blanched Almonds
docs.text: Total Time 1 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• some almonds
  • some boiling water

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text: • 1 heat-safe bowl

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Put the almonds in a heat-safe bowl and pour boiling water on top to cover. Let stand for 1 minutes (don't let them soak too long in the hot water or the nuts themselves will soften too much).

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Drain the almonds and run cold water over them to cool them down.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: The soaked almonds should now have skins that are loose enough to remove. Working one almond at a time, gently squeeze the nut between your fingers to begin popping it out of the skin, then peel the skin away to remove it fully.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.seriouseats.com/how-to-blanch-almonds

docs.title: Blueberry Syrup for Pancakes
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 15 3 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 0.5 cup maple syrup
  • 1.5 cup blueberries

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Put the maple syrup and blueberries into a pan and bring to the boil.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Let bubble for 2 to 3 minutes, and then pour into a jug and bring to the breakfast table with the pancakes.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.foodnetwork.com/recipes/nigella-lawson/blueberry-syrup-for-pancakes-recipe-1937313

docs.title: Bouquet Garni
docs.text: Total Time 5 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 3 sprigs parsley
  • 0.5 bay leaf
  • 2 sprigs thyme
  • 1 leek, white portion only (optional)
  • 2 cloves
  • 2 Tbsp dried parsley
  • 1 Tbsp dried thyme
  • 1 Tbsp dried marjoram
  • 2 bay leaves
  • 2 Tbsp dried celery leaves

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 kitchen string
  • 1 4-inch squares of cheesecloth

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: A bouquet garni is a combination of herbs, vegetables, and occasionally spices bundled in cheesecloth or tied with a string and used to flavor soup, stock, and sauces. They are removed before serving.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Fresh Herbs: Bunch together parsley, bay leaf, thyme, leek, white portion only (optional), and cloves.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: To make removal easier, you may place them inside several overlapping celery ribs or leak greens and bind tightly with kitchen string.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Dried Herbs: If you cannot get fresh herbs, wrap dried herbs, coarsely crumbled but not powdered, in 4-inch squares of cheesecloth tied into pouches. Store in tightly covered container up to 1 month.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Allow for 12 bags dried parsley, dried thyme,dried marjoram, bay leaves, and dried celery leaves.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • Joy of Cooking

docs.title: Breadcrumbs
docs.text: Total Time 5 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 1 loaf white mountain bread (publix)
  • 5 cloves garlic
  • 2 Tbsp sun-dried tomatoes
  • 1 Tbsp parsley
  • 0.5 cup Parmesan

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text: • 1 food processor

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Remove the crust from the white mountain bread (publix).

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Mix the garlic, sun-dried tomatoes and parsley in your food processor until well blended.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Mix the bread in the food processor and pulse until fine.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Mix the Parmesan in the food processor and pulse until fine.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: You can keep the crumbs in the refrigerator for a few days in small Tupperware style container or in the freezer for at least 3 to 4 months.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://chefjeanpierre.com/recipes/fresh-breadcrumbs/

docs.title: Brown Sugar
docs.text: Total Time 5 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text: Type White Sugar Molasses Light 0.25 cup 0.25 Tbsp Light 0.5 cup 0.5 Tbsp Light 0.75 cup 0.75 Tbsp Light 1 cup 1 Tbsp Dark 0.25 cup 0.5 Tbsp Dark 0.5 cup 1 Tbsp Dark 0.75 cup 1.5 Tbsp Dark 1 cup 2 Tbsp

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 bowl
  • 1 wooden spoon or mixer
  • 1 airtight container

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Gather the ingredients.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Combine white sugar and molasses in a bowl to make brown sugar. Mix with a wooden spoon or mixer until thoroughly blended.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Store brown sugar in an airtight container to prevent from drying out. Enjoy in your favorite recipes.

docs.title: Buttermilk
docs.text: Total Time 15 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 1 cup whole milk
  • 1 Tbsp vinegar or lemon juice

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text:
Mix 1 cup of whole milk with 1 tablespoon vinegar or lemon juice and let it sit for 10 to 15 minutes.

Note

The acidity in buttermilk tenderizes the gluten (protein) in flour, plus it works with baking soda better than plain milk by both neutralizing the flavor of the soda at the same time it is activating it, providing wonderful leavening.

Info

Buttermilk may also be made as a by product of the butter making process.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • The King Arthur Baking Company All-Purpose Baker's Companion

docs.title: Candied Orange Peel
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 4 6.00 hours

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 8 cup water
  • 3 large naval oranges
  • 2.5 cup granulated sugar
  • 0.5 tsp kosher salt

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 colander
  • 1 medium saucepan
  • 1 vegetable peeler or paring knife
  • 1 saucepan

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Place a colander in the sink. Bring 2 cups of the water to a boil in a medium saucepan over high heat.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Meanwhile, trim the top and bottom ends of 3 large naval oranges. Use a vegetable peeler or paring knife to peel 1 inch wide strips of zest from the oranges, going from top to bottom and making sure the strips have a thin layer of white pith (this will prevent the strips from curling too much later). Use a knife to cut the zest strips lengthwise into thinner 1/4 inch strips. Add the strips to the saucepan (it’s okay if the water isn't not boiling yet).

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Once the water is boiling, boil the orange peels for 30 seconds. Drain in the colander. Return the peels to the saucepan and add 2 cups of the water. Bring to a boil over high heat. Boil for 30 seconds and drain again. Repeat one more time for a total of 3 blanches.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Return the peels to the saucepan. Add the remaining 2 cups water, 1 1/2 cups of the granulated sugar, and 1/2 teaspoon kosher salt. Stir to combine and bring to a simmer over high heat. Reduce the heat to medium low and simmer until the peels are translucent and the syrup is thickened, 20 to 25 minutes. Meanwhile, line a baking sheet with parchment paper and place a wire rack on top.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Turn off the heat. Let the peels rest in the syrup for 5 minutes. Use tongs or chopsticks to transfer the peels onto the rack in a single layer, making sure they do not touch. Let dry on the rack for at least 6 hours to dehydrate and complete the candying process.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Place the remaining 1 cup granulated sugar in a shallow bowl. Working with a few at a time, toss the candied orange peels in the sugar until evenly coated all over.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.thekitchn.com/candied-orange-peel-recipe-23424483

docs.title: Caramelized Onions
docs.text: Total Time 1.67 hours

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 4 large onions
  • 1 Tbsp olive oil
  • 2 Tbsp (28 g) sweet butter
  • 0.5 cup (107 g) light brown sugar
  • 0.5 cup (114 g) balsamic vinegar
  • some salt
  • some pepper

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 Dutch oven
  • 1 sauté pan

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: In a Dutch oven at very low heat, cook the onions covered (no oil, no water nothing) just the onions for about 60 to 90 minutes. When cooked drain and set aside.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: After the onions have drained all the water, in a sauté pan, heat the olive oil and sweet butter at a medium heat, add the drained onion and cook until light golden brown.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text:
Add the light brown sugar and the balsamic vinegar. Cook for at least 10 minutes at very low heat. Season with salt and pepper. The onions are supposed to be NOT sweet NOT sour.

Tip

Spread the hot onions on a large flat surface, such as a sheet pan and let all of the water evaporate before putting in the freezer to prevent the formation of ice crystals.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://chefjeanpierre.com/recipes/caramelized-onions/

docs.title: Chickpea Flour
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 164 g 0 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text: • 200 g dried chickpeas

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 high-speed blender or spice grinder
  • 1 Sieve

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Directly blend the dried chickpeas in a high-speed blender or spice grinder.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Sieve the flour to remove any lumps. Then try grinding the larger particles again. Repeat until no lumps are left.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Store in an airtight container for up to 2 months.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.alphafoodie.com/how-to-make-chickpea-flour/

docs.title: Chili Paste
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 16 1.05 hours

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 1 large onion
  • 10 cloves garlic
  • 1 lb fresh chillies
  • 3 cashews
  • 5 candlenuts (alternative)
  • 5 macadamia (alternative)
  • 1 tsp granulated sugar
  • 1 tsp salt
  • some water
  • 0.5 cup vegetable oil

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 blender
  • 1 deep wok or saucepan
  • 1 jar

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Peel and quarter the onion, and peel the garlic.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Place fresh chillies, garlic, onion, cashews candlenuts (alternative), macadamia (alternative), granulated sugar, and salt in a blender. Add enough water to allow you to blend to a paste.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: As you'll be frying the paste in oil, you don't want it to be too runny.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: However, the long and slow cooking means that you may have to add a splash of water towards the end if it gets too dry.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Heat the vegetable oil in a deep wok or saucepan, then fry the chili paste on medium heat initially for about 3 minutes until fragrant.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Lower the heat and cook for 1 hour, uncovered, stirring every 15 minutes or so. In the last 15 minutes, you might have to stir a couple of times more, as the chili paste starts to dry up.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: If it starts getting too dry and is catching (burning) at the bottom, add a splash of water (about 60 ml / 1/4 cup) to allow you to keep cooking the paste for the full hour. Use less if you only have 10 minutes or so to go.

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text: Let your cooked red chili paste cool to room temperature and store in a clean jar in the fridge; it will last up to 2 weeks in the fridge. You can even freeze until needed, in ice cube trays would be perfect, as you can use a little at a time as needed.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.linsfood.com/homemade-chilli-paste-a-very-handy-basic-recipe/#recipe

docs.title: Coconut Bacon
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 4 cups 24 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 4 cups coconut chips
  • 2 Tbsp olive oil
  • 2 tsp chipotle powder
  • 1.25 tsp salt
  • 0.75 cup maple syrup

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 wide, heavy-bottomed pot
  • 1 oiled baking sheet

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Preheat the oven to 250°F.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: In a wide, heavy-bottomed pot over medium-high heat, add the coconut chips, olive oil, chipotle powder, and salt. Toast for 10 minutes, stirring continuously so the chips do not burn.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: When the coconut chips area dark golden color, stir in the maple syrup and continue cooking until the chips are well coated, another 2 minutes.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Transfer the coconut chips to an oiled baking sheet and toast them in the oven until they are crispy, 10 to 12 minutes.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Check every 3 to 4 minutes and turn the chips over to make sure they cook evenly.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: When the coconut chips are dry and crisp, remove them from the oven and allow them to cool completely.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: The coconut bacon can be stored in an airtight container or glass jar for up to 1 month outside of the refrigerator.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • The Gracias Madre Cookbook

docs.title: Confectioners' Sugar
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 1 cup 5 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 1 Tbsp cornstarch
  • 1 cup granulated sugar

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text: • 1 high-powered blender or a spice grinder

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text:
In order to make your own confectioners' sugar, you will need a fairly high-powered blender or a spice grinder. You should also add one tablespoon of cornstarch to each cup of granulated sugar. Blend both ingredients on high for 30 seconds, and guess what? You now have powdered sugar.

Note

Do not try this in a food processor, since this appliance will not be able to grind the sugar finely enough to turn it into a powder.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.mashed.com/182903/how-to-make-powdered-sugar-from-granulated-sugar/

docs.title: Croutons
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 4-6 cups 20 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 0.25 cup olive oil
  • 1 loaf bread
  • 2 tsp Italian seasoning
  • 1 tsp garlic powder
  • 0.75 tsp salt
  • 0.5 tsp pepper

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 large baking sheet
  • 1 parchment paper
  • 1 large bowl

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Preheat oven to 375°F. Line a large baking sheet with parchment paper; set aside.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: In a large bowl, evenly drizzle the olive oil over the bread chunks. Then evenly sprinkle the Italian seasoning, garlic powder, salt and pepper over the bread. Toss gently until well-combined.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Spread the bread cubes out in a single layer on a baking sheet.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Bake until golden, turning once halfway through cooking in order to brown all sides of the croutons. Cooking time will depend on the thickness of the cubes, so watch to be sure that they do not burn. (Mine generally take between 15 to 20 minutes.)

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Remove from oven, and let cool completely. Use immediately, or store in an air-tight container for up to 1 week.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.gimmesomeoven.com/how-to-make-homemade-croutons/

docs.title: Crumb Crust
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 1 9-in or 10-in piecrust and topping 30 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 1.5 cup graham cracker
  • 1.5 cup vanilla or chocolate wafer or gingersnap (alternative)
  • 0.5 cup sugar
  • 6 Tbsp unsalted butter
  • 0.5 salt
  • 1 tsp cinnamon (optional)

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 bowl
  • 1 pie pan

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: The flavor of the filling should determine which cracker or cookie to crumble.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Put in a bowl, reserving a tablespoon or two for topping, if desired 1/2 cups fine graham cracker, vanilla or chocolate wafer (alternative), or gingersnap crumbs.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Add and stir until well blended: 1/4 to 1/2 cup sugar, depending on sweetness of the cookies. 6 tablespoons (3/4 stick) unsalted butter, melted and cooled, 1/2 tsp salt, and 1 teaspoon ground cinnamon (optional).

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: An easy way to shape the crumb crust is to place the crumb mixture in a pie pan, distributing the crumbs fairly evenly, then press another pie pan of the same diameter firmly into the dough. When the top pan is removed, a crust of even thickness underneath. Trim any excess that is forced over the top edge, or just pat back into the pan.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Crumb crusts do not need to be baked before filling, but if used unbaked, the crust must first be frozen for 20 minutes, or the filling will soften it. If baked before filling, they are more crunchy and flavorful; a 350°F oven for 10 to 12 minutes will do the trick. Cool the baked shell before filling.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: When the pie is filled, scatter reserved crumbs as a topping.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • Joy of Cooking

docs.title: Crème Fraîche
docs.text: Total Time 16.00 hours

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 1 cup heavy cream
  • 2 Tbsp buttermilk

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 bowl
  • 1 clean kitchen cloth

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: In a bowl, combine the heavy cream and buttermilk. Cover with a clean kitchen cloth in a warm, draft-free place and let sit until thickened, but still a pourable consistency, 12 to 16 hours. Stir and refrigerate until ready to use. (Can be refrigerated for up to 1 week.)

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.foodnetwork.com/recipes/homemade-creme-fraiche-3646147.amp

docs.title: Date Paste
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 2 cups 20 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 4 cups water
  • 12 oz Medjool dates

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 pot
  • 1 4 cup glass measuring cup
  • 1 high speed blender

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Bring 4 cups of water to a simmer and remove the pot from the heat.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Place Medjool dates into a 4 cup glass measuring cup and cover with hot water. Let dates sit for 10 minutes to soften. Reserve 1.5 cups of the soaking liquid and drain the remaining water from the dates.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Place the dates and 1 cup of the reserved water into a high speed blender and blend until smooth. Add more water if you'd like a thinner consistency. Transfer to a glass container and cover.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://amyinthekitchen.com/date-paste/

docs.title: Dry Roasted Peanuts
docs.text: Total Time 22 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text: • 4 cups raw or preroasted peanuts

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text: • 1 rimmed baking sheet

docs.title: Instructions
docs.text:
Note

You can use raw or preroasted peanuts here, but do not use salted peanuts. Roasting the nuts before grinding them not only boosts their flavor but also warms their oils, allowing for faster breakdown during processing. (We also warm preroasted nuts for this reason.)

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Adjust oven rack to middle position and heat oven to 375°F. Spread raw or preroasted peanuts in single layer on rimmed baking sheet and roast until fragrant and slightly darkened, 10 to 12 minutes, rotating sheet halfway through roasting. (If using preroasted peanuts, place in oven for 5 minutes to warm.) Transfer sheet to wire rack and let peanuts cool slightly, about 10 minutes.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.cooksillustrated.com/recipes/11339-homemade-peanut-butter

docs.title: Dulce de Leche
docs.text: Total Time 3.00 hours

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text: • 1 can sweetened condensed milk

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 large pan
  • 1 pair of tongs or slotted spoon

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Bring a large pan of water to a rolling boil. Make sure that you put enough water in the pan to completely cover the can you're about to cook.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Remove the label from the can of sweetened condensed milk and carefully submerge it into the boiling water using a pair of tongs or slotted spoon. Make sure you place the can on its side, so it can roll around. If you place the can bottom or top-side down, the boiling water can cause it to bounce up and down, which is really annoying...

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Cook the can for 3 hours, making sure the can is covered with water at all times. Add more boiling water if necessary.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Using a pair of tongs, a fork, or a slotted spoon, take the can out of the pan and place it onto a heatproof surface to cool. Make sure it has cooled to room temperature before you open the can, otherwise the dulce de leche will squirt out like a fountain... Once cooled, stir until smooth.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Cooled dulce de leche can be stored, tightly covered, in the refrigerator for up to 3 weeks

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Spread it on bread, drizzle over cookies, cake or ice cream or eat by the spoonful. Enjoy!

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://thetoughcookie.com/2014/01/14/making-dulce-de-leche-made-in-the-can/

docs.title: Evaporated Milk
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 1.5 cups 25 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text: • 3.25 cups full-fat milk

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text: • 1 non-stick heavy bottom saucepan

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: In a non-stick heavy bottom saucepan, bring the full-fat milk to a simmer over medium heat (the milk will cook onto the sides of the pan, so using a non-stick pan will be so much easier to clean).

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Once it simmers, turn down the heat to medium-low and let it gently simmer, stirring the milk occasionally to make sure it's not getting scorched on the bottom of the pan.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Simmer the milk for about 25 minutes or until it's reduced down to roughly 1 1/2-1 1/4 cups of liquid.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Once the milk has reduced and turned a creamy color pass it through a sieve remove any skin. Set aside to cool completely.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Store the evaporated milk covered in the fridge for up to 5 days.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.biggerbolderbaking.com/evaporated-milk-recipe/

docs.title: Fajita Veggies
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 8 15 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• : 0.25 cup sunflower oil
  • 2 large green peppers
  • 1 large red onions
  • 0.5 tsp oregano
  • 0.5 tsp salt

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text: • 1 large skillet

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: In a large skillet over medium-high heat, heat sunflower oil until shimmering. Add green peppers, red onions, oregano, and salt to taste (I like 1/2 teaspoon).

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Cook, tossing occasionally, until slightly softened but still tender-crisp, about 7 minutes. Remove from heat and serve.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.culinaryhill.com/chipotle-grilled-peppers-and-onions/

docs.title: Flavored Sugars
docs.text: Total Time 5 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text: Flavor Granulated Sugar Ingredient Amount Spiced Chocolate 1/2 cup Cocoa Powder 1 Tbsp - - Cinnamon 3/4 tsp - - Cayenne 1/8 tsp Chai Spice 1/2 cup Cinnamon 1/4 tsp - - Ground Ginger 1/4 tsp - - Cardamom 1/4 tsp - - Cloves 1/4 tsp - - Black Pepper 1 pinch Ginger Lime 1/2 cup Ground Ginger 1/2 tsp - - Lime Zest 1 lime Vanilla Cardamom 1/2 cup Vanilla Bean Seeds 1 bean - - Cardamom 1 tsp Caffè Latte 1/2 cup Milk Powder 1 Tbsp - - Instant Espresso Powder 2 tsp

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 bowl
  • 1 fork
  • 1 glass jar

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Add granulated sugar and ingredients to a bowl. Use a fork or small whisk to combine, breaking up any clumps.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Store in a glass jar or any container with a tight-fitting lid for a few months.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • Cook's Illustrated

docs.title: Frico Crumble
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 1.5 cups 15 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text: • 2 oz Asiago, Manchego, or cheddar cheese

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 10-inch nonstick skillet
  • 1 spatulas
  • 1 paper towels

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Sprinkle 2 ounces finely grated aged Asiago, Manchego, or cheddar cheese (1/2 cup) evenly over bottom of cold 10-inch nonstick skillet. Cook over medium heat until edges are lacy and light golden, 2 to 3 minutes. Remove skillet from heat and let sit for 1 minute.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Using 2 spatulas, carefully flip frico. Return to medium heat and cook until second side is golden, about 1 minute. Carefully slide frico onto plate and set aside until cooled, about 10 minutes.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Wipe skillet clean with paper towels and repeat with 2 more ounces cheese. Let cool completely, then crumble into bite-size pieces.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • Cook's Illustrated

docs.title: Graham Crackers
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 12 55 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 0.13 tsp cinnamon
  • 0.5 tsp baking soda
  • 0.5 tsp salt
  • 0.75 tsp baking powder
  • 0.5 cup all-purpose flour
  • 3 oz dark brown sugar
  • 1 cup graham flour
  • 6 Tbsp unsalted butter
  • 2.25 oz molasses
  • 3 Tbsp milk
  • 0.5 tsp vanilla

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 food processor
  • 1 plastic
  • 1 parchment
  • 1 pizza cutter
  • 1 fork

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: In a food processor, combine cinnamon, baking soda, salt, baking powder, all-purpose flour, dark brown sugar, and graham flour. Pulse to combine. Add very cold diced unsalted butter and pulse until it resembles coarse cornmeal.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Add molasses, milk and vanilla. Pulse until a smooth dough forms. Press dough into a 1/2" thick disc, wrap in plastic and refrigerate 30 minutes.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Roll dough between sheets of parchment to 1/8" thickness. Cut into 2 X 2 inch squares with a pizza cutter (or an accordion cutter, if you have one). Prick each cracker 3 times with the tines of a fork (or a docking roller if you have one). Remove irregular edges and bake in preheated 350°F oven for 25 minutes until the color has gotten slightly paler. Allow to cool completely IN THE PAN. Store in zip top bag with as much air removed as possible for up to 14 days.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.food.com/recipe/graham-crackers-alton-brown-337422

docs.title: Grated Vegetable Shortening
docs.text: Total Time 45 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text: • 1 stick vegetable shortening

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 box grater
  • 1 cold bowl or onto a cold plate

docs.title: Instructions
docs.text:
Note

Substitute for suet.

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: If you can't find suet then we have found that grated vegetable shortening (such as Trex, Crisco or Copha) is a good substitute. To grate the shortening firstly freeze a stick or block of it until firm but not solid (this usually takes about 30 minutes).

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Grate the shortening on the coarse side of a box grater into a cold bowl or onto a cold plate, returning the fat to the freezer if it becomes too soft.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Before using the grated shortening chill it for another 10 to 15 minutes in the freezer.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.nigella.com/ask/substitute-for-suet

docs.title: Honey Whipped Cream
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 12 11 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 1 cup heavy cream
  • 1 Tbsp honey
  • 0.5 tsp vanilla
  • 0.13 tsp salt

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 mixing bowl
  • 1 hand mixer

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Place a mixing bowl and beater attachments of a hand mixer in the freezer for 10 minutes.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Pull your bowl and beaters out of the freezer and add in the heavy cream, honey, vanilla, and salt.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Whip on the medium speed setting of your hand mixer for 1 minute, or until the cream has become slightly fluffier in consistency.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Switch the speed to high and continue to whip until stiff peaks form.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Whipped cream can be stored in an airtight container in the refrigerator for up to 12 hours.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.tastingtable.com/923217/honey-whipped-cream-recipe/

docs.title: Ice Cream Cones
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 6 3 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 2 large egg whites
  • 1 pinch salt
  • 95 g confectioners' sugar
  • 0.25 tsp vanilla
  • 65 g all-purpose flour
  • 55 g unsalted butter

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 stand mixer
  • 1 spatula
  • 1 waffle cone maker
  • 1 cone roller

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: In the bowl of stand mixer fitted with the whisk attachment, whisk the egg whites until soft peaks form. Add the salt and 1 tablespoon of the confectioners' sugar then whisk until stiff peaks form.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Using a spatula, gently fold in vanilla extract and the remaining sugar, then fold in the all-purpose flour and melted unsalted butter, until smooth.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Heat a waffle cone maker according to manufacturer’s instructions. Spray the cooking plates with oil. Place a heaped tablespoon of the batter in the center of the cooking plate and close the lid.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Cook for 2 to 3 minutes until dark golden. While the waffle is warm, carefully roll it around the cone roller to form a cone shape, then leave to cool. Repeat with the remaining batter to make 6 cones.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://thegreatbritishbakeoff.co.uk/recipes/all/prue-leith-pistachio-praline-ice-cream/

docs.title: Jackfruit Mixiote
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 2 cups 12 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 2 Tbsp olive oil
  • 1 medium onion
  • 2 cloves garlic
  • 2 tsp cumin
  • 0.5 tsp chipotle powder
  • 1 20-oz can jackfruit
  • 0.5 cup salsa ranchera
  • 0.33 cup barbecue sauce
  • 1 small dried ancho chile
  • 2 tsp brown sugar
  • 0.25 tsp salt

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 small nonstick or cast-iron pan
  • 1 large nonstick or cast-iron pan
  • 1 high-speed blender

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: In a small nonstick or cast-iron pan, toast the dry ancho chile until fragrant.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: In a large nonstick or cast-iron pan over medium heat, heat the olive oil.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Add the onion, garlic, cumin, and chipotle powder and cook until the onion has softened and the spices are very fragrant, about 5 minutes.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Add the jackfruit and cook, stirring occasionally, until some of the liquid from the jackfruit has cooked out, another 5 to 7 minutes.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: In a high-speed blender, add the salsa ranchera, barbecue sauce, toasted dried ancho chile, brown sugar, and salt and blend until smooth.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Add the mixture to the jackfruit in the pan and stir to combine.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • The Gracias Madre Cookbook

docs.title: Jean Pierre's Vegetable Stock
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 4 to 6 quarts 2.00 hours

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 2 lbs carrots
  • 2 lbs onion
  • 1 stock celery
  • 2 leeks
  • 1 28-oz can tomatoes
  • 10 sprigs parsley
  • 3 bay leaves
  • 14 whole peppercorns
  • 3 sprigs thyme
  • 12 cloves garlic

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 strainer
  • 1 fine sieve

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Make sure all the vegetables are VERY clean. Place carrots, onion, celery, white and light green parts of leeks, tomatoes, parsley, bay leaves, whole peppercorns, thyme, and garlic in non-reacting (NO ALUMINUM) stock pot. Cover the vegetables with cold water only cover them.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Bring to boil, and IMMEDIATELY reduce to heat to a slow simmer. Cover and cook for about 90 minutes. Turn of the heat and let infuse for 30 minutes.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Strain the vegetables in a strainer and re-add the strained liquid to the pot.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Simmer the broth until it is reduced by 1/3.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Strain very carefully through a fine sieve, discarding all the solids.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://chefjeanpierre.com/recipes/how-to-make-vegetable-stock/

docs.title: Lemon Curd
docs.text: Total Time 30 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 3 lemons
  • 1.5 cup sugar
  • 0.25 lb butter
  • 4 eggs
  • 0.5 cup lemon juice
  • 0.13 tsp salt

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 peeler
  • 1 food processor
  • 1 2 quart saucepan, double boiler, or bain-marie
  • 1 fine mesh sieve

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Using a carrot peeler, remove the zest of 3 lemons, being careful to avoid the white pith. Put the zest in a food processor fitted with the steel blade. Add the sugar and pulse until the zest is very finely minced into the sugar.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Cream the room temperature butter and beat in the sugar and lemon mixture. Add the eggs, 1 at a time, and then add the lemon juice and salt. Mix until combined.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text:
Pour the mixture into a 2 quart saucepan, double boiler, or bain-marie and cook over low heat until thickened (about 10 minutes), stirring constantly. The lemon curd will thicken at about 170°F, or just below simmer. Remove from the heat and pass through a fine mesh sieve and cool or refrigerate.

Tip

It is best to sieve the mixture while it is still hot.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.foodnetwork.com/recipes/ina-garten/lemon-curd-recipe-1941910

docs.title: Marshmallow Fluff
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 6.5 cups 12 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 76 water
  • 149 g granulated sugar
  • 234 g light or dark corn syrup or honey
  • 3 large egg whites
  • 0.5 tsp cream of tartar
  • 1 tsp vanilla

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 medium-sized saucepan
  • 1 candy thermometer

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: In a medium-sized saucepan combine the water, granulated sugar and light or dark corn syrup or honey. Stir gently to combine. Insert a candy thermometer set for 240°F and heat over medium-high flame. Do not stir the sugar water as it cooks or it will form crystals.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: When the sugar syrup begins to form large bubbles, and the thermometer reads about 225°F to 230°F, place the egg whites and cream of tartar in the bowl of your stand mixer and beat the whites to soft peaks. This should take about 3 to 4 minutes.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: By the time the whites are whipped, the sugar syrup should be at 240°F. Remove from the heat and with the mixer running, carefully pour the syrup in a thin, steady stream into the whites.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: The whites will deflate slightly at first, but as the sugar syrup becomes incorporated, they will thicken, turn white and begin to fluff up.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Continue to whip the fluffy spread for 7 to 8 minutes, or until very thick and glossy. Add the vanilla and whip for another minute.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text:
Scoop the spread into an airtight container. Store for up to 2 weeks at room temperature. The spread can be re-whipped by hand if it becomes "flat."

Tip

Want to try flavored marshmallow spread? Here's some suggestions: Chocolate: add 1/4 to 1/3 cup cocoa powder during the last minutes of mixing Mint: substitute 1 teaspoon peppermint extract for the vanilla Lemon: add the zest of one large lemon to the finished spread.

Tip

If you want to substitute meringue powder for the fresh egg whites, use 3 tablespoons meringue powder + 5 tablespoons water.

Tip

Baking vegan? A good substitute for the egg whites in this recipe is aquafaba, the liquid drained from a can of chickpeas. Surprisingly, it whips into peaks just like egg whites! Substitute 2 tablespoons aquafaba for each large egg white; for specifics on the technique read our blog post, A guide to aquafaba.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.kingarthurbaking.com/recipes/homemade-marshmallow-spread-recipe

docs.title: Mint Filling
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 4 dozen 0 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 1 3-oz pkg cream cheese
  • 2 cups confectioners' sugar
  • 0.5 tsp vanilla
  • 0.25 tsp peppermint extract
  • 5 drops green food color
  • 3 tsp milk

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text: • 1 small bowl

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Beat cream cheese, confectioners' sugar, vanilla, peppermint extract and green food color in small bowl until smooth.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Add 2 to 3 teaspoons milk, if needed, for spreading consistency.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • Favorite Brand Name: Gifts From the Christmas Kitchen

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text: Mirepoix  Onion  Carrot  Celery 4 oz 2 oz 1 oz 1 oz 8 oz 4 oz 2 oz 2 oz 16 oz 8 oz 4 oz 4 oz 24 oz 12 oz 6 oz 6 oz 32 oz 16 oz 8 oz 8 oz

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Traditional mirepoix consists of two parts onions, one part carrots, and one part celery, with the proportions determined by weight. Therefore, one pound (16 oz) of mirepoix would be made up of 8 ounces of onions, 4 ounces of carrots, and 4 ounces of celery.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.thespruceeats.com/what-is-mirepoix-996133

docs.title: Miso Nori Paste
docs.text: Total Time 0 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 1 8x7 sheet nori
  • 0.25 cup white miso

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 tongs
  • 1 spice grinder

docs.title: Instructions
docs.text:
Note

Substitute for anchovy.

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Using tongs, hold 8 by 7-inch sheet of nori 2 inches above low flame, flipping every 3 to 5 seconds, until nori is aromatic and shrinks slightly, about 20 seconds (or toast in 275°F oven). Tear sheet into 1.5 inch pieces and grind in spice grinder to fine powder, about 30 seconds.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Measure out 1 teaspoon nori powder and stir into 1/4 cup white miso. (Extra powder can be stored in airtight container at room temperature for up to 2 months.) Paste can be stored in airtight container in refrigerator for up 1 month.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: To use as flavoring agent: Substitute in 1:1 ratio for minced anchovies (1 minced anchovy = 1/2 teaspoon).

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.cooksillustrated.com/how_tos/13677-a-vegan-substitute-for-anchovies

docs.title: Mushroom Pastor
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 4 cups 2.22 hours

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 1 lb oyster mushrooms
  • 2 dried guajillo chiles
  • 1 dried ancho chile
  • 1 chipotle in adobo
  • 0.25 onion
  • 0.5 cup pineapple juice
  • 2 Tbsp orange juice
  • 2 tsp apple cider vinegar
  • 1 clove garlic
  • 1 clove
  • 1.5 tsp salt
  • 0.5 tsp pepper
  • 0.25 tsp cumin
  • 0.25 tsp oregano

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 large bowl
  • 1 large cast-iron or other heavy sauté pan
  • 1 high-speed blender
  • 1 large nonstick pan
  • 1 tongs or a slotted spoon

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Remove the thick lower stems from the oyster mushrooms.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Over a large bowl, shred the oyster mushrooms into bite-size pieces. Set aside.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: In a large cast-iron or other heavy sauté pan over medium heat, toast the dried guajillo chiles and dried ancho chile until just fragrant, about 3 minutes.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: In a high-speed blender, add the toasted chiles, chipotle in adobo, onion, pineapple juice, orange juice, apple cider vinegar, garlic, clove, salt, pepper, cumin. and oregano.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Blend until smooth.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Pour the mixture over the mushrooms and toss to coat. Don't worry if the sauce doesn't look like it will coat all of the mushrooms-they'll collapse as they marinate, and you can give them another stir halfway through.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Cover and marinate in the refrigerator for at least 2 hours before cooking.

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text: When ready to serve, heat a large nonstick pan over medium heat.

docs.title: Step 9
docs.text: Using tongs or a slotted spoon, remove the mushrooms and leave any excess marinade in the bowl.

docs.title: Step 10
docs.text: Cook until the mushrooms are warmed through and the marinade has thickened a bit and become saucy, about 10 minutes.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • The Gracias Madre Cookbook

docs.title: Nixtamal Nicoyan Corn Tortillas
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 16 6 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 2 cups masa harina
  • 1 tsp salt
  • 0.25 tsp baking soda
  • 1.5 cups warm water

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 large bowl
  • 1 plastic wrap
  • 1 griddle or skillet
  • 1 kitchen tongs

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Whisk the masa harina, salt, and baking soda in a large bowl. Add 1.5 cups warm water and stir until a soft dough forms. If the mixture won’t form a soft ball of dough, add warm water in 1 tablespoon increments until it will. Cover with plastic wrap and set aside for 5 minutes.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Turn the dough out onto a clean, dry work surface. Knead gently for 1 minute. Divide it into 16 equal pieces, each about the size of a small plum.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: To use a tortilla press, line the press with two small sheets of wax paper. Put one piece of dough between the sheets, close the press, and gently press down. Remove the dough between the wax paper sheets, then repeat with more wax paper and the remaining dough balls. To make tortillas by hand, put each dough ball between two pieces of wax paper and roll it into a thin 6-inch round.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Set a griddle or skillet, preferably cast iron, over high heat until smoking. Remove one flattened dough ball from the wax paper and set on the griddle or in the pan. Cook for 30 seconds, flip with kitchen tongs, and cook until lightly toasted with tiny bubbles in the tortilla, about 30 seconds more. Transfer to a clean kitchen towel, wrap gently, and continue cooking more tortillas, keeping them warm as a stack in the towel. Serve warm.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.bluezones.com/recipe/nixtamal-nicoyan-corn-tortillas/

docs.title: Onion Pique
docs.text: Total Time 5 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 0.5 onion
  • 1 bay leaf
  • 2 whole dried cloves

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Trim off the root end of half a peeled onion.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Attach a bay leaf to the cut-side of the onion using 2 or 3 whole dried cloves as pins.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Add to a pot of stock or milk to cook for about 20 minutes. Remove, squeeze out the liquid, and discard when the stock or milk is finished.

docs.title: Onion Clouté
docs.text: Leave out the bay leaf and just spike your onion with cloves.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.culinaryhill.com/how-to-make-an-onion-pique/

docs.title: Onion Soup Mix
docs.text: Total Time 5 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 0.25 cup dried onion flakes
  • 0.25 tsp onion powder
  • 0.25 tsp parsley
  • 2 Tbsp beef bouillon granules
  • 0.13 tsp celery seed
  • 0.13 tsp paprika
  • 0.13 tsp pepper

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Mix dried onion flakes, onion powder, parsley, beef bouillon granules, celery seed, paprika, and pepper together is a small mixing bowl. Store in an airtight container until you a ready to use.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.eatingonadime.com/homemade-onion-soup-mix/

docs.title: Oreo Pie Crust
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 8 20 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 24 cookies Oreos
  • 4 Tbsp butter

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 food process
  • 1 large bowl
  • 1 9-inch ungreased pie plate

docs.title: Instructions
docs.text:
Note

This recipe works best with classic Oreo cookies. I suggest not using the Thins, Double Stuf, or Mega Stuf.

Note

This crust recipe can be pressed into a 9 to 10-inch springform pan for a cheesecake crust as well.

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Pulse the Oreos (filling included) in a food process or chopper until you get fine crumbs. Add the crumbs to a large bowl. Add the melted butter and stir to ensure the crumbs are well coated.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Pour the mixture into a 9-inch ungreased pie plate and carefully press the mixture evenly on the bottom and sides of the pie plate. I like to use a 1/3 or 1/4 cup dry measuring cup to press it flat.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: To set the crust, you can either bake it or refrigerate it. If I'm going to use it in a no-bake recipe, I just put it in the refrigerator for about 30 minutes to allow the butter to harden and set the crust. Otherwise, you can bake it in a 350°F oven for 8 to 10 minutes, then allow it to cool completely before finishing your recipe.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://southernbite.com/homemade-oreo-pie-crust/

docs.title: Pasta
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 4 20 minutes

docs.title: Ratio
docs.text: Flour  Egg 3 parts 2 parts

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 2 cups all-purpose flour
  • 3 large eggs
  • 0.5 tsp salt (optional)
  • 1 tsp olive oil (optional)

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 fork
  • 1 dough scraper

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Mount in a clean counter all-purpose flour.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Make a well in the center and add to the well eggs, salt (optional), and olive oil (optional).

docs.title: Step 3A
docs.text: Beat the eggs lightly with a fork, drawing in some flour as you go, until the eggs are mixed and slightly thickened. Using the fingertips of one hand, gradually incorporate the flour into the eggs and blend everything into a smooth, not too stiff dough. If the dough feels too dry and crumbly, add a little water as needed. If it is too sticky, add a little more flour. Use a dough scraper to left and turn the dough if it sticks.

docs.title: Step 3B
docs.text: Alternatively, process the ingredients in a food processor just until blended, 15 to 20 seconds, being careful not to overwork the dough. Knead the dough until satiny and very elastic, about 10 minutes, or pulse for 15 to 20 seconds then remove from the processor and knead for 10 minutes. Divide the dough into 4 pieces, and wrap the pieces loosely in plastic wrap or cover with an inverted bowl. Let the dough rest at room temperature for 60 minutes before rolling out.

docs.title: 𓇫 Rolling Out and Cutting Fresh Pasta
docs.text: The key to light, resilient pasta is gently stretching and pulling the sheet of dough as you roll it thinner and thinner. Whether with a rolling pin or a hand-cranked pasta machine, work with only a quarter of the pasta dough at a time, leaving the rest loosely covered.

docs.title: Working by Hand
docs.text: Lightly flour a large surface and use a rolling pin to roll out one piece of the dough at a time, repeatedly giving it a quarter turn as the circle grows. Continue, flipping the dough over occasionally, until it reaches the desired thickness. For ribbon pastas, such as fettuccine, the dough should be about 1/8 inch thick, thin enough to detect the outline of your hand through it. For filled pasta, the sheets should be as thin as paper, sheer enough to see your hand clearly through it.
