• Joy of Cooking
  • https://lilluna.com/how-to-cook-pasta/
  • https://www.barilla.com/en-us/help/measuring-pasta

docs.title: Peanut Butter
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 16 50 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 4 cups raw or preroasted peanuts
  • 1 tsp honey
  • 0.75 tsp salt

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 rimmed baking sheet
  • 1 food processor

docs.title: Instructions
docs.text:
Note

You can use raw or preroasted peanuts here, but do not use salted peanuts. Roasting the nuts before grinding them not only boosts their flavor but also warms their oils, allowing for faster breakdown during processing. (We also warm preroasted nuts for this reason.) You can customize your peanut butter by adding 1/4 to 1/2 teaspoon of ground cinnamon, nutmeg, or ginger or 1/8 teaspoon of cayenne pepper to the peanuts before processing in step 2.

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Dry roast the raw or preroasted peanuts.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Process peanuts in food processor until oil is released and paste begins to form, scraping down sides of bowl often. Add honey and salt and continue to process to desired smoothness, 3 to 4 minutes longer. Season with extra honey and salt to taste. If butter is thicker than desired, thin by adding vegetable oil, 1 teaspoon at a time, pulsing 3 times after each addition, until desired consistency is reached. If butter is thinner than desired, thicken by adding water, 1 teaspoon at a time, pulsing 3 times after each addition, until desired consistency is reached. Transfer to jar with tight-fitting lid. Butter can be stored at room temperature or refrigerated for up to 2 months.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.cooksillustrated.com/recipes/11339-homemade-peanut-butter

docs.title: Pectin
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 2 cups 30 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 2 lbs tart green apples
  • 4 cups water
  • 1 Tbsp lemon juice

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 saucepan
  • 1 cheesecloth

docs.title: Instructions
docs.text:
Note

Pectin is a natural fiber found in most plants. Fruits like apples and oranges are particularly high in pectin, with the highest concentrations in the skins, cores and seeds.

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: In a saucepan, boil two pounds of tart green apples (slightly under-ripe apples work best) with four cups of water and one tablespoon of lemon juice for 30 minutes, then strain through cheesecloth

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text:
Boil further to reduce the volume by half will result in an effective homemade liquid pectin.

Info

See Equivalents & Substitutes for dry to liquid pectin conversion.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.thekitchn.com/the-point-of-pectin-5-reasons-to-add-it-to-your-jam-193449

docs.title: Pickled Carrots & Daikon
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 20 20 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 2 lbs carrots
  • 2 lbs daikon radishes
  • 4 tsp granulated sugar
  • 2 tsp salt
  • 1 cup granulated sugar
  • 2.5 cups white vinegar
  • 2 cups warm water

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 colander
  • 1 bowl
  • 1 jars

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Julienne the carrots and the daikon radishes: Cut them first crosswise into 2.5 inch long segments. Then cut 1/4 inch thick slices lengthwise. Stack the slices and cut them again into 1/4 inch thick batons.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Massage in the salt and sugar: Place the carrots and daikon radishes in a large bowl. Sprinkle with 4 teaspoons of granulated sugar and 2 teaspoons of salt. Use your clean hands to toss the carrots and daikon with the salt and sugar until well coated.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Continue to mix the carrots and daikon with your hands until they begin to soften, about 3 minutes. They are ready once you can bend a piece of daikon all the way over without it breaking.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Rinse: Transfer the carrots and daikon to a colander, rinse with cool water and drain well.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Make the vinegar and sugar mixture: In a bowl (an 8 cup Pyrex measuring cup works great for this) mix together one cup of granulated sugar, the white vinegar and the warm water, until the sugar dissolves.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Pack the vegetables in the jars and fill with the vinegar mixture: Prepare clean jars. Pack the daikon and carrots tightly into the jars. Pour over the pickling liquid to cover. Seal. Refrigerate.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: The pickles should sit at least overnight before eating; their flavor will improve with time. They should last 4 to 6 weeks in the refrigerator.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.simplyrecipes.com/recipes/vietnamese_daikon_and_carrot_pickles/

docs.title: Pizza Dough
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 12 1 hour

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 2 cup all-purpose flour
  • 1 pkg instant yeast
  • 1.5 tsp sugar
  • 0.75 tsp salt
  • 0.25 tsp garlic powder (optional)
  • 0.25 tsp dried basil (optional)
  • 2 Tbsp olive oil
  • 0.75 cup warm water

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 large bowl
  • 1 wooden spoon
  • 1 parchment paper
  • 1 pizza pan

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Combine 1 cup (125g) of all-purpose flour, instant yeast, sugar, and salt in a large bowl. If desired, add garlic powder (optional) and dried basil (optional) at this point as well.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Add olive oil and warm water and use a wooden spoon to stir well very well.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Gradually add another 1 cup (125g) of flour. Add any additional flour as needed (I've found that sometimes I need as much as an additional 1/3 cup), stirring until the dough is forming into a cohesive, elastic ball and is beginning to pull away from the sides of the bowl (see video above recipe for visual cue). The dough will still be slightly sticky but still should be manageable with your hands.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Drizzle a separate, large, clean bowl generously with olive oil and use a pastry brush to brush up the sides of the bowl.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Lightly dust your hands with flour and form your pizza dough into a round ball and transfer to your olive oil-brushed bowl. Use your hands to roll the pizza dough along the inside of the bowl until it is coated in olive oil, then cover the bowl tightly with plastic wrap and place it in a warm place.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Allow dough to rise for 30 minutes or until doubled in size. If you intend to bake this dough into a pizza, I also recommend preheating your oven to 425°F (215°C) at this point so that it will have reached temperature once your pizza is ready to bake.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Once the dough has risen, use your hands to gently deflate it and transfer to a lightly floured surface and knead briefly until smooth (about 3-5 times).

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text: Use either your hands or a rolling pin to work the dough into 12" circle.

docs.title: Step 9
docs.text: Transfer dough to a parchment paper lined pizza pan and either pinch the edges or fold them over to form a crust.

docs.title: Step 10
docs.text: Drizzle additional olive oil (about a Tablespoon) over the top of the pizza and use your pastry brush to brush the entire surface of the pizza (including the crust) with olive oil.

docs.title: Step 11
docs.text: Use a fork to poke holes all over the center of the pizza to keep the dough from bubbling up in the oven.

docs.title: Step 12
docs.text: Add desired toppings (see the notes for a link to my favorite, 5-minute pizza sauce recipe!) and bake in a 425°F (215°C) preheated oven for 13-15 minutes or until toppings are golden brown. Slice and serve.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://sugarspunrun.com/the-best-pizza-dough-recipe/

docs.title: Pumpkin Filling
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 12 21 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 1 Tbsp olive oil
  • 1 medium onions
  • 1 cup cremini mushroom
  • 1.5 cups pumpkin or butternut squash
  • 1 tsp salt
  • 1 cup kale
  • 2 Tbsp fresh mint

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text: • 1 large nonstick or cast-iron pan

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: In a large nonstick or cast-iron pan over medium-high heat, heat the olive oil. Add the thinly sliced onions and thinly sliced cremini mushroom and cook, stirring, until the onions are translucent and the mushrooms have given off some moisture, about 8 minutes.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Reduce the heat to medium and add the diced pumpkin or butternut squash and 1/2 tsp of salt.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Cook, stirring occasionally, until the squash is soft but holds its shape, about 10 minutes.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Add the chopped kale and the remaining 1/2 tsp salt and cook until the kale is wilted, about 3 minutes.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Add the chopped fresh mint and stir to combine.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • The Gracias Madre Cookbook

docs.title: Pumpkin Purée
docs.text: Total Time 2.52 hours

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text: • 1 pumpkin or large squash (sugar pie pumpkin, butternut, buttercup or kabocha squash)

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 baking sheet
  • 1 parchment paper
  • 1 food processor
  • 1 fine mesh strainer or cheesecloth

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Preheat the oven to 400°F and line a baking sheet with parchment paper. Slice the pumpkin or large squash (sugar pie pumpkin, butternut, buttercup or kabocha squash) in half, scoop out the seeds and place cut side down on the baking sheet.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Roast for 40 to 60 minutes or until the flesh is soft and a fork easily slides in. Let cool for about 1 hour. Use your hands to peel the flesh from the skin and place in a food processor. Purée until smooth, letting your food processor run for about 1 minute, stopping to scrape down the sides as needed. If your puree is more watery than the texture of canned pumpkin, strain the excess liquid by letting it sit in a fine mesh strainer or cheesecloth over a bowl for 30 minutes.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text:
Chill until ready to use.

Note

Avoid large Halloween carving pumpkins because their flesh is too fibrous for a soft puree.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.loveandlemons.com/how-to-make-pumpkin-puree/

docs.title: Pumpkin Seed Parmesan
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 1 cup 0 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 0.5 cup pumpkin seeds
  • 0.5 cup sesame seeds
  • 1 tsp salt
  • 0.5 tsp minced garlic
  • 0.5 tsp chili powder

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text: • 1 food processor or high-speed blender

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Toast the pumpkin and sesame seeds until fragrant.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: In a food processor or high-speed blender, add the pumpkin seeds, sesame seeds, salt, minced garlic, and chili powder and pulse until a loose powder forms.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Store in the refrigerator for up to 2 weeks.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • The Gracias Madre Cookbook

docs.title: Queso Fresco
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 24 3.50 hours

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 1 gallon whole milk
  • 0.67 cup lemon juice or vinegar
  • some salt

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 colander
  • 1 cheesecloth
  • 1 large pot
  • 1 instant-read thermometer
  • 1 slotted spoon or wire skimmer
  • 1 plastic wrap

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Line colander with four layers of cheesecloth or 2 layers of food-safe paper towels and set over large bowl.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Heat whole milk in a large pot over medium-low heat, stirring frequently, until it registers 165 to 180°F on an instant-read thermometer. Add the lemon juice or vinegar 1 tablespoon at a time, stirring gently after each addition. Stop adding the acid when the curds separate from the whey: you will see white clumps of curd suspended in a pale translucent whey. Let sit uncovered for at least 5 minutes and up to 20 minutes while the separation finishes.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Using slotted spoon or wire skimmer, transfer curds to prepared colander, cover exposed top with plastic wrap, and allow to drain until desired texture is reached, about 20 minutes if using for pressed cheese (see step 3), or an hour for fresh curds.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Gently stir in salt to taste. Using slotted spoon or wire skimmer, transfer curds to prepared colander, cover exposed top with plastic wrap, and allow to drain until desired texture is reached, about 20 minutes if using for pressed cheese (see step 3), or an hour for fresh curds. Gently stir in salt to taste.Using slotted spoon or wire skimmer, transfer curds to prepared colander, cover exposed top with plastic wrap, and allow to drain until desired texture is reached, about 20 minutes if using for pressed cheese (see step 3), or an hour for fresh curds. Gently stir in salt to taste.Using slotted spoon or wire skimmer, transfer curds to prepared colander, cover exposed top with plastic wrap, and allow to drain until desired texture is reached, about 20 minutes if using for pressed cheese, or 1 hour for fresh curds.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Gently stir in salt to taste.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: For pressed cheese, gather curds into a ball in the middle of the cloth and press them into a hockey-puck shape. Tie the cloth closed around the cheese.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Place the bound cheese back in the colander and place a heavy can or pan on top.

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text: Let sit until cheese has reached desired texture, about a 1.5 hours.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.seriouseats.com/queso-fresco-easy-cheese-recipe

docs.title: Quick Mexican-Style Chorizo
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 8 oz 8 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 1.5 Tbsp vegetable oil
  • 1 Tbsp ancho chile powder
  • 1 Tbsp paprika
  • 1.5 tsp ground coriander
  • 1.5 tsp dried oregano
  • 0.75 tsp salt
  • 0.5 tsp pepper
  • 0.25 tsp ground cinnamon
  • 1 pinch cayenne
  • 1 pinch allspice
  • 3 Tbsp cider vinegar
  • 1.5 tsp sugar
  • 1 clove garlic
  • 8 oz soy meat

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 12-inch nonstick skillet
  • 1 rubber spatula

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Combine vegetable oil, ancho chile powder, paprika, ground coriander, dried oregano, salt, pepper, ground cinnamon, cayenne, and allspice in 12-inch nonstick skillet. Cook over medium heat, stirring constantly, until mixture is bubbling and fragrant. Off heat, carefully stir in cider vinegar, sugar, and garlic (mixture will sputter). Let stand until steam subsides and skillet cools slightly, about 5 minutes.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Add soy meat to skillet. Mash and mix with rubber spatula until spice mixture is evenly incorporated into soy meat. Return skillet to medium-high heat and cook, mashing and stirring until soy meat has broken into fine crumbles and juices are bubbling, about 3 minutes.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • Cook's Illustrated

docs.title: Quick Strawberry Jam
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 600 g 5 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 200 g granulated sugar
  • 24 g apple pectin
  • 700 g strawberry purée
  • 30 g lemon juice
  • 20 g rum

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 small bowl
  • 1 medium pot
  • 1 bowl

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: In a small bowl, combine granulated sugar and apple pectin. Pour the strawberry purée into a medium pot and bring to a simmer over medium heat. Stir in the lemon juice and rum.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text:
While whisking, sprinkle the sugar and pectin mixture on top of the simmering purée and mix until incorporated.

Tip

Make sure to sprinkle the sugar and pectin mixture evenly over the purée, rather than dumping the whole mixture in at once as it may clump into a ball.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text:
Continue cooking the purée for 4 to 5 minutes, stirring occasionally until the purée has reduced to a thick jam texture.

Tip

To test for when the jam is set, spoon some onto a marble surface or plate, let cool for 1 minute, then run your finger through it to see if the jam stays put and doesn’t run back together. If it stays put, then it’s ready!

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Remove the pot from the heat and let cool to room temperature. Transfer the jam to a bowl. Chill in the fridge, covered with plastic wrap, until ready to use.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • Dominique Ansel

docs.title: Ranch Dressing Mix
docs.text: Total Time 5 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 1 cup dry buttermilk
  • 2.5 Tbsp dried parsley
  • 2 Tbsp dried chives
  • 2 tsp dried dill
  • 2.5 tsp garlic powder
  • 1.5 tsp onion powder
  • 1.5 tsp dried onion flakes
  • 2 tsp salt
  • 0.5 tsp black pepper
  • 0.5 tsp paprika
  • 0.25 tsp cayenne

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text: • 1 mixing bowl

docs.title: Instructions
docs.text:
Note

2 tablespoons of the ranch mix is equivalent to one packet.

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: In a mixing bowl; measure and add in the dry buttermilk with dried parsley dried chives, dried dill, garlic powder, onion powder, dried onion flakes, salt, black pepper, paprika, and cayenne whisking to combine.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Transfer the ranch mix into a jar or container that has a tight-fitting lid.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Store in the fridge for up to 12 months.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.simplyscratch.com/homemade-ranch-dressing-mix/

docs.title: Rice Flour
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 1.25 to 1.5 cups 5 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text: • 1 cup rice

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 baking sheet
  • 1 blender or spice grinder
  • 1 fine-mesh sieve

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Rinse the rice under cold water until the water runs clear. This removes excess starch and impurities.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: For an even finer flour, you can spread the rinsed rice on a baking sheet and let it air dry completely. This step is optional but recommended.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Working in small batches, add the rice to your blender or spice grinder. Pulse until the rice is broken down into a fine powder. This may take a few minutes, depending on your equipment.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text:
If you want an extra-fine flour, sift it through a fine-mesh sieve to remove any larger pieces. This step is optional.

Note

Any kind will work (white, brown, long grain, short grain), but keep in mind that the type of rice will affect the texture of your flour.

Note

The type of rice you use will affect the texture of your flour. For example, glutinous rice flour (made from sweet rice) will be stickier than flour made from long-grain rice.

Tip

Overloading your blender or grinder can result in unevenly ground flour.

Tip

Over-grinding can cause the flour to heat up and become gummy.

Tip

For a super fine texture, grind the rice once, then pass it through the grinder again.

docs.title: Ricotta
docs.text: Total Time 26 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 4 cup whole milk
  • 2 cup heavy cream
  • 1 tsp salt
  • 3 Tbsp white wine vinegar

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 large sieve
  • 1 deep bowl
  • 1 cheesecloth
  • 1 stainless-steel or enameled pot
  • 1 bowl

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Set a large sieve over a deep bowl. Dampen 2 layers of cheesecloth with water and line the sieve with the cheesecloth.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Pour the whole milk and heavy cream into a stainless-steel or enameled pot such as Le Creuset. Stir in the salt. Bring to a full boil over medium heat, stirring occasionally. Turn off the heat and stir in the white wine vinegar. Allow the mixture to stand for 1 minute until it curdles. It will separate into thick parts (the curds) and milky parts (the whey).

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Pour the mixture into the cheesecloth-lined sieve and allow it to drain into the bowl at room temperature for 20 to 25 minutes, occasionally discarding the liquid that collects in the bowl. The longer you let the mixture drain, the thicker the ricotta. (I tend to like mine on the thicker side, but some prefer it moister.) Transfer the ricotta to a bowl, discarding the cheesecloth and any remaining whey. Use immediately or cover with plastic wrap and refrigerate. The ricotta will keep refrigerated for 4 to 5 days.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.foodnetwork.com/recipes/ina-garten/homemade-ricotta-recipe-1923290

docs.title: Roasted Garlic
docs.text: Total Time 40 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 1 whole garlic bulb
  • some olive oil
  • 1 pinch salt

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text: • 1 baking pan

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Preheat your oven to 400°F (205° C). A toaster oven works great for this.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Peel and discard the papery outer layers of the whole garlic bulb. Leave intact the skins of the individual cloves of garlic

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Using a sharp knife, cut 1/4 to a 1/2 inch from the top of cloves. This exposes the individual cloves of garlic.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Place the garlic heads in a baking pan, cut side up. (A muffin pan works great for this, as it keeps the garlic bulbs from rolling around.)

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Drizzle a couple teaspoons of olive oil over each exposed head, using your fingers to rub the olive oil over all the cut, exposed garlic cloves.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Sprinkle a pinch of salt over the top of the garlic head.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Cover the bulb with aluminum foil.

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text: Bake at 400°F (205°C) for 30 to 40 minutes, or until the cloves are lightly browned and feel soft when pressed.

docs.title: Step 9
docs.text: Allow the garlic to cool enough so you can touch it without burning yourself. Use a small knife cut the skin slightly around each clove. Use a cocktail fork or your fingers to pull or squeeze the roasted garlic cloves out of their skins.

docs.title: Step 10
docs.text: Eat as is (I love straight roasted garlic) or mash with a fork and use for cooking. Can be spread over warm French bread, mixed with sour cream for a topping for baked potatoes, or mixed in with Parmesan and pasta.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.simplyrecipes.com/recipes/roasted_garlic/

docs.title: Roasted Red Peppers
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 4 20 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 2 red bell pepper
  • some olive oil

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 baking sheet
  • 1 foil

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Turn on the broiler on your oven.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Cut the cap off each red bell pepper, and pull out the seeds. Discard.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Cut the peppers in half, and lay skin side up on a baking sheet lined with foil.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Broil until skins are charred black, about 10 minutes.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Remove peppers from oven, and use tongs.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Cover with a plate or even foil and let the peppers steam for at least 10 minutes.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Remove covering, and peel the charred skins off.

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text: Slice each pepper half into strips (at your desired thickness).

docs.title: Step 9
docs.text: Store in the refrigerator for up to a week.

docs.title: Step 10
docs.text: Optional: to make them last a bit longer, pour a coating of olive oil over the peppers and toss to combine.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.apinchofhealthy.com/how-to-roast-red-peppers/

docs.title: Roux
docs.text: Total Time 20 minutes

docs.title: Ratios
docs.text:
flour fat 3 2

Note

At home, and especially for small amounts, equal parts of flour and whole butter by weight can be used.

docs.title: Thickening
docs.text: Liquid Roux 10 1

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text: Roux Type Sauce Consistency Clarified Butter All-Purpose Flour Liquid Time White Light 1.5 Tbsp 1.5 Tbsp 4 cups 3-5 minutes White Medium 2 Tbsp 2 Tbsp 4 cups 3-5 minutes White Heavy 3 Tbsp 3 Tbsp 4 cups 3-5 minutes Blond Light 1.5 Tbsp 1.5 Tbsp 4 cups 6-7 minutes Blond Medium 2 Tbsp 2 Tbsp 4 cups 6-7 minutes Blond Heavy 3 Tbsp 3 Tbsp 4 cups 6-7 minutes Brown Light 1.5 Tbsp 1.5 Tbsp 4 cups 15-20 minutes Brown Medium 2 Tbsp 2 Tbsp 4 cups 15-20 minutes Brown Heavy 3 Tbsp 3 Tbsp 4 cups 15-20 minutes

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text: • 1 medium saucepan

docs.title: Instructions
docs.text:
Note

The longer you cook the roux, the less it will thicken a sauce or other mixture. Heat eventually breaks down the starch in the flour.

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Melt in a medium saucepan over medium-low heat add 2 Tbsp clarified butter. Whisk in until well blended and smooth, about 1.5 minutes 2 Tbsp all-purpose flour.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: White roux, used to make white sauce, or béchamel, is cooked just until the butter and flour are evenly incorporated and should be removed from the heat before the roux begins to color, 3 to 5 minutes.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Blond roux, used in velouté sauces and some cream soups, is cooked until it begins to give off a faint nutty aroma and turns an ivory color, 6 to 7 minutes.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Brown roux, basic to Cajun and Creole cooking, is cooked the longest (15 to 20 minutes, sometimes more) until it is dark brown and has a string nutty fragrance.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Light sauce uses 3 oz total roux (1.5 oz each of butter and flour) for each 4 cups of liquid.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Medium sauce uses 4 oz total roux (2 oz each of butter and flour) for each 4 cups of liquid.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Heavy sauce uses 6 oz total roux (3 oz each of butter and flour) for each 4 cups of liquid.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • Joy of Cooking

docs.title: Sauerkraut
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 24 30 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 1 head green cabbage
  • 2 Tbsp pickling and canning salt
  • 1.5 tsp juniper berries
  • 2 cups water

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 parchment paper
  • 1 1/2 gallon glass or ceramic container
  • 1 large bowl
  • 1 1 quart zipper-lock bag
  • 1 cheesecloth
  • 1 rubber band

docs.title: Instructions
docs.text:
Note

To help the cabbage stay submerged, we place a bag of brine on top to weigh it down. We use brine (rather than water) because if the bag breaks it won’t ruin the careful balance of salinity inside the jar. For a balanced flavor, we prefer fermenting at a cool room temperature of 65 degrees (consider locations such as a basement, den, or cabinet in an air-conditioned room). We don’t recommend fermenting above 70 degrees as the flavor suffers, and above 75 degrees food safety becomes a concern. You will need cheesecloth for this recipe.

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Cut out parchment paper round to match diameter of 1/2 gallon glass or ceramic container. Toss green cabbage with 4 teaspoons pickling and canning salt in large bowl. Using your hands, forcefully knead salt into cabbage until it has softened and begins to release moisture, about 3 minutes. Stir in juniper berries.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Tightly pack cabbage mixture and any accumulated liquid in jar, pressing down firmly with your fist to eliminate air pockets as you pack. Press parchment round flush against surface of cabbage.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Dissolve remaining 2 teaspoons salt in water and transfer to 1 quart zipper-lock bag; squeeze out air and seal bag well. Place bag of brine on top of parchment and gently press down. Cover jar with triple layer of cheesecloth and secure with rubber band.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Place jar in cool room-temperature location (50°F to 70°F; do not expose cabbage to temperatures above 70°F) away from direct sunlight and let ferment for 6 days; check jar daily, skimming residue and mold from surface and pressing to keep cabbage submerged. After 6 days, taste sauerkraut daily until it has reached desired flavor (this may take up to 7 days longer; sauerkraut should be pale and translucent with a tart and floral flavor).

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: When sauerkraut has reached desired flavor, remove cheesecloth, bag of brine, and parchment and skim off any residue or mold. Serve. (Sauerkraut and accumulated juices can be transferred to clean jar, covered, and refrigerated for up to 2 months; once refrigerated, flavor of sauerkraut will continue to mature.)

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • Cook's Illustrated

docs.title: Scottish Oatmeal
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 5 oz 2 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text: • 5 oz steel-cut oats

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text: • 1 food processor

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Process 3/4 cup plus 2 tablespoons (5 ounces) steel-cut oats in a food processor until they're about half oat flour and half oat pieces, about 2 minutes, or blend in a blender for about 15 seconds.

docs.title: Simple Syrup
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 500 g 15 minutes

docs.title: Ratio
docs.text: Sugar  Water  Alcohol 10 parts 10 parts 1 part

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 250 g granulated sugar
  • 250 g water
  • 25 g alcohol (optional)

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text: • 1 pot

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text:
In a pot, bring granulated sugar and water to a boil while stirring occasionally. Remove from heat and stir in alcohol (optoinal) such as dark rum. Let cool to room temperature.

Tip

This is known as a simple syrup, which is a sugar syrup made with a 1:1 ratio of sugar to water.

docs.text: • Dominique Ansel

docs.title: Sourdough Starter
docs.text: Total Time 0 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 4.5 cups (702 g) whole-wheat flour
  • 5 cups (709 g) all-purpose flour

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 container
  • 1 1 liter mason jar

docs.title: Days 1-3
docs.text: Combine whole-wheat flour and all-purpose flour and keep in container as feed. Mix 1 cup (142 g) of flour mixture and 2/3 cup (151 g) of room temperature water in a 1 liter mason jar. Cover and let set at room temperature for 48 to 72 hours.

docs.title: Days 4-10/14
docs.text: Measure 1/4 cup (2 oz) of starter and transfer and stir in 1/2 cup (2.5 oz) of flour mixture and 1/4 cup (2 oz) of room temperature water. Repeat every 24 hours. Use for baking once doubled in size during 8 to 12 hour window.

docs.title: Store & Maintain
docs.text: Combine 1/4 cup (2 oz) starter, 1/2 cup (2.5 oz) all-purpose flour, and 1/4 cup (2 oz) room temperature water and let sit for 5 hours. Refrigerate and repeat weekly.

docs.title: Prepare for Baking
docs.text: 18 to 24 hours before, combine 1/2 cup (4 oz) starter add 1 cup (5 oz) all-purpose flour and 1/2 cup (4 oz) room temperature water. Cover and sit at room temperature for 5 hours. Measure out and refrigerate for 12 to 18 hours before use.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RGO1cLw7P6c

docs.title: Stiff Sourdough Starter
docs.text: Total Time 0 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients - Flour Mixture
docs.text:
• 150 g whole wheat
  • 180 g all-purpose flour

docs.title: Ingredients - Conversion
docs.text:
• 10 g sourdough starter
  • 50 g flour mixture
  • 25 g water

docs.title: Ingredients - Maintenance
docs.text:
• 10 g sourdough starter
  • 20 g flour mixture
  • 10 g water

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Create your flour mixture by mixing 150 g of whole wheat and 180 g of all-purpose flour.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Take 10 g of your existing sourdough starter

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Feed with 50 g of flour mixture and 25 g of water

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: On the next day, take 10 g of your stiff starter, feed again with 50 g of flour and 25 g of water

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: The starter is very dry and mixing is a pain. I typically knead it on my bench

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Please repeat this for another 3 days, it takes time for your microorganisms to adapt.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Bring out the starter from the fridge and let it sit at room temperature for 8 to 12 hours.

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text: Take 10 g of your existing sourdough starter.

docs.title: Step 9
docs.text: Feed with 50 g of flour mixture and 25g of water.

docs.title: Step 10
docs.text: Let it sit at room temperature for 1 to 4 hours before returning it to the fridge.

docs.title: Step 11
docs.text: Feed once a week.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text:
• https://www.the-bread-code.io/recipe/2021/10/24/all-you-need-to-know-stiff-liquid-regular-starter.html
  • https://www.kingarthurbaking.com/recipes/a-smaller-sourdough-starter-recipe
  • https://www.kingarthurbaking.com/blog/2018/10/30/maintaining-a-smaller-sourdough-starter

docs.text: Purée 700 g (4.5 cups) fresh strawberries (hulled and cut in half) in a blender or food processor until smooth. If you prefer your jam to be seedless, strain out the purée with a fine mesh strainer.

docs.title: Streusel Crumble
docs.text: Total Time 12 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 250 g all-purpose flour
  • 250 g hazelnut flour
  • 250 g sugar
  • 6 g fleur de sel
  • 250 g butter

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 sheet pan
  • 1 parchment paper
  • 1 stand mixer

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Preheat the oven to 350°F (175°C). Line a sheet pan with parchment paper.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: In a stand mixer fitted with the paddle attachment (or in a large bowl using a spatula), combine the all-purpose flour, hazelnut flour, sugar, and fleur de sel. Add the butter and mix to combine. Using your fingers, break up the streusel dough into pieces about the size of marbles. (Alternatively, push the dough through the holes of a wire rack to get pieces of a more uniform size.)

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Spread the streusel over the prepared pan and bake until golden, 10 to 12 minutes. The edges should be crunchy and the inside still soft. Let cool completely.

docs.title: Sweetened Coconut Flakes
docs.text: Total Time 15 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 0.25 (57 g) cup water
  • 4 tsp (17 g) granulated sugar
  • 1 cup (113 g) unsweetened coconut flakes

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 small saucepan
  • 1 baking sheet
  • 1 parchment paper

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: In a small saucepan, heat the water and granulated sugar together with the heat set to medium.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Add the unsweetened coconut flakes to the water and sugar mixture. Stir the mixture with the coconut until the water is absorbed. Once the water is absorbed, remove the coconut from the heat.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text:
Add the coconut to your baking sheet lined with parchment paper and let it dry.

Note

Instead of using sugar, you can use honey or maple syrup to naturally sweeten your coconut. To do so, use four teaspoons of honey or maple syrup in place of sugar. Then, instead of using hot water, use just warm water instead to mix all the ingredients together.

docs.title: Source

docs.title: Sweetened Condensed Milk
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 1.5 cups 1.08 hours

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 2.5 cups whole milk
  • 1 cup granulated sugar
  • 0.5 cup heavy cream
  • 0.13 tsp salt

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 medium saucepan
  • 1 heatproof airtight container

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Place 2.5 cups whole milk, 1 cup granulated sugar, 1/2 cup heavy cream, and 1/8 teaspoon kosher salt in a medium saucepan. Heat over medium heat, stirring occasionally, until bubbles form along the edges of the pan, about 5 minutes. Do not let the mixture come to a boil.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Simmer, reducing the heat as needed and stirring and scraping the sides of the pan often, until thickened and reduced to 1.5 cups, 50 to 60 minutes. It should coat the back of a spoon.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Pour into a heatproof airtight container and let cool completely. Cover and refrigerate for up to 1 week or freeze for up to 3 months. Let thaw overnight in the fridge and shake or whisk well before using.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.thekitchn.com/how-to-make-sweetened-condensed-milk-recipe-23421073

docs.title: Sweetened Whipped Cream

  • 0.5 tsp vanilla (optional)

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 chilled bowl
  • 1 chilled beaters

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Beat in a chilled bowl with chilled beaters at high or medium-high speed until thickened cold heavy cream.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: If desired, add and beat to the desired consistency 2 tsp to 2 Tbsp sugar (optional), 1 to 4 Tbsp confectioners' sugar (optional), or honey (optional) and vanilla (optional).

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Use immediately.

docs.title: Toasted Nuts
docs.text: Total Time 10 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text: • some nuts

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text: • 1 sheet pan

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: For large batches of nuts, spread them on a sheet pan in a single layer and toast them in a 350°F oven for 7 to 10 minutes. Shake the pan occasionally during this time to make sure the nuts toast evenly. The nuts are done when their color has deepened and you can smell their aroma.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text:
For smaller batches, you can toast them in a dry (un-oiled) pan over medium heat. Shake the pan constantly to prevent burning, and the nuts are toasted when they’re evenly brown and have an aroma.

Note

It’s best to toast only as many nuts as you’ll be using immediately. The intense toasted flavor diminishes with time.

docs.title: Source

docs.title: Tomato Paste
docs.text: Total Time 3 hours 15 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 8 lbs roma tomatoes
  • 2 Tbsp olive oil
  • 4 bay leaf

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 food mill
  • 1 4 ounce canning jars

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Wash and chop your roma tomatoes.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: In a hot pan drizzle a little bit of olive oil. I did about a tablespoon

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Add your tomatoes and cook until soft.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Pass the soft tomatoes through a food mill.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Once you have a tomato pulp and puree, return it to the stove and add 1 bay leaf per 2 pounds of tomatoes.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Cook on medium high to big heat to reduce the tomatoes down to the above consistency. Be sure to stir and scrape down the edges and the bottom of the pot. The longer the tomatoes reduce into paste, the lower you should turn down the temperature.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Portion into 4 ounce canning jars and water bath can or freeze in ice cube trays.

docs.text: • https://www.savoringthegood.com/how-to-make-home-made-tomato-paste/

docs.title: Vanilla Bean Cream
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 2 cups 20 minutes

docs.title: Ratios
docs.text: cream  cream  vanilla bean 4 cups 908 g 2 beans 3 cups 681 g 1.5 beans 2 cups 454 g 1 bean 1 cup 227 g 1/2 bean 1/2 cup 114 g 1/4 bean

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 2 cups heavy cream
  • 1 vanilla bean

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 saucepan
  • 1 sieve

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Scrape the seeds from the vanilla bean.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Heat heavy cream and vanilla bean, with seeds, in a saucepan over very low heat until cream is just bubbling.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Remove pan from heat; steep for about 20 minutes.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Use a sieve to strain the cream and serve warm.

docs.title: Vanilla Sugar
docs.text: Total Time 5 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 2 cups granulated sugar
  • 1 vanilla bean pod

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text: • 1 food processor or blender

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Place granulated sugar in your food processor or blender. Any small chopper or even a coffee bean grinder works. (Process in batches if needed.) You can skip the food processor/blender and just mix the sugar and vanilla bean seeds in a bowl with a whisk, but you’ll get better flavor if you pulse the two together.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Cut the vanilla bean pod in half lengthwise. Use a knife to scrape out the seeds. Place the seeds on top of the sugar. (Save the empty beans/pods.) Use a spoon or another knife to scrape the seeds off the knife– they’re sticky and clumpy.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Pulse/blend/whisk until all the seeds are broken up and blended, about 10-12 pulses. If you notice extra large clumps, feel free to keep pulsing/whisking or sift them out. Pour vanilla sugar into your jar or container.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Submerge the empty bean/pod into the sugar. Cut it as needed to fit. This is actually optional, but the empty bean adds more flavor as the weeks go on. You could also use the empty beans to make vanilla extract. See written details above this recipe.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Use sugar immediately or wait at least 2 weeks for optimal flavor.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Store vanilla sugar at room temperature. Give it a shake every few weeks because it can clump up. If stored in a cool, dry place, vanilla sugar has a long shelf life, 2+ years at least. (I guarantee you’ll use it up before then!)

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-vanilla-sugar/

docs.title: Vegan Marshmallows
docs.text: Total Time 4.77 hours

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 1.5 cups aquafaba
  • 0.5 tsp cream of tartar
  • 2 tsp xanthan gum
  • 2 cups sugar
  • 2 tsp agar powder
  • 0.5 cup water
  • 1 vanilla bean
  • 1 tsp vanilla
  • 0.5 cup tapioca or potato starch

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 13 x 9-inch baking dish
  • 1 stand mixer
  • 1 medium saucepan
  • 1 kitchen shears or a very sharp knife

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Lightly grease a 13 x 9-inch baking dish and set aside.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Place 1 cup of the aquafaba and cream of tartar in your stand mixer with the whisk attachment installed and beat to stiff peaks. Slowly sift in the xanthan gum while the motor is running, until completely incorporated. Pause when the mixture is thick and fluffy. This can take about 10 to 15 minutes.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Meanwhile, combine the sugar, and agar powder in a medium saucepan with the remaining 1/2 cup of aquafaba, water, vanilla bean seeds, and vanilla extract. Stir once to moisten all the sugar and then keep your spatula out of it! Gently swirl the pan from this point forward to prevent the mixture from crystalizing. Bring to a boil and cook until it reaches 250°F.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Turn the mixer up to high speed and very carefully stream the sugar syrup in. Beat for 1 minute longer before quickly transferring the sticky fluff to your prepared baking dish. Work quickly as it will begin to set as soon as it cools.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Let rest at room temperature for 30 minutes before wrapping the whole tray in plastic and refrigerating for at least 4 hours, or ideally overnight.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: When thoroughly chilled, turn out the massive mallow onto a clean counter coated generously with tapioca or potato starch. Use kitchen shears or a very sharp knife coated with more starch to slice small cubes. Toss each once in the starch to coat, to prevent them from sticking to one another.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.worldofvegan.com/vegan-vegetarian-marshmallows

docs.title: Vegan Parmesan
docs.text: Total Time 5 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 0.75 cup raw cashew
  • 3 Tbsp nutritional yeast
  • 0.75 tsp sea salt
  • 1 dash garlic powder
  • 1 dash onion powder (optional)

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text: • 1 food processor

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Add raw cashew pieces, nutritional yeast, sea salt, garlic powder, and onion powder (optional) to a food processor. Pulse to a fine meal, stopping to scrape down the sides of the bowl as necessary. Set aside. (This recipe will yield enough "cheese" to sprinkle on salads, pasta dishes, omelettes...store the leftovers in an airtight container in the fridge and it will keep for a couple of weeks.)

docs.title: Vegan Veggie Ground Meat
docs.text: Total Time 15 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 1 head cauliflower
  • 16 oz Portobello mushrooms or jackfruit
  • 2 medium carrots
  • 1 red onion
  • 3 cloves garlic
  • 1.5 cups walnuts
  • 3 Tbsp tomato paste
  • 2 Tbsp Italian seasoning
  • 1 Tbsp paprika
  • 2 tsp sage
  • 2 tsp garlic powder
  • 1 tsp thyme
  • 1 tsp oregano
  • 2 tsp cumin

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 food processor
  • 1 pan

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Coarsely blend cauliflower, Portobello mushrooms or jackfruit, and carrots separately in a food processor. Blend red onion, and garlic together. Mushrooms can be made even coarser for a more meaty texture (This will need to be done in batches).

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Coarsely blend walnuts along with tomato paste until combined.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Add vegetables and mushrooms to pan and continue to cook on medium until water releases begins to release, about 5 minutes. Increase heat to high.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Continue to mix until most of the water has cooked out add Italian seasoning, paprika, sage, garlic powder, thyme, oregano, and cumin. Continue to cook on high for another 5 to 10 minutes, or until all the water has evaporated and no water remains at the bottom of the pan.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Turn off heat and add walnut and tomato paste mixture. Mix thoroughly to combine.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Add to your dish of choice. Enjoy!

docs.text: • https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lDuy_NqW_mQ

docs.title: Vegetable Broth
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 3.5 cups 65 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 3 Tbsp butter
  • 1 cup onion
  • 1 cup celery
  • 1 cup turnip
  • 1 cup carrot
  • 4 cups boiling water
  • some salt
  • some pepper

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text: • 1 large saucepan

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Serve strained or unstrained, hot or cold.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Melt in a large saucepan over medium heat butter.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Add and cook gently for 5 minutes 3 cups or more chopped vegetables for stock such as onion, celery, turnip, and carrot.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Do not let the vegetables brown. Add 4 cups of boiling water or a combination of boiling water and tomatoes or tomato juice.

docs.title: Step 5

docs.title: Yogurt
docs.text: Total Time 13.66 hours

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 7.5 cups ultra-pasteurized whole, 2 percent low-fat, 1 percent low-fat, or skim milk
  • 0.5 cup plain yogurt
  • 5 quarts water

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 saucepan
  • 1 1-quart Mason jars
  • 1 clean spoon

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Bring ultra-pasteurized whole, 2 percent low-fat, 1 percent low-fat, or skim milk to 115°F in saucepan over medium heat, 2 to 5 minutes. (If your milk gets hotter than 115°F, let it cool to 115°F before proceeding. Higher temperatures can kill some cultures.) Off heat, whisk plain yogurt into milk until very well combined. Divide mixture evenly between two 1-quart Mason jars (they will be very full; a funnel can be helpful for this step). Add lids, then screw on rings until just finger-tight.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Adjust oven rack to lowest position and turn on oven light. Bring 5 quarts water to boil in large covered pot. Place jars in second large pot. Add water until jars are submerged to their necks. (If jars are taller than pot, add water to 14 inches from rim of pot.) Remove jars and bring water to 120°F over medium heat. Return jars to pot of 120°F water. Transfer both pots to oven. Incubate yogurt, without opening oven door, for 5 hours.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Remove 1 jar from water bath. Using clean spoon, taste yogurt for tartness and consistency. If tarter, thicker yogurt is desired, return jar to water bath and shut oven door. (Bear in mind that yogurt will thicken significantly as it cools but can be loosened up by stirring prior to serving.) Set oven to 350°F and heat for 3 minutes (start your timer as soon as you set the dial; oven will not reach 350°F). Turn off oven and let incubate for up to 10 more hours, repeating heating step each time oven door is opened. Remove jars from water bath and refrigerate until fully cooled and set, about 8 hours. (Yogurt can be refrigerated for up to 2 weeks.)

docs.title: How to Customize
docs.text:
Making yogurt that you'll love begins with choosing a starter yogurt that you enjoy. Any variety (whole milk, Greek, Icelandic, etc.) will do the job, but keep in mind that different brands use different combinations of bacteria, and this accounts for variability in flavors ranging from buttery to cheesy to tangy to mild; textures can be firm, thin, gelatinous, ropy, or custardy. These qualities will transfer to your finished yogurt.

Then there's the milk. Any type (whole, low-fat, or skim) will work, but the more fat your milk contains, the richer your yogurt will be and the more structure it will have. And yet, the starter and milk are only the beginning Here are more ways to create a truly artisanal yogurt to suit your personal tastes.

docs.title: Richer
docs.text: Substitute 1/2 cup ultra-pasteurized heavy cream for 1/2 cup milk.

docs.title: Denser
docs.text: Whisk 1/4 cup nonfat dry milk powder into cold milk before heating it.

docs.title: Strained
docs.text: Place triple layer of cheesecloth over mouth of jar with chilled yogurt, screw on lid ring, and drain in refrigerator upside down in 2-cup measuring cup overnight.

docs.title: Extract
docs.text: Stir 1/4 tea spoon extract (we like vanilla or almond) into milk along with starter.

docs.title: Sweetener
docs.text: Garnish individual servings with white or brown sugar, honey, maple syrup, or fruit jam.

docs.title: Control Sourness & Thickness
docs.text: Adjust the incubation time to produce the effect you desire: The longer yogurt ferments, the more lactic acid is produced, and the more sour and thick it becomes. Chilling stops fermentation and allows the gel to set fully (it will loosen when stirred or served).

docs.title: Mild & Thin
docs.text: Incubate for 5 hours.

docs.title: Tart & Thick
docs.text:
Incubate for up to 15 hours.

Note

Extra-tart yogurt is great for making frozen yogurt

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • Cook's Illustrated

docs.title: 3-Ingredient Garlic Butter
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 1 cup 5 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 1 cup butter
  • 2 Tbsp parsley
  • 2 cloves garlic

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text: • 1 electric mixer

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Place the softened butter, parsley, and garlic into a bowl.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Mix all of the ingredients using an electric mixer until they're fully combined.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Enjoy your garlic butter on any number of dishes. Store refrigerated in an airtight container.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.tastingtable.com/880451/3-ingredient-garlic-butter-recipe/

docs.title: Almond Butter
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 16 oz 20 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 16 oz almonds
  • 0.25 tsp salt
  • 0.25 tsp cinnamon (optional)
  • 0.5 tsp vanilla (optional)
  • 2 Tbsp maple syrup or honey (optional)

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 large, rimmed baking sheet
  • 1 high-speed blender or food processor

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Preheat the oven to 350°F. Spread the almonds across a large, rimmed baking sheet and toast the almonds for 10 minutes, stirring halfway.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Let the almonds cool until they’re just warm (not hot), about 10 minutes.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Transfer the almonds to a high-speed blender or food processor. Blend until creamy, pausing to scrape down the sides as necessary. You’re going to think it’ll never blend, but be patient! The almonds will go from flour-like clumps, to a ball against the side of the food processor (keep scraping down the sides and breaking up the ball), and finally, it will turn lusciously creamy. If the mixture gets crazy hot along the way, stop and let it cool for a few minutes.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Once the almond butter is very smooth and creamy (no sooner!), you can blend in any add-ins you would like. I always add salt, for more flavor overall. You can also add cinnamon (optional) for a hint of spice, and vanilla (optional) and/or maple syrup or honey (optional) for almond butter that tastes more special than store-bought.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Blend until the add-ins are evenly dispersed. When I added maple syrup, I had to let the mixture cool, and then blend a few additional minutes, to make it creamy again.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Let the almond butter cool to room temperature, then transfer the mixture to a mason jar and screw on the lid. Store in the refrigerator for up to 2 weeks, or until you see or smell any signs of spoilage.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://cookieandkate.com/homemade-almond-butter-recipe/

docs.title: Brown Butter with Sage
docs.text: Total Time 5 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 2 Tbsp unsalted butter
  • 30 leaves fresh sage

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text: • 1 skillet or saucepan

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Place unsalted butter in a skillet or saucepan large enough to hold the cooked pasta; turn heat to medium, and add fresh sage. Cook until butter turns nut-brown and sage shrivels, then turn heat to a minimum.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://cooking.nytimes.com/recipes/5704-pasta-with-butter-sage-and-parmesan

docs.title: Butter
docs.text: Total Time 10 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 1 qt 40 percent heavy whipping cream
  • some iced water

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 stand mixer
  • 1 fine mesh bag or cheesecloth or face towel

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Add 40 percent heavy whipping cream to bowl of stand mixer fitted with the whisk attachment.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Turn mixer on to level 4 or 5 and mix until you get whipped cream.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: As the cream gets thicker, increase the mixer speed.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: The cream should separate from the milk. The milk is buttermilk.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: When the cream gets lumpy and starts to turn yellow, keep whipping until the buttermilk separates from the cream.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Scrape the butter off the walls of the bowl and out of the mixer blades and smush it all together.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Add the butter to a fine mesh bag or cheesecloth or face towel. Rinse the butter in iced water because if you don't rinse the buttermilk off of the butter, the butter will spoil quickly.

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text: Shape the butter and store it in a container in the fridge.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://chefjeanpierre.com/recipes/how-to-make-butter/

docs.title: Chili Lime Butter
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 6 30 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 1 lime
  • 2 Tbsp unsalted butter
  • 0.25 cup mayonnaise
  • 0.5 cup cotija cheese
  • 0.75 tsp chipotle powder
  • 0.25 tsp salt
  • 0.25 bunch cilantro
  • 0.25 tsp paprika

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text: • 1 mixing bowl

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Combine lime juice with lime zest.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Whisk the unsalted butter and mayonnaise together in a mixing bowl until smooth.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Add the lime juice mixture, cotija cheese, chipotle powder, salt, cilantro, and paprika to the butter and mayonnaise. Mix well.

docs.title: Clarified Butter
docs.text: Total Time 0 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text: • 2 sticks unsalted butter

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 heavy-bottomed saucepan
  • 1 ladle
  • 1 bowl

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Begin With Unsalted Butter. To begin, gently melt a stick or two of unsalted butter in a heavy-bottomed saucepan over low heat.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Let the Milk Solids Separate. As the butter melts, you'll see a layer of foam rising to the surface. The bubbles are the butter's water content boiling off and the white residue is the milk proteins separating out from the butterfat and water.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: If you've ever cooked milk too long and had it curdle, it's the same thing. Curdling happens when the milk solids break away from the emulsion, either because of heat or the introduction of an acidic ingredient like lemon juice.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Skim the Foam and Milk Solids. As the butter continues to simmer, use a ladle to skim the foam and milk proteins from the surface of the liquefied butter. Note the clear, golden liquid underneath the foamy residue. This is different from the technique for making ghee, in which the milk solids are allowed to settle to the bottom and turn slightly brown. That adds a nutty flavor to the ghee, which isn't bad, but it's not what you want for clarified butter.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Set Aside the Milk Solids. Keep a separate bowl for the buttery, foamy milk solids that are skimmed off because it can be used to coat other foods. (For one thing, it's fantastic on popcorn.) It can also be added to mashed potatoes or served overcooked vegetables and fish, even pancakes, waffles, and the like.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Continue Skimming and Simmering. In a few minutes, most of the milk solids will have been skimmed off, leaving just the pure, yellow butterfat.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Another use for clarified butter is making sauces, especially butter-based emulsified sauces like Hollandaise and béarnaise. The water in ordinary butter can destabilize the emulsion and cause it to break. Since its water content has been removed, clarified butter eliminates this problem.

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text: Remove Clarified Butter From Heat. Clarified butter doesn't spoil as easily as ordinary butter, so it can be kept for quite a long time. While it can be stored at room temperature, a cool place is best, so definitely don't keep it right next to the stove. For best results, store it in an opaque container with a tight-fitting lid, since prolonged exposure to light and oxygen can cause fats to become rancid.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text:
• https://www.thespruceeats.com/how-to-make-clarified-butter-995451
  • https://youtu.be/C8ReU5s4i0k?si=yGh4r-SH6qFCDUcX

docs.title: Garlic-Parsley Basting Butter
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 4 10 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 4 Tbsp unsalted butter
  • 1 Tbsp Worcestershire
  • 1 Tbsp parsley
  • 1 tsp garlic
  • 0.5 tsp pepper

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text: • 1 small saucepan

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Melt unsalted butter in small saucepan over medium heat. Add Worcestershire, parsley, minced garlic, and pepper and cook, stirring frequently, until mixture is simmering and fragrant, 1 to 2 minutes. Remove from heat. Cover to keep warm until ready to use.

docs.title: Source

docs.title: Ghee
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 2 lbs 40 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text: • 2 lb unsalted butter

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 large pot or saucepan
  • 1 spoon or ladle
  • 1 sieve or strainer
  • 1 glass container
  • 1 cheesecloth or a clean dish towel

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Take your 2 pounds of unsalted butter and put it into a large pot or saucepan. Set your stove to medium heat and allow the butter to melt completely.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Once the butter has melted, increase the heat slightly until it comes to a rolling boil. Make sure to stir occasionally during this process to prevent any burning or sticking to the bottom of the pan.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: After reaching a rolling boil, reduce the heat slightly so that the mixture continues to simmer. The simmering butter should foam, and water will start evaporating. This process will take about 10 to 15 minutes.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Keep an eye on the mixture and stir it occasionally. Do not leave it unattended.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: After 10 to 15 minutes, you will notice the butter developing a large amount of foam on top and you might see some brown spots - these are the milk solids starting to caramelize.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Turn off the heat and let the mixture settle for about 10 minutes. The milk solids will fall to the bottom of the pan and continue to caramelize, which gives ghee its characteristic nutty flavor.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: After the mixture has settled, gently skim off the remaining foam from the top of the butter using a spoon or ladle. Be careful not to disturb the milk solids at the bottom.

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text: Set a sieve or strainer over a clean glass container, and line it with a cheesecloth or a clean dish towel.

docs.title: Step 9
docs.text: Slowly pour the butter into the lined strainer. Be careful not to let the browned milk solids from the bottom of the pan pour into the strainer. Only the liquid should pass through.

docs.title: Step 10
docs.text: Allow the ghee to cool down, then put the lid on your glass container. You can store ghee at room temperature for up to six months, or in the fridge for up to a year.

docs.title: Step 11
docs.text: And there you have it, your ghee is done! Your homemade ghee is now ready to use in your favorite recipes! Enjoy the nutty flavor it brings to your dishes. Remember, unlike salted butter, ghee is, in essence, butter oil more like a cooking oil, and doesn't need added salt. You can control the salt levels in your cooking separately.

docs.title: Source
docs.text:
• https://chefjeanpierre.com/recipes/how-to-make-ghee/

docs.title: Ginger-Miso Basting Butter
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 4 10 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:

  • 1 Tbsp white miso
  • 1 Tbsp soy sauce

  • 0.5 tsp pepper

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text: • 1 small saucepan

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Melt unsalted butter in small saucepan over medium heat. Add white miso, soy sauce, grated fresh ginger, and pepper and cook, stirring frequently, until mixture is simmering and fragrant, 1 to 2 minutes. Remove from heat. Cover to keep warm until ready to use.

docs.title: Ratio
docs.text: butter  oil  Salt 3 parts 2 parts 0.5%  Serves  Total Time 45 2.03 hours

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 227 g unsalted butter
  • 150 g olive or canola oil
  • 0.25 tsp salt

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text: • 1 food processor

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Let the unsalted butter slowly come to room temperature. To speed this process, cut the butter into small chunks and separate them from each other. Do not try to speed things up in the microwave, even at half power... you’ll change the texture of the butter.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Place the room temperature butter into a food processor along with the olive or canola oil and salt.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Process the butter, oil and salt for 1 to 2 minutes, scraping the sides of the processor periodically, till all lumps have disappeared and the mixture is smooth and soft. It will be quite liquid, but don't worry, it will firm up in the fridge.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Pour the softened butter into a container that can be sealed airtight (like a Tupperware). Refrigerate for 1 to 2 hours till fully chilled and firm.

docs.title: Dry Caramel
docs.text: Total Time 20 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 1 tsp vanilla
  • 200 ml heavy cream
  • 300 g granulated sugar
  • 100 g unsalted butter

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 sugar thermometer
  • 1 large heavy bottom saucepan
  • 1 wooden spoon
  • 1 heat proof large bowl

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Add vanilla to heavy cream so that it is ready to go.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Use a sugar thermometer to monitor the temperature.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Put granulated sugar in large heavy bottom saucepan over medium heat.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text:
Use a wooden spoon to draw outside edges into the middle so that it heats more evenly.

Warning

Don't put cold thermometer in very hot sugar to avoid damaging the thermometer.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Wait until the mixture boils to a lovely amber color and then take pan off of the heat.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Stir in vanilla and cream mixture a little bit at a time.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Add more a little bit a time, like tempering chocolate.

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text: Once cream has been incorporated, stir in the unsalted butter.

docs.title: Step 9
docs.text: Put back onto medium heat and wait until the temperature reaches 118°C (245°F).

docs.title: Step 10
docs.text: Keep stirring so that oils don't separate from the cream.

docs.title: Step 11
docs.text: Pour into nice heat proof large bowl to let it cool.

docs.title: Step 12
docs.text: Use while quite warm so that it doesn't seize up.

docs.title: Step 13
docs.text: Use it in tray bakes.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ihHytr6MTro

docs.title: Hard Caramel
docs.text: Total Time 30 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 225 g granulated sugar
  • 60 ml water
  • 15 g unsalted butter
  • 60 g toasted pecans

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 silicone spatula
  • 1 large heavy bottom saucepan
  • 1 silicone brush
  • 1 silicone mat

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Grease silicone spatula so that the caramel doesn't stick to it.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text:
Put granulated sugar and water in large heavy bottom saucepan and put on medium heat.

Warning

Do not stir so that the mixture doesn't crystallize. If it does, just keep on medium-low heat.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text:
If a bit of crystallization around the edge of the pan, take a silicone brush and dip in water and wipe away.

Note

Can keep a lid on the pot to trap the steam to prevent crystallization.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Add unsalted butter once the caramel mixture turns to a nice dark rich amber color.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Add nuts and seeds such as toasted pecans to the mixture

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Pour onto silicone mat to let it cool for 10 to 15 minutes until it is snapable.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text:
Use it for brittles and sugar shards.

How to clean utensils

Add water and utensils, including thermometer, to pan and bring to a boil and then clean.

How to clean counter tops

Put damp cloth over caramel on countertops for a half an hour or so and then clean.

docs.title: Wet Caramel
docs.text: Total Time 30 minutes

docs.title: Ratio
docs.text: Sugar  Cream 1 part 1 part

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 1 tsp vanilla
  • 245 ml heavy cream
  • 220 g granulated sugar
  • 120 ml water

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 large heavy bottom saucepan
  • 1 silicone brush
  • 1 heat proof large bowl

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Add vanilla to heavy cream so that it is ready to go.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text:
Put granulated sugar and water in large heavy bottom saucepan and put on medium heat.

Warning

Do not stir so that the mixture doesn't crystallize. If it does, just keep on medium-low heat.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text:
If a bit of crystallization around the edge of the pan, take a silicone brush and dip in water and wipe away.

Note

Can keep a lid on the pot to trap the steam to prevent crystallization.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Take pan off of heat once the caramel mixture turns to a nice amber color.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Stir in vanilla and cream mixture a little bit at a time to avoid splattering. Add more a little bit a time, like tempering chocolate.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Pour into nice heat proof large bowl to let it cool.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text:
Use it to drizzle or to flavor butter cream.

Warning

Don't put caramel hot into the fridge to cool it down because it is going to bring the temperature of the fridge up and put other food in the danger zone.

docs.title: Almond Extract
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 2 oz 5-6 weeks

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 10 raw, unsalted almonds
  • 2 oz vodka or bourbon

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text: • 1 2-fl. oz glass jar

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: To skin the almonds you first blanch them. This means plunging them into boiling water for one minute exactly. Wash under cold running water until they are quite cold, then squeeze the nut out of the skin, or rub it off in a clean tea cloth.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Chop your raw, unsalted almonds small enough to fit in your 2-fl. oz glass jar.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text:
Place chopped almonds into your jar.

Note

For the almond extract, it is probably best to use, or re-use, a larger jar. Then as few as 8 almonds, which have been skinned, chopped and covered with the vodka or bourbon or glycerin in a small jar if using. I would use a larger jar and a handful of almonds, as many as you like. Cover the chopped almonds to about one inch over the ingredients and proceed. Then, when it is ready, you can strain it into smaller bottles and proceed to use the same almonds for a second batch.

docs.title: Lemon Extract
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 2 oz 5-6 weeks

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 1 lemon
  • 2 oz vodka

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text: • 1 2-fl. oz glass bottle

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Peel thin strips of zest from your lemon.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Place zest into your 2-fl. oz glass bottle.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Add vodka, filling up to the neck of the bottle.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Every few days, tilt your bottle upside down to gently mix the liquid inside.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: After 5-6 weeks, you have extract!

docs.title: Mint Extract
docs.text: Total Time 5-6 weeks

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 0.5 cup mint leaves
  • 2 oz vodka

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 2-fl. oz glass bottle
  • 1 chopstick, skewer, or other poking device

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Stuff mint leaves into your 2-fl. oz glass bottle.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Using a chopstick, skewer, or other poking device, lightly bruise/crush the leaves inside the bottle.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Add vodka, filling up to the neck of the bottle.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Every few days, tilt your bottle upside down to gently mix the liquid inside.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: After 5-6 weeks, you have extract! (I’m not sure if, like vanilla extract, you can just leave the mint leaves inside. Since it’s leafy plant matter which disintegrates more easily, it may be a good idea to take it out. My leaves went from a vibrant green in the beginning to kind of a dull brown by the end so I took them out just to be safe – I poured my mint extract into another container through a sieve and discarded the mint leaves, then poured the filtered extract back into the bottle.)

• 1 large navel orange
  • 2 oz vodka

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text: • 1 2-fl. oz glass bottle

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Peel thin strips of zest from 1/2 of your navel orange.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Place zest into your 2-fl. oz glass bottle.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Add vodka, filling up to the neck of the bottle.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Every few days, tilt your bottle upside down to gently mix the liquid inside.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: After 5-6 weeks, you have extract! (I think with citrus peels the acid (and alcohol bath), it’s probably safe to leave the peels inside the bottle like a vanilla bean for re-fill purposes. If you don’t feel comfortable doing this, take it out!)

docs.title: Vanilla Extract
docs.text: Total Time 5-6 weeks

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 3 vanilla beans
  • 2 oz vodka or bourbon

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text: • 1 2-fl. oz glass bottle

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Cut your vanilla beans in half, then split open each half to expose the vanilla seeds on the inside of the pod.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Place cut vanilla beans inside your 2-fl. oz glass bottle.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Add vodka or bourbon, filling up to the neck of the bottle.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Seal tightly and store bottle in a cool, dry place.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Every few days, tilt your bottle upside down to gently mix the liquid inside.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: After 5-6 weeks, you have extract! (If you leave in your vanilla beans, when you start running low, just add more vodka and wait a little.)

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Note: As a guide you use 1 cup/8 ozs of vodka to 4 - 6 vanilla beans, depending on the quality of the beans.

docs.title: Mousse
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 8 inch cake 30 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 2 each gelatin sheets
  • 312 g whole milk
  • 308 g 70 percent dark chocolate
  • 448 g heavy cream

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 bowl of ice water
  • 1 small pot
  • 1 whisk
  • 1 medium heatproof bowl
  • 1 spatula
  • 1 hand blender
  • 1 stand mixer
  • 1 large rubber spatula
  • 1 plastic wrap

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text:
Soak the gelatin sheets in a bowl of ice water until soft, about 20 minutes. (If using powdered gelatin, sprinkle 2 tsp (6g) gelatin over 6 tsp (30g) water in a small bowl, stir, and let sit for 20 minutes to bloom.)

Tip

Whether using sheet or powdered gelatin, you must use cold water since warm or hot water will immediately dissolve the gelatin and you will not be able to work with it.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: In a small pot, bring the whole milk to a boil over medium heat, stirring occasionally with a whisk. Remove from heat.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Place the 70 percent dark chocolate in a medium heatproof bowl. Pour half of the hot milk over the chocolate and let it stand for 30 seconds. Stir gently with a spatula until the milk has melted the chocolate. Once melted, pour in the remaining milk, and stir to combine.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Switch to a hand blender and emulsify the ganache until smooth, glossy, and free of any lumps.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Squeeze out any excess water from your bloomed gelatin sheets. Whisk the bloomed gelatin into the hot ganache until the gelatin has dissolved. When finished, the ganache should have the consistency of mayonnaise. Let cool to 90 to 95°F (32 to 35°C).

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text:
In a stand mixer fitted with a whisk attachment, whip the heavy cream until it forms medium-stiff peaks.

Tip

At room temperature, the ganache will remain smooth but won’t melt the whipped cream.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Using a large rubber spatula, slowly pour the ganache into the whipped cream as you constantly fold until fully incorporated. Be careful not to overmix, so as not to deflate the airy texture of the mousse.

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text:
Cover the mousse with plastic wrap pressed directly on the surface, to prevent a skin from forming. Refrigerate for at least 12 hours to set.

Variation

To make a silky hazelnut dark chocolate mousse, start with the dark chocolate mousse recipe, and add in 100 g (1/3 cup) store-bought hazelnut paste as you warm up your milk. You can purchase hazelnut paste online.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • Dominique Ansel

docs.title: American Buttercream
docs.text: Total Time 19 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 150 g soft unsalted butter
  • 340 g confectioners' sugar
  • 4 Tbsp whole milk

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text: • 1 stand mixer

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Add soft unsalted butter to a stand mixer and beat until nice and pale, about 5 minutes.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Sift confectioners' sugar and add to butter in two stages, beating for about 3 to 5 minutes between each addition. Make sure the mixer is started at a low speed so that the sugar doesn't go everywhere.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Turn up speed to medium-high and beat until the buttercream is nice and smooth and pale, about 3 to 5 minutes.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Add vanilla to milk/liquid if needed.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Add 3 to 4 Tbsp of whole milk and beat for 3 to 4 minutes. Other flavors may be added at this point.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: The consistency should by spreadable and soft. Add more liquid as desired.

docs.title: Brown Butter Cream Cheese Frosting
docs.text: Total Time 10 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
Layers 3 Tiers
  • 227 g unsalted butter
  • 16 oz cream cheese
  • 1 vanilla bean
  • 1 pinch kosher salt
  • 1 lb confectioners' sugar
Layers 2 Tiers
  • 151 g unsalted butter
  • 8 oz cream cheese
  • 0.5 vanilla bean
  • 1 pinch kosher salt
  • 227 g confectioners' sugar

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text: • 1 stand mixer

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Brown the unsalted butter and add to the bowl of a stand mixer.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Solidify the brown butter submerging the stand mixer bowl into an ice bath until opaque but not hardened and still soft.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Add room temperature cream cheese to mixer bowl and mix on medium speed until smooth.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Add vanilla bean to mixer bowl.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Add a generous pinch of kosher salt and confectioners' sugar to bowl

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Pulse mixer to combine everything with towel over mixer to prevent spillage.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text:
Beat mixture until combined.

Note

If the frosting is loose and won't hold it's shape, which can be confirmed by checking for a soft peak, refrigerate for 10 minutes while stirring the frosting every few minutes.

docs.title: Chocolate Ganache Glaze or Frosting
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 1.5 cups 10 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 0.75 cup heavy cream
  • 8 oz semisweet or bittersweet chocolate
  • 1 Tbsp liqueur (optional)

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text: • 1 small saucepan

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Bring to a boil in a small saucepan 3/4 cup heavy cream.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Remove from the heat and add finely chopped semisweet or bittersweet chocolate.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Stir until most of the chocolate is melted. Cover and let stand for 10 minutes, then stir or whisk very gently until completely smooth. Stir in liqueur (optional).

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: For a pourable glaze, let stand at room temperature, stirring occasionally, until the ganache cools to about 85°F. For frosting, let stand until spreadable. If the ganache becomes too stiff, set the pan in a larger pan of hot water and stir until softened; or remelt and cool to 85°F to 95°F for use as a glaze.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: This keeps for up to 3 days at room temperature or up to 1 week refrigerated.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • Joy of Cooking

docs.title: Classic Vanilla Buttercream Frosting
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 12 10 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 1 cup butter
  • 3 cups confectioners' sugar
  • 1 Tbsp milk or cream
  • 1 tsp vanilla
  • 1 pinch salt

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Beat the butter at high speed for about 90 seconds or until light and glossy.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Add half of the confectioners' sugar and beat in for about 30 seconds.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Add the remaining sugar and beat for another 30 seconds.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Add the milk or cream, vanilla, and salt to the frosting and beat for another 60 seconds until thick and creamy.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: The batch of frosting will cover 12 cupcakes, 24 miniature cupcakes, or an 11 X 13 inch cake.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.tastingtable.com/911810/classic-vanilla-buttercream-frosting-recipe/

docs.title: Craquelin
docs.text: Total Time 60 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 210 g unsalted butter
  • 250 g light brown sugar
  • 250 g all-purpose flour
  • 1 pinch salt

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 stand mixer
  • 1 parchment paper
  • 1 rolling pin

docs.title: Step 1
