docs.text: In a stand mixer, cream together soft unsalted butter and light brown sugar.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Once the mixture has been creamed, add all-purpose flour and salt. Turn on mixture on low speed until the mixture is nice and crumbly.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Knead the dough into a bowl inside of the mixer bowl.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Take half of the dough and sandwich it between two sheets of parchment paper.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Using a rolling pin, roll the dough until it is 2 mm (0.08 inches) thick.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Chill in a freezer for at least 1 hour.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • Cupcake Jemma

docs.title: Cream Cheese Frosting
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 2 cups 0 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients - Food Processor Method
docs.text:
• 8 oz cold cream cheese
  • 6 Tbsp unsalted butter, softened
  • 2 tsp vanilla
  • 3 cups confectioners' sugar, sifted
  • some lemon zest (optional)
  • some orange zest (optional)
  • some cinnamon (optional)
  • some liqueur (optional)

docs.title: Ingredients - Electric Mixer Method
docs.text:
• 8 oz cold cream cheese
  • 5 Tbsp unsalted butter, softened
  • 2 tsp vanilla
  • 4 cups confectioners' sugar, sifted
  • some lemon zest (optional)
  • some orange zest (optional)
  • some cinnamon (optional)
  • some liqueur (optional)

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 food processor
  • 1 medium bowl

Info

There are two secrets to making perfectly smooth cream cheese frosting with enough body to swirl on a cake or pipe through a pastry bag: Do not overbeat, and use cold - not softened - cream cheese. Have the butter, if using it, at room temperature, and sift the confectioners' sugar after measuring.

Info

Feel free to vary the amount of confectioners' sugar to suit your taste: we have seen recipes with as little as 1 tsp and as much as 1/2 cup sugar per once of cream cheese.

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Combine in a food processor and pulse just until smooth and creamy cold cream cheese, unsalted butter, softened, vanilla, and confectioners' sugar, sifted.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: If the frosting is too stiff, pulse for a few seconds longer, do not overprocess. If desired, stir in additional flavorings to taste such as lemon zest (optional), orange zest (optional), cinnamon (optional), or liqueur (optional).

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Beat in a medium bowl at low speed just until blended cold cream cheese, unsalted butter, softened, and vanilla.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Add one-third at a time and beat just until smooth and the desired consistency confectioners' sugar, sifted.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: If the frosting is too stiff, beat for a few seconds longer; do not overbeat. If desired, stir in additional flavorings to taste such as lemon zest (optional), orange zest (optional), cinnamon (optional), or liqueur (optional).

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • Joy of Cooking

docs.title: Danette's Kosher Marshmallow Creme Fondant (DKF)
docs.text: Total Time 10 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 2 cups confectioners' sugar
  • some vegetable shortening
  • 1 7-oz jar Jet-Puffed Marshmallow Creme
  • 1 Wilton white fondant
  • some white food coloring (optional)

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 large bowl
  • 1 large spoon

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Get a large bowl and place some of your 2 lb bag confectioners' sugar in it (about 2 cups). Take a large spoon and lather that thing up with vegetable shortening. It will make your life a whole lot easier getting all the fluff out of the jar. Place all the fluff (Jet-Puffed Marshmallow Creme) on top of the confectioners' sugar in the bowl.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Add some more sugar on top of the fluff. There are roughly about 8 cups of sugar in a 2 lb bag. I never use all the sugar. There is usually a cup and a half or sometimes two cups left over by the time I finish. So for now leave at least that much and use your best judgment in the end for how much more you feel you need to add.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: This is the point where you need to lather your hands up well in shortening. The best and most effective way I have found is to fold the sugar into the fluff. Over and over again until your ball starts to form. Work as much of the sugar into the fluff as you can. Once you get close you may want to turn your fondant out onto the table for and easier work surface.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Now your fondant should be kneaded into a fairly smooth ball.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Take your Wilton white fondant and you will knead them both together.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Optional step here, but highly recommended, once your fondant is completely kneaded together get your white food coloring (optional) and add a few drops. Knead until your fondant is white add more drops as necessary.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: If at this point your fondant feels sticky or too soft add some remaining powdered sugar until you reach the consistency you desire. If the fondant is too soft for your liking then add one teaspoon of tylose. More than this is not so great for cake coverage. This can be used to cover cakes immediately. If you are going to use this for modeling then you can add up to two teaspoons. For modeling please let it set overnight and allow the tylose to mature.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • The Short Cakes

docs.title: Dominique Ansel's Chocolate Ganache
docs.text: Total Time 15 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 220 g heavy cream
  • 45 g whole milk
  • 220 g 66 percent cocoa chocolate
  • 45 g unsalted butter

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 small saucepan
  • 1 large bowl

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Combine the heavy cream and the whole milk in a small saucepan and bring to a boil over medium heat. Remove from the heat.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Place the 66 percent cocoa chocolate in a large bowl. Slowly pour the hot cream mixture over the chocolate in two additions and stir until the chocolate has melted and the mixture is smooth. You’re mixing to melt the chocolate here, not to incorporate air, so stop mixing when all the chocolate has melted.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text:
Add the unsalted butter and stir until fully incorporated. Let cool completely. Adding butter softens the ganache and makes it smoother.

Best For:

  1. Filling tarts and light cakes—this is a rich filling, so I usually recommend a thin slice of chocolate ganache tart.
  2. Glazing (i.e., finishing) mousse cakes when the ganache is still warm and liquid.
  3. Truffles ganache rolled and finished with unsweetened cocoa powder.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fsYvgNcii7c

docs.title: French Buttercream
docs.text: Total Time 20 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 8 large egg yolks
  • 160 g granulated sugar
  • 5 Tbsp cold water
  • 380 g soft unsalted butter

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 stand mixer
  • 1 large heavy saucepan
  • 1 candy thermometer

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Add egg yolks to a stand mixer and whisk on high until nice and pale and fluffy. Consistency should be super thick and glossy and shiny.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Make sugar syrup by adding granulated sugar and cold water to a large heavy saucepan and give the pan a swirl so that that are no bits of sugar around the edge of the pan and turn on medium-high heat.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Use a candy thermometer to monitor the temperature until it gets to 237°F (114°C).

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Set the mixer to high-medium speed and pour in the sugar syrup on the inside wall of the bowl in a small steady stream, being careful not to have the syrup make contact with the whisk.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Set mixer to highest speed.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Whip for 5 minutes until the mixture is nice and cool. This is referred to as a pâte à bombe.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text:
Mix soft unsalted butter a little bit at a time to the mixer while on slow speed. Turn up speed until incorporated. Repeat until all butter has been used.

Note

Salt and vanilla may be added later to add flavor.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HGncBDkbzwU

docs.title: Marzipan
docs.text: Total Time 20 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 300 g ground almonds
  • 100 g granulated sugar
  • 350 g confectioners' sugar
  • 2 drops almond essence (optional)
  • 2 egg white

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text: • 1 food processor

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Put ground almonds, granulated sugar, confectioners' sugar, and almond essence (optional) into a food processor and pulse until the mixture comes together into a fine powder. Gently add the egg white and whiz the whole lot together until it comes together.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Dust a work surface with some icing sugar, then tip the marzipan dough out. Gently bring it together with your hands until it makes a smooth dough. You don’t want it to be sticky at this point, so you may need to add more icing sugar.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Then simply roll the marzipan out; ready to cover your cake.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • Delish UK

docs.title: Mom's Buttercream Frosting
docs.text: Total Time 5 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 1 lb confectioner's sugar
  • 0.33 cup soft butter
  • 0.25 cup milk
  • 0.25 tsp salt
  • 1 tsp vanilla

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 large bowl
  • 1 electric mixer

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: In a large bowl, with electric mixer at low speed, combine confectioner's sugar, soft butter, milk, salt, and vanilla.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Beat at medium speed 1 to 2 minutes, until creamy. If desired, add more milk until frosting is spreading consistency.

docs.title: Chocolate
docs.text: Add 1/4 cup unsweetened cocoa powder, beat an extra minute.

docs.title: Lemon Frosting
docs.text: Replace milk with 1/4 cup lemon juice, add 1 tsp lemon zest.

docs.title: Orange Frosting
docs.text: Replace milk with 1/4 cup orange juice. Add 1 tsp orange zest.

docs.title: Sour Cream
docs.text: Add 3 Tbsp sour cream, beat an extra minute.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • Mom Patricia Farmer

docs.title: Peanut Butter Frosting
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 2 cups 10 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 0.5 cup smooth peanut butter
  • 3 oz cold cream cheese
  • 1.5 Tbsp unsalted butter, softened
  • 1 tsp vanilla
  • 3 Tbsp cream or milk
  • 2 Tbsp bourbon or rum (optional)
  • 2.66 cups confectioners' sugar, sifted
  • 2 Tbsp cream, milk, or liquor or as needed

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text: • 1 medium bowl

docs.title: Instructions
docs.text:
Note

Stir in chopped peanuts to taste, or sprinkle them over the finished cake, if desired. Try this as a filling for any cake frosted or glazed with chocolate. Have the cream cheese cold. The butter can be cold, but it's better to have it at room temperature.

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Beat in a medium bowl just until blended smooth peanut butter, cold cream cheese, unsalted butter, softened, vanilla, cream or milk, and bourbon or rum (optional).

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Add one-third at a time and beat just until smooth and the desired consistency is reached confectioners' sugar, sifted.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: If the frosting is too stiff, add, but do not overbeat cream, milk, or liquor or as needed.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • Joy of Cooking

docs.title: Peppermint Buttercream Frosting
docs.text: Total Time 7 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 0.5 cup unsalted butter
  • 2 cups confectioners' sugar
  • 1 Tbsp heavy cream
  • 0.5 tsp peppermint extract

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Beat 1/2 cup (1 stick) softened unsalted butter for 2 minutes on medium.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: beat in 1/2 cup confectioners' sugar.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Beat in 1 Tbsp heavy cream and 1/2 tsp peppermint extract.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Gradually beat in 1.5 cups additional confectioners' sugar.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Beat 5 minutes, scraping bowl occasionally.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • Magnolia

docs.title: Sour Cream Topping
docs.text: Total Time 10 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 2 16-oz containers sour cream
  • 1 Tbsp granulated sugar
  • 2 tsp vanilla

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text: • 1 medium bowl

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: In a medium bowl, stir together sour cream, granulated sugar, and vanilla.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Place topping in the center of cheesecake, and spread gently to the edges. Return to 350°F oven for 10 minutes.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.marthastewart.com/350089/cheesecake-cupcakes-sour-cream-topping

docs.title: Swiss Buttercream
docs.text: Total Time 10 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 4 large egg whites
  • 300 g granulated sugar
  • 400 g soft unsalted butter, cubed
  • 1 tsp vanilla

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 double boiler or bain-marie
  • 1 whisk
  • 1 stand mixer

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Add egg whites and granulated sugar to a double boiler or bain-marie on low heat and whisk until all sugar is dissolved. Check by rubbing the mixture between your fingers.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Whisk in stand mixer on medium high speed for about 10 minutes until the mixture is completely cooled and fluffy.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Add soft unsalted butter, cubed to mixer on medium speed one cube at a time. Do not rush this step.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Add 1 tsp of vanilla.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=D53Hf_WNJqc

docs.title: Vegan Strawberry Frosting
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 16 15 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 0.5 cup fresh strawberries (80 g)
  • 0.33 cup vegan butter
  • 4 cup confectioners' sugar

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 large mixing bowl
  • 1 electric hand mixer

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Make strawberry purée by blending fresh strawberries (80 g) until smooth.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Add softened vegan butter to a large mixing bowl and use an electric hand mixer to beat until fluffy — about 1 minute.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Add 1/4 cup strawberry purée and beat again until fully incorporated, scraping down the sides as needed.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Begin adding sifted confectioners' sugar 1/4 cup (28 g) at a time (sifting reduces clumps). Mix on low speed until each 1/4 cup is well incorporated and thick yet spreadable. We found that 3.5 cups (392 g) was the sweet spot (literally)!

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Spread frosting on a fully cooled strawberry, vanilla, or chocolate cake and enjoy! Use immediately or store frosting in the refrigerator up to 5 days or in the freezer up to 1 month.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://minimalistbaker.com/vegan-strawberry-frosting

docs.title: White Chocolate Frosting
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 3 cups 5 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 6 oz white chocolate
  • 1 8-oz pkg cream cheese
  • 4 Tbsp unsalted butter
  • 1 tsp vanilla
  • 2.5 cups confectioners' sugar

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 small saucepan
  • 1 large mixing bowl
  • 1 electric mixer

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Place the white chocolate in a small saucepan and melt over low heat, about 4 minutes. Remove the pan from the heat and let the chocolate cool.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Place the room temperature cream cheese and room temperature unsalted butter in a large mixing bowl. Beat with an electric mixer on low speed until well combined, about 30 seconds. Stop the machine. Add the melted white chocolate and blend on low for 30 seconds. Add the vanilla and confectioners' sugar and blend on low speed for 30 seconds more. Increase the mixer speed to medium and beat until the frosting is fluffy, about 1 minute.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Use to frost the top and sides of the cake of your choice. Refrigerate the frosted cake until serving time.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • The Cake Mix Doctor

docs.title: French Meringue
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 9-in pie 15 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 2 egg whites
  • 0.25 tsp cream of tartar
  • 3 Tbsp sugar
  • 4 Tbsp confectioners' sugar (alternative)
  • 0.5 tsp vanilla

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Preheat oven to 325°F to 350°F.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Whip until frothy 2 egg whites

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Add 1/4 teaspoon cream of tartar

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Whip them until they are stiff, but not dry; until they stand in peaks that lean over slightly when the beater is removed. Beat in, 1 tablespoon at a time 3 tablespoons sugar or 4 tablespoons confectioners' sugar (alternative).

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Do not overheat. Beat in 1/2 teaspoon vanilla

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Spread on pie and bake 10 to 15 minutes, depending on the thickness of the meringue.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • Joy of Cooking

docs.title: Italian Meringue
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 9-in pie 30 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 0.5 cup water
  • 0.25 tsp cream of tartar
  • 1 cup sugar
  • 3 egg whites

docs.title: Instructions
docs.text:
Note

This classic Italian meringue does not require baking, because the egg whites are already cooked by the hot syrup. You may want to brown it lightly in a 350° oven. This meringue is not so stiff as Swiss or French.

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Heat in a heavy pan and stir until dissolved 1/2 cup water, 1/4 teaspoon cream of tartar, and 1 cup sugar.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: When the syrup is boiling cover and cook about 3 minutes or until the steam has washed down any crystals that may have formed on the sides of the pan. Uncover and cook without stirring to 238° to 240°. Pour the syrup very gradually onto 3 well-beaten egg whites beating constantly, until this frosting meringue is cool and ready to be spread on the pie filling or pudding.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • Joy of Cooking

docs.title: Swiss Meringue
docs.text: Total Time 10 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 4 large egg whites
  • 1 cup sugar (189 g)
  • 1 pinch salt
  • 2 tsp vanilla

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 stand mixer
  • 1 saucepan

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: In the bowl of a stand mixer, combine the egg whites, sugar (189 g) , and salt.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Bring a saucepan with a few inches of water to a simmer. Set the mixer bowl over the simmering water, making sure the water does not touch the bottom of the bowl. Continuously, but gently, stir the mixture until the egg whites are very warm to the touch and the sugar has dissolved, about 4 minutes. Test this by dipping a finger into the mixture and rubbing it between your fingers—the mixture should no longer have any grains of sugar in it and should be very warm to the touch.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: In the bowl of a stand mixer fitted with a whisk attachment, beat the meringue on medium-low speed until foamy, about 2 minutes. Gradually increase the speed and beat until you achieve a stiff peak that droops only slightly when you lift up the whisk, and the bottom and sides of the bowl no longer feel warm to the touch, about 4 minutes. Add the vanilla and beat a few seconds to mix it in.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Swiss meringue is best when used immediately and served the same day. Do not refrigerated it in bulk or it will lose its lightness and become weepy. However, you can frost your cake or cupcakes and refrigerate overnight if needed; the meringue will be less airy the next day, but still fine.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.simplyrecipes.com/recipes/how_to_make_swiss_meringue/

docs.title: All-Purpose Flaky Pastry Dough
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 1 9-in or 10-in double crust 30 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 450 g all-purpose flour
  • 2 Tbsp granulated sugar
  • 1 tsp salt
  • 283 g (2.5 sticks) unsalted butter
  • 227 g ice water

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 pastry blender
  • 1 fork

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, sugar, and salt.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Add the butter to the bowl with the dry ingredients and toss, separating the pieces and coating them in the flour mixture. Use your fingertips to quickly break and smash the pieces of butter into smaller bits (it’s OK if some of the butter is left in large pieces; you’ll break it up more in the next step). Make a well in the center of the bowl and add 2/3 cup (152g) of the ice water. Toss with a fork to distribute the water until you have a clumpy mixture with lots of dry spots.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Tip the contents of the bowl out onto a clean work surface. Use a bench knife or bowl scraper to chop up the mixture, breaking up the clumps and pieces of butter and periodically using the scraper to toss and push the mixture back into a pile. Continue to chop and toss the mixture until it’s broken down into small, uniform pieces with very few floury spots and the butter pieces are no larger than a pea. This process helps bring the dough together without working it excessively, increasing tenderness.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Push the mixture into a pile and squeeze it with your hands so it holds together in large pieces. If you still have some dry floury areas, move any large pieces to one side, leaving the dry bits in the pile. Drizzle 1/2 tablespoon of ice water over the floury area, then use the bench knife or bowl scraper in the same chopping motion to evenly distribute the water. Squeeze the dough to bring it together, move the large pieces to the side, then repeat with more ice water as needed until no dry flour remains on the surface.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Use your hands to pat the dough firmly into a square, then use a floured rolling pin to flatten the square until it’s 3/4" thick. Pat around the four sides with your hands or the scraper to square off and compact the dough then cut it in half.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Lift one half up (again, using the scraper to help) and place it directly on top of the other. Use the scraper to lift the stack of dough and dust underneath with more flour, then roll over it with the pin to flatten and lengthen it slightly, dusting the top with flour if needed to prevent sticking. Cut the dough in half again, this time crosswise, and stack the halves again. The stacking and flattening increases the flakiness of the dough and further distributes the moisture, making it easier to roll out.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Working quickly, use the scraper to loosen the dough from the surface and dust underneath and on top with more flour, then flatten it with the rolling pin into a long rectangle measuring 3/4" thick.

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text: If making the Walnut & Oat Slab Pie leave the rectangle whole. If making a round pie, cut the rectangle in half crosswise to make 2 equal portions. Whatever form the dough takes when it’s chilled is the form it will most easily assume when being rolled out, so if it’s destined to be round, as for a pie, use the heel of your hand to round off any corners and press the portion(s) into more of a disk shape. If it’s destined to be rectangular, pat around the sides to straighten and square off the corners.

docs.title: Step 9
docs.text: Wrap each piece in your favorite reusable wrapper, maintaining the round or rectangular shape. Roll over the wrapped pieces with the rolling pin to flatten the dough and force it to fill out the wrap (applying this pressure will help prevent cracking later).

docs.title: Step 10
docs.text: Transfer the dough to the refrigerator and chill until it’s very cold and firm, at least 2 hours. If a recipe requires a single portion of dough, freeze the other portion and save it for another use.

docs.title: Step 11
docs.text: To roll out the chilled pastry dough: Remove the cold pastry dough from the refrigerator and let it sit at room temperature for a minute or two to soften slightly. Unwrap the dough and place it on a lightly floured surface.

docs.title: Step 12
docs.text: Use a rolling pin to beat the dough evenly across the surface, applying enough force to leave an imprint but not enough to crack or splinter it. If rolling it into a round, lift and rotate the dough every couple of whacks to keep the round shape. If rolling it into a square or rectangle, beat the dough lengthwise across the entire surface, then rotate it 90° (a quarter turn) and beat crosswise, repeating several times in both directions. Continue to beat the dough, lifting it frequently and adding more flour if needed to prevent sticking, until it’s just under 1/2" thick. This will make the dough pliable and easier to roll out while still cold.

docs.title: Step 13
docs.text:
Dust underneath and on top of the dough with more flour, then roll it out, frequently lifting and rotating the dough to work it into a round, or turning it 90° every so often and rolling it lengthwise and crosswise for a square or rectangle. Continue to roll, keeping the dough moving on the work surface and dusting it with more flour as needed to prevent sticking, until you have the size and/or thickness specified in the recipe. If it starts to feel soft or sticky, transfer the dough to a baking sheet and refrigerate until it’s cold and firm, about 10 minutes, then proceed.

Note

Store unbaked pastry dough, well-wrapped, in the refrigerator for 2 days or in the freezer for up to 2 months.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.kingarthurbaking.com/recipes/all-purpose-flaky-pastry-dough-recipe

docs.title: Basic Pastry
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 1 9-in or 10-in double crust 30 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 2.5 cups all-purpose flour
  • 1.25 tsp salt
  • 0.75 cup vegetable shortening
  • 3 Tbsp unsalted butter
  • 6 Tbsp ice water
  • 1 Tbsp ice water

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 pastry blender
  • 1 fork

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: For a 9-in single-crust pie, use half the recipe.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Stir together all-purpose flour and salt.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Add chilled vegetable shortening and cold unsalted butter.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Cut half of the shortening into the flour mixture with a pastry blender or work it in lightly with the tips of your fingers until it has the consistency of cornmeal. Cut the remaining half into the dough until it is pea-sized. Sprinkle the dough with ice water.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Blend the water gently into the dough until it just holds together; you may lift the ingredients with a fork, allowing the moisture to spread. If necessary to hold the ingredients together, add 1 tsp to 1 Tbsp ice water.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Divide the dough in half, shape each into a disk, and wrap in plastic wrap. To fill the bake, see individual recipes.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • Joy of Cooking

docs.title: Chocolate Biscuit
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 2 layer 8 inch round cake 45 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 176 g granulated sugar
  • 319 g (11) egg whites
  • 176 g granulated sugar
  • 226 g (11) egg yolks
  • 102 g unsweetened cocoa powder

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 sheet pans
  • 1 parchment or a silicone mat
  • 1 stand mixer
  • 1 rubber spatula
  • 1 offset spatula
  • 1 paring knife

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Preheat your oven to 400°F (205°C). Line 2 sheet pans with parchment or a silicone mat. Spray the parchment/silicone mats with a thin layer of non-stick cooking spray.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: In a stand mixer fitted with a whisk attachment, whip the egg yolks and the first measurement of the granulated sugar (176g) on high speed until light and fluffy (the mixture should be pale and almost white), 4 to 5 minutes. Transfer the mixture to a bowl and set aside. Clean and fully dry the stand mixer bowl.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text:
Make a French meringue: In the stand mixer, whip together the (11) egg whites on medium-high speed until bubbles start to form. While continuing to mix, slowly stream in the second measurement of the granulated sugar (176g) and continue mixing until the meringue is shiny and glossy with medium-stiff peaks. Once you remove the bowl from the mixer, do not let the meringues stand too long or they will clump. Slowly and steadily continue folding them with a rubber spatula to prevent this from happening.

Tip

When making meringue, make sure your bowl is clean and dried thoroughly. Any excess moisture in the bowl may prevent the egg whites from whipping into that fluffy, voluminous texture you’re aiming for.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Now you’ll combine the two mixtures together, but first, you’ll need to lighten the denser (11) egg yolk mixture with a little of the light-and-airy meringue (this way, when you fold it all together, the meringue won’t totally deflate). First, take 1/3 of the meringue and fold it into the yolk mixture with a spatula until combined. Carefully fold in the unsweetened cocoa powder until it’s evenly combined. Then gradually add the remaining 2/3 of the meringue, little by little, gently folding to combine before each addition. Be careful not to overmix, as it'll cause the fluffy texture to deflate and you’ll end up with a dense cake.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text:
Pour half of the batter onto the first sheet pan, leveling it out with an offset spatula to within 1/2 inch of the edge of the mat/pan. Repeat with the rest of the batter on the second sheet pan.

Tip

This cake is known as a biscuit, which is a French-style cake that’s thin and a bit dry in texture, so you’ll have to add moisture by either soaking it with a syrup soak and/or layering it with mousse to make a layered cake.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text:
Bake both sheet pans for 6 to 8 minutes, or until the middle is fully set.

Tip

Never just rely on a timer, as every oven is different; there are three ways to know if the cake is done: Jiggle it: the cake should still be a little bouncy in the middle. Nudge it: press the top gently; it should bounce back. Stick it: stick a cake tester (or toothpick or paring knife) into the center, and if it comes out clean, you’re done!

Tip

People often burn chocolate cakes because it's harder to tell if it’s cooked through with the dark color of the batter. So be extra careful and check even before the suggested bake time.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text:
Remove the cake from the oven and let cool in the pan. When cooled, use a paring knife to run along the edges of the cake to loosen it from the sides of the pan. Invert the sheet of cake onto another sheet pan or a countertop lined with parchment. Gently peel off the parchment paper or silicone mat. Using your 8-inch round cake ring as a guide, use a paring knife to cut out two even discs of cake from the inside of the ring. Set aside, covered in plastic wrap until ready to use.

Tip

Cutting the cake from inside the ring, as opposed to the outside, ensures that it will fit perfectly in the cake ring when it comes time to assemble the finished cake. Also, don’t discard the cake scraps! They’re always a pastry chef’s favorite. Break them into small pieces to sprinkle on top of ice cream, or enjoy by the handful as is.

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text: Best enjoyed fresh the day-of. The cake can also be made in advance. In the fridge: cover in plastic wrap and keep chilled for up to 3 days. In the freezer: cover in plastic wrap and store in an airtight container in the freezer for no more than 2 to 3 weeks. To defrost, keep it in the plastic wrap and place in the fridge for 2 to 3 hours until it is moist and soft again. Always defrost in the fridge to keep bacteria from developing, and keep it wrapped so that condensation forms outside the plastic wrap.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • Dominique Ansel

docs.title: Danish Pastry
docs.text: Total Time 9.13 hours

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 500 g strong white bread flour
  • 10 g salt
  • 80 g caster sugar
  • 10 g instant yeast
  • 2 medium eggs
  • 90 ml cool water
  • 125 ml tepid full-fat milk
  • 250 g chilled unsalted Normandy butter

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 stand mixer
  • 1 dough hook
  • 1 plastic bag
  • 1 fridge

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Put the strong white bread flour into the bowl of a stand mixer fitted with a dough hook. Add the salt and caster sugar to one side of the bowl and the instant yeast to the other. Add the eggs, cool water and tepid full-fat milk and mix on a slow speed for 2 minutes, then on a medium speed for 6 minutes.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Tip the flour out onto a lightly floured surface and shape into a ball. Dust with flour, put into a clean plastic bag and chill in the fridge for an hour.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: On a lightly floured surface, roll out your chilled dough to a rectangle, about 50 x 20cm and about 1cm thick. Flatten the chilled unsalted Normandy butter to a rectangle, about 33 x 19cm, by bashing it with a rolling pin. Lay the butter on the dough so that it covers the bottom two-thirds of it. Make sure that it is positioned neatly and comes almost to the edges.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Fold the exposed dough at the top down one-third of the butter. Now gently cut off the exposed bit of butter, without going through the dough, and put it on the top of the dough you have just folded down. Fold the bottom half of the dough up. You will now have a sandwich of two layers of butter and three of dough. Pinch the edges lightly to seal in the butter. Put the dough back in the plastic bag and chill for 1 hour to harden butter.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Take the dough out of the bag and put it on the lightly floured surface with the short end towards you. Now roll it out to a rectangle, about 50 x 20cm, as before. This time fold up one-third of the dough and then fold the top third down on top. This is called a single turn. Put the dough back in the plastic bag and chill for another hour. Repeat this stage twice more, putting the dough back into the fridge between turns.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Your dough now needs to be left in the fridge for 8 hours, or overnight, to rest and rise slightly. It is then ready to use.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.paulhollywood.com/post/danish-pastry-dough

docs.title: Deluxe Butter Pastry
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 1 9-in or 10-in double crust 20 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 1 Basic Pastry Dough
  • 2 sticks cold unsalted butter
  • 0.25 cup chilled vegetable shortening

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Prepare Basic Pastry Dough substituting 1 cup (2 sticks) cold unsalted butter for the vegetable shortening or lard and 1/4 cup chilled vegetable shortening for the butter.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • Joy of Cooking

docs.title: Dominique Ansel's Pâte à Choux
docs.text: Total Time 40 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 0.33 cup water
  • 4 Tbsp whole milk
  • 5.5 Tbsp unsalted butter
  • 1 tsp sugar
  • 1 tsp salt
  • 0.67 cup all-purpose flour
  • 4 eggs

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 medium pot
  • 1 wooden spoon
  • 1 stand mixer
  • 1 sheet tray
  • 1 parchment paper
  • 1 pastry brush

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Preheat the oven to 375°F.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Combine the water, whole milk, unsalted butter, sugar and salt in a medium pot over medium heat and bring to a boil.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Add the all-purpose flour and stir, using a wooden spoon, until the mixture comes together, about 5 minutes. Continue to stir until the dough begins to dry out and pull away from the sides of the pot, about 2 minutes.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Transfer the dough to the bowl of a stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment. Whip on low speed, adding the 3 eggs one at a time, making sure each egg is fully incorporated before adding the next.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Cut the tip of a piping bag and insert a plain round tip. Using a rubber spatula, transfer the choux to the piping bag. Line a sheet tray with parchment paper and pipe 5 rows of choux dough, 5 in each row, about 1.5 inches in diameter, leaving a 1 inch gap between rounds. Using a pastry brush, lightly brush the egg wash on each choux. Bake on a center rack at 375° for 10 minutes. Rotate the sheet tray and bake for an additional 10 minutes until the mounds are puffed and golden brown.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text:
Remove the sheet tray from the pan and allow to cool for a few minutes before serving.

Note

For cheese puffs, add 2 ounces (about 1/2 cup) grated Comté or Gruyère cheese after all of the eggs have been incorporated in step 3.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.tastingtable.com/687285/how-to-make-dominique-ansels-pate-a-choux/

docs.title: Empanada Pastry
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 12-15 1 hour 15 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 3 cups all-purpose flour
  • 0.25-0.5 tsp salt
  • 6 oz butter
  • 1 egg
  • 0.25-0.5 cup water or milk

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text: • 1 food processor

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Mix the all-purpose flour and salt in a food processor.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Add the butter and pulse.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Add the egg and the water or milk (in small increments) and continue pulsing until a clumpy dough forms.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: To make the empanada dough by hand, follow the same instruction but use your hands to mix the ingredients together.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Split the dough into 2 large ball, flatten slightly into the shape of disks. The dough can be used immediately or refrigerated until ready to use (1-2 days max).

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Roll out the dough into a thin sheet and cut out round disc shapes for empanadas (use round molds or a small plate). You can also make small individual balls with the dough and roll out each individual ball to a round shape (doesn’t need to be perfectly round) – if you have a tortilla press you can use it to flatten the dough balls.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Use immediately, or store in the refrigerator/freezer to use later.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.laylita.com/recipes/how-to-make-empanada-dough/

docs.title: Filo
docs.text: Total Time 25 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 500 g all-purpose flour
  • 2 tsp baking powder
  • 0.25 tsp salt
  • 2 eggs
  • 170 g full-fat Greek yogurt
  • 90 ml vegetable oil
  • 50 g melted unsalted butter
  • 1 Tbsp white wine vinegar
  • some cornflour

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text: • 1 mixing bowl

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Sift the all-purpose flour, baking powder, and salt into a mixing bowl and make a well in the center.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: In a separate bowl, whisk the eggs, full-fat Greek yogurt, vegetable oil, melted unsalted butter and white wine vinegar together until smooth.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Pour the egg mixture into the flour and bring everything together to form a dough.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Tip out the dough onto a lightly floured work surface and knead it for 10 minutes, until smooth, then divide it into six pieces.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Shape each piece into a ball, then place the balls on a plate or baking tray, cover them with a clean tea towel and leave them to rest for 15 minutes.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Lightly dust the work surface with cornflour. Roll out one of the balls of dough to a circle about 30cm diameter. Dust the top with cornflour, then fold the right-hand edge to the center and the left-hand edge to the center, so that they meet.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Dust again with cornflour, then fold the top down to the center and the bottom up to the center, to give a rough square.

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text: Dust again with cornflour. Take each corner and fold them inwards so they meet in the middle to make a smaller square.

docs.title: Step 9
docs.text: Dust again with cornflour, then repeat Step 8, folding the corners into the middle again to give an even smaller square. Turn the dough over (joins underneath), cover it and leave it to rest for 15 minutes.

docs.title: Step 10
docs.text: Repeat with the remaining five balls of dough until you have six small squares.

docs.title: Step 11
docs.text: Roll out one of the squares of dough to a rough 30 cm diameter circle.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://thegreatbritishbakeoff.co.uk/recipes/all/paul-hollywood-baklava/

docs.title: Flaky Olive Oil Dough
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 1 9-inch pie or tart crust 60 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 227 g all-purpose flour
  • 13 g granulated sugar
  • 1 tsp salt
  • 0.25 tsp baking powder
  • 96 g olive oil
  • 57 g cold tap water

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 medium bowl
  • 1 fork
  • 1 parchment paper
  • 1 plastic

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: In a medium bowl, whisk together the all-purpose flour, granulated sugar, salt, and baking powder to combine. Make a well in the center of the dry ingredients.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Pour 6 tablespoons of the olive oil (2.9 oz / 83 g) into the well, and use a fork to incorporate some of the flour from around the sides of the bowl until you have shaggy pieces. Break up the pieces with your fingertips so they're no larger than a pea.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Drizzle 1/4 cup cold tap water into the bowl, stirring constantly with a fork, then switch back to your hands and knead the mixture inside the bowl until a dough comes together. Transfer the dough to a work surface, leaving any floury bits behind in the bowl, then add more water 1 teaspoon at a time to the bowl to bring the rest of the dough together, add it to the rest of the dough.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Knead the dough a few times just until it's smooth (you don't want to work the dough too much, although the oil does help prevent gluten development, thus protecting it against toughness). Press the dough into a 2-inch-thick square, wrap it tightly in plastic, and refrigerate for 1 hour.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text:
Roll out the dough between two large sheets of parchment paper, periodically peeling off and repositioning each piece of the parchment, one at a time, for wrinkle-free rolling, to a 1/4-inch-thick square.

Tip

You can skip the step of brushing the dough with more oil and rolling it up if you want to save time - the baked dough will still turn out flaky, just not as flaky.

Tip

Use a firm hand to roll out the dough—this is not as delicate a pastry as pie dough, nor is it as prone to stickiness, since there's no butter to soften. If the dough isn't rolling out easily and stubbornly springs back, cover it and let it rest on the surface for 10 minutes before going over it again with the rolling pin.

Note

The dough, wrapped tightly and refrigerated, will keep up to 3 days or can be frozen up to 1 month (place in a resealable plastic bag before freezing). Let the frozen dough thaw overnight in the refrigerator before using.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Remove the top sheet of parchment paper and brush the remaining 1 tablespoon oil across the surface of the dough.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Starting at the side closest to you, fold up the dough into a flat, loose roll.

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text: Flatten the roll with the heel of your hand across the entire length. Roll out the dough into a rough rectangle that's about ¼ inch thick, then bring the left and right sides of the dough inward to fold it in thirds (this step ensures lots of flaky layers).

docs.title: Step 9
docs.text: Wrap the dough in plastic, pressing out any air, and press down on the dough with the heel of your hand to flatten it into a ½-inch-thick disk. Refrigerate the dough until it's relaxed, at least 30 minutes and up to 3 days. It's now ready to use.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • Dessert Person

docs.title: Hot Water Crust
docs.text: Total Time 20 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 265 g all-purpose flour
  • 55 g strong white bread flour
  • 55 g unsalted butter
  • 65 g vegetable shortening
  • 1 tsp salt
  • 135 ml boiling water

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 bowl
  • 1 pan
  • 1 spoon

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Put all-purpose flour and strong white bread flour into a bowl. Add the cubed unsalted butter and rub in with your fingertips.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text:
Danger

Melting vegetable shortening on the stovetop in water can cause the mixture to explode. Watch carefully and don't overcook.

Heat the vegetable shortening in a pan until melted. Dissolve the salt in the boiling water, then add to the melted vegetable shortening.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Pour this liquid into the flour. Mix with a spoon then, as soon as it is cool enough, tip the dough onto a lightly floured surface and work together into a ball. Be careful that the dough is not too hot when you start to work it.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Once the dough ball is formed, leave it to cool slightly. If it’s still lumpy, work it a minute or two longer.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Divide the dough in two, making one piece slightly bigger than the other.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text:
• https://www.paulhollywood.com/post/pork-pies
  • https://youtu.be/1nArqhRyszw
  • https://youtu.be/f0sUuossGNQ
  • https://youtu.be/Ee-8PckT1cA

docs.title: Pat-in-the-Pan Butter Dough
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 1 9 inch pie crust 0 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 0.5 cup all-purpose flour
  • 0.5 tsp salt
  • 0.5 cup unsalted butter
  • 3 Tbsp heavy cream

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 bowl
  • 1 food processor

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Whisk together in a bowl or process in a food processor for 10 seconds 1/2 cups all-purpose flour, 1/2 teaspoon salt

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Add 1/2 cup (1 stick) unsalted butter, cut into 8 pieces, softened.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Mash with the back of a fork or process until the mixture resembles coarse crumbs.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Drizzle over the top 2 to 3 tablespoons heavy cream.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Stir or process until the crumbs look damp and hold together when pinched.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: To shape the crust for a pie or tart, pat the dough evenly over the bottom and up the sides of a 9-inch pie pan or a 9 or 10 inch two-piece tart pan, or roll it with a rolling pin between sheets of wax paper and flip it into the pan. If making a pie, crimp or flute the rim. To bake, thoroughly prick the sides and bottom of the crust with a fork. Bake in a preheated 425°F oven (400°F for shortbread) until the crust is golden brown, 18 to 22 minutes, pricking the bottom once or twice if it bubbles. If you will be filling the crust with an uncooked mixture that requires further baking, whisk together 1 large egg yolk and a pinch of salt, and brush the warm crust with this glaze, then return to the oven and bake until the glaze sets, 1 to 2 minutes.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: This dough will also make eight 3/2-inch tartlet crusts. For tartlets, divide the dough into 8 pieces and into molds or shape over inverted muffin tins. If baking press "blind," without a filling, bake at 450°F until firm and it golden brown, 12 to 15 minutes, pricking the crusts once or twice if they bubble.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • Joy of Cooking

docs.title: Pat-in-the-Pan Shortbread Dough
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 1 9-in single pie  crust 1.37 hours

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 1.25 cups all-purpose flour
  • 0.33 cup sugar
  • 1 tsp lemon zest
  • 0.25 tsp salt
  • 0.5 cup unsalted butter
  • 1 large egg yolk

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 bowl
  • 1 fork
  • 1 9-inch pie pan

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: When baked, this rich, sweet dough resembles a shortbread cookie. Use it for a cream pie, a lemon tart, a fresh fruit tart with pastry cream, or any other pie or tart with a creamy or buttery filling.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Whisk together in a bowl of process in a food processor for 10 seconds all-purpose flour, sugar, lemon zest, and salt.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Add unsalted butter cut into 8 pieces.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Mash with the back of a fork or process until the mixture resembles coarse crumbs. Add egg yolk.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Mix with spatula or process just until the dough comes together in a ball. If the dough is too soft and sticky to work with, wrap it and refrigerate for at least 30 minutes (up to 2 days). Grease or butter the bottom of a 9-inch pie pan or 9.5- or 10-inch two-piece tart pan or eight 3.5-inch tartlet pan. Dust the pans with flour, and tap out the excess. Pat the dough evenly over the bottom and up the sides of the prepared pan. Thoroughly prick the bottom and sides with a fork. Refrigerate for 30 minutes. Preheat the oven to 400°F. Bake until deep golden brown, 18 to 22 minutes for crust, 19 minutes for tartlets.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • Joy of Cooking

docs.title: Puff Pastry
docs.text: Total Time 9.17 hours

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 150 g chilled strong white bread flour
  • 150 g chilled plain flour
  • some salt
  • 2 large eggs
  • 100 ml cold water
  • 250 g chilled unsalted butter

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 large bowl
  • 1 plastic bag
  • 1 fridge
  • 1 rolling pin

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Put the chilled strong white bread flour, chilled plain flour, salt, eggs, and cold water into a large bowl and gently mix to an even dough with your fingers. Transfer the dough to a lightly floured surface and knead it for 5 to 10 minutes until smooth. The dough should feel a little tight at this stage. Shape the dough into a ball and put it into a plastic bag in the fridge to chill overnight, or for at least 7 hours.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Flatten the chilled unsalted butter into a rectangle, about 40 x 19cm, by battering it down with your rolling pin. (You may find this easier to do this if you sandwich the butter between 2 sheets of cling film). Return to the fridge for 1 hour to harden the butter again.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Roll out your dough to a rectangle, about 60 x 20cm wide. Put the butter on the dough so it covers the bottom two-thirds. Make sure that it is positioned neatly and covers almost to the edges.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Lift the exposed dough at the top and fold it down over half of the butter, then fold the butter-covered bottom half of the dough up over the top. You will now have a sandwich of two layers of butter and three of dough. Pinch the edges together to seal. Put it back in a plastic bag and chill for 1 hour.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Take the dough out of the bag and put it on a lightly floured surface with a short end towards you. Roll out to a rectangle as before, keeping the edges as even as possible. Fold the top quarter down and the bottom quarter up so they meet neatly in the center. Then fold the dough in half along the center line. This is called a book turn. Chill in the bag for 1 hour.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Take the dough out of the bag, put it on a lightly floured surface with the short end towards you and roll into a rectangle as before. This time, fold down one-third of the dough and then fold up the bottom third to make a neat square. This is called a single turn. Chill in the bag for another hour.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Bring your dough out again and do a single turn as previously. Chill in the bag overnight. Your dough is now ready to use.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.paulhollywood.com/post/puff-pastry

docs.title: Pâte Brisée
docs.text: Serves  Total Time double crust pie 2.00 hours

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 450 g all-purpose flour
  • 2 Tbsp granulated sugar
  • 1 tsp salt
  • 20 Tbsp (283 g) unsalted butter
  • 2/3 cup (152 g) ice water

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 large bowl
  • 1 fork
  • 1 bench knife or bowl scraper
  • 1 rolling pin
  • 1 reusable wrapper

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: In a large bowl, whisk together the all-purpose flour, granulated sugar, and salt.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Add the cold unsalted butter to the bowl with the dry ingredients and toss, separating the pieces and coating them in the flour mixture. Use your fingertips to quickly break and smash the pieces of butter into smaller bits (it’s OK if some of the butter is left in large pieces; you’ll break it up more in the next step). Make a well in the center of the bowl and add 2/3 cup (152g) of the ice water. Toss with a fork to distribute the water until you have a clumpy mixture with lots of dry spots.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Tip the contents of the bowl out onto a clean work surface. Use a bench knife or bowl scraper to chop up the mixture, breaking up the clumps and pieces of butter and periodically using the scraper to toss and push the mixture back into a pile. Continue to chop and toss the mixture until it’s broken down into small, uniform pieces with very few floury spots and the butter pieces are no larger than a pea. This process helps bring the dough together without working it excessively, increasing tenderness.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Push the mixture into a pile and squeeze it with your hands so it holds together in large pieces. If you still have some dry floury areas, move any large pieces to one side, leaving the dry bits in the pile. Drizzle 1/2 tablespoon of ice water over the floury area, then use the bench knife or bowl scraper in the same chopping motion to evenly distribute the water. Squeeze the dough to bring it together, move the large pieces to the side, then repeat with more ice water as needed until no dry flour remains on the surface.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Use your hands to pat the dough firmly into a square, then use a floured rolling pin to flatten the square until it’s 3/4 inch thick. Pat around the four sides with your hands or the scraper to square off and compact the dough then cut it in half.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Lift one half up (again, using the scraper to help) and place it directly on top of the other. Use the scraper to lift the stack of dough and dust underneath with more flour, then roll over it with the rolling pin to flatten and lengthen it slightly, dusting the top with flour if needed to prevent sticking. Cut the dough in half again, this time crosswise, and stack the halves again. The stacking and flattening increases the flakiness of the dough and further distributes the moisture, making it easier to roll out.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Working quickly, use the scraper to loosen the dough from the surface and dust underneath and on top with more flour, then flatten it with the rolling pin into a long rectangle measuring 3/4" thick.

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text: If making the Walnut & Oat Slab Pie leave the rectangle whole. If making a round pie, cut the rectangle in half crosswise to make 2 equal portions. Whatever form the dough takes when it’s chilled is the form it will most easily assume when being rolled out, so if it’s destined to be round, as for a pie, use the heel of your hand to round off any corners and press the portion(s) into more of a disk shape. If it’s destined to be rectangular, pat around the sides to straighten and square off the corners.

docs.title: Step 9
docs.text: Wrap each piece in your favorite reusable wrapper, maintaining the round or rectangular shape. Roll over the wrapped pieces with the rolling pin to flatten the dough and force it to fill out the wrap (applying this pressure will help prevent cracking later).

docs.title: Step 10
docs.text: Transfer the dough to the refrigerator and chill until it’s very cold and firm, at least 2 hours. If a recipe requires a single portion of dough, freeze the other portion and save it for another use.

docs.title: Step 11
docs.text: To roll out the chilled pastry dough: Remove the cold pastry dough from the refrigerator and let it sit at room temperature for a minute or two to soften slightly. Unwrap the dough and place it on a lightly floured surface.

docs.title: Step 12
docs.text: Use a rolling pin to beat the dough evenly across the surface, applying enough force to leave an imprint but not enough to crack or splinter it. If rolling it into a round, beat the dough diagonally in both directions to make an X, then roll lengthwise and widthwise. Lift and rotate the dough every couple of whacks to keep the round shape. If rolling it into a square or rectangle, beat the dough lengthwise across the entire surface, then rotate it 90° (a quarter turn) and beat crosswise, repeating several times in both directions. Continue to beat the dough, lifting it frequently and adding more flour if needed to prevent sticking, until it’s just under 1/2 inch thick. This will make the dough pliable and easier to roll out while still cold.

docs.title: Step 13
docs.text: Dust underneath and on top of the dough with more flour, then roll it out, frequently lifting and rotating the dough to work it into a round, or turning it 90° every so often and rolling it lengthwise and crosswise for a square or rectangle. Continue to roll, keeping the dough moving on the work surface and dusting it with more flour as needed to prevent sticking, until you have the size and/or thickness specified in the recipe. If it starts to feel soft or sticky, transfer the dough to a baking sheet and freeze until it’s cold and firm, about 10 minutes, then proceed.

docs.title: Sources
docs.text:
• https://www.kingarthurbaking.com/recipes/all-purpose-flaky-pastry-dough-recipe
  • https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vT4Kk9v3B5Y
  • https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0rHT0QPvLTc&t=2807s
  • https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=k6LyV7A6UmU&t=770s

docs.title: Pâte À Choux
docs.text: Total Time 1.20 hours

docs.title: Ratio
docs.text: Flour  Butter  Egg  Water 1 part 1 part 2 parts 2 parts

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 1 cup (227 g) water or milk
  • 8 Tbsp (113 g) unsalted butter
  • 0.38 tsp salt
  • 1.25 cups (150 g) flour
  • 4 large eggs
  • 2 tsp granulated sugar (optional)1

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 saucepan
  • 1 spoon

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Preheat the oven to 425°F.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Put the water, unsalted butter, and salt in a saucepan on low heat until the butter melts. Once melted, bring the mixture to a rolling boil.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Remove it from the heat and add the flour all at once. Stir vigorously.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Return the pan to the burner and cook over medium heat, stirring all the while, until the mixture forms a ball; this should take only about a minute. A film should form on the bottom of the pan.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Remove the pan from the heat and spread on the inside of the mixer bowl to let the mixture cool for 5 to 10 minutes, to 140°F. It will still feel hot, but you should be able to hold a finger in it for a few seconds.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: In the mixer, beat in the room temperature eggs one at a time; the mixture will become fluffy and glossy. Check that the mixture is then enough by making a V when dripped from the mixer paddle. The mixture should be thick enough that when a finger is dragged through it to make a trough, the sides of the trough continue to stand. Beat for at least 2 minutes after adding the last egg.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Form the choux paste into whatever shape you desire, using a spoon, or by putting the dough in a pastry bag and piping it.

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text: Bake for 15 minutes, then reduce the oven temperature to 375°F and bake for an additional 15 minutes. Turn off the oven, open the door a crack, and leave the pastry inside to cool for 30 minutes. Remove from the oven to cool completely. Carefully split the pastry, fill, and frost as desired.

docs.title: Source
docs.text:
• The King Arthur Baking Company All-Purpose Baker's Companion

  1. Sugar is optional. At the very least, choux should be seasoned with salt. If it's going to be used for a dessert, a small amount of sugar can also be added to gently push it in a sweet direction. ↩

docs.title: Rough Puff Pastry
docs.text: Total Time 30 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 300 g all-purpose flour
  • 1 pinch salt
  • 50 g chilled butter
  • 120 g frozen butter

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text: • 1 bowl

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Mix the all-purpose flour and salt together in a bowl. Rub in the chilled butter using your fingertips until the mixture resembles breadcrumbs. Gradually add enough water to form a dough (about 4-6 tablespoons of water).

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Roll the dough out into a rectangle on a lightly floured work surface.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Grate half of the frozen butter over the bottom two thirds of the dough. Fold down the top third and fold up the bottom third as if folding a letter.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Turn the folded dough through 90 degrees and roll it out into a rectangle again. Repeat the process of adding the remaining frozen butter and fold as before.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Wrap the dough in cling film and leave to rest in the fridge for 30 minutes before using.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.bbc.co.uk/food/recipes/cheats_rough_puff_pastry_91549

docs.title: Sweet Pastry
docs.text: Total Time 15 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 165 g plain flour
  • 25 g ground almonds
  • 120 g chilled unsalted butter
  • 55 g caster sugar
  • 1 medium egg

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 large bowl
  • 1 cling film

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Stir in the plain flour and ground almonds together in a large bowl, then add the cubed chilled unsalted butter and rub in your fingertips until the mixture looks like crumbs. Stir in the caster sugar.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Break in the egg and work into the mixture with your fingers, breaking it together to form a soft dough.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Tip the dough onto a lightly floured work surface and shape it into a ball. Flatten with your fingers to a disc and wrap in cling film. Chill for at least 3 hours before using. 15 minutes.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.paulhollywood.com/post/sweet-pastry

docs.title: Sweet Tart
docs.text: Total Time 15 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 40 g almond flour
  • 130 g all-purpose flour
  • 30 g confectioners' sugar
  • 1/2 tsp Diamond Crystal kosher salt
  • 1 stick (113 g) unsalted butter
  • 1 large egg yolk
  • 1/2 tsp vanilla
  • 4 tsp cold water

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 sheet pan
  • 1 food processor
  • 1 aluminum foil
  • 1 tart pan

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Preheat oven to 350°F. Toast almond flour in sheet pan until fragrant, about 5 to 10 minutes.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Beat and egg yolk with the vanilla and cold water in a small bowl.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Add the confectioners' sugar, all-purpose flour, salt, and almond flour to a food processor and pulse.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Add the 1/2" cubed cold unsalted butter to the food processor and pulse until it looks like coarse corn meal.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Add liquid ingredients to food processor and pulse.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Tip the dough onto a lightly floured work surface and shape it into a ball. Flatten with your fingers to a rectangle and wrap in cling film. Chill for at least 1 hour before using. 15 minutes.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Take the dough out of the fridge and divide almost in half, about 9/16ths using a bench scraper.

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text: Divide the smaller half into six equal strips and use the strips to press into the sides of the pan, ensuring to press the dough into the bottom corner. Using the leftovers from the six strips, fill in some of the cracks where the dough strips come together.

docs.title: Step 9
docs.text: Divide the slightly larger half of the dough and cut it into many thin pieces and press those strips into the bottom of the pan.

docs.title: Step 10
docs.text: Using floured fingers, or a straight sided measuring cup, press and thin the dough into the pan. Use the measuring cup to press the dough into the fluted edge of the pan.

docs.title: Step 11
docs.text: Pop the dough into the freezer for 5 minutes.

docs.title: Step 12
docs.text:
Use a knife to trim the top edge of the pan.

Tip

Hold onto the pie scraps to use to patch any cracks after parbaking.

docs.title: Step 13
docs.text:
Take aluminum foil and press it into the bottom of the pan and press the foil up the sides of the pan. Ensure to keep the top edge of the crust exposed to make it easier to tell when the crust is done in the oven.

Note

There is no need to use pie weights when par-baking.

docs.title: Step 14
docs.text: Parbake the crust for 15 to 20 minutes.

docs.title: Step 15
docs.text: Remove the foil and bake a little longer, until the bottom is set.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Fowgc-J4kCc

docs.title: Vanilla Sablé Shell
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 8 inch tart shell 2.35 hours

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 81 g confectioners’ sugar
  • 127 g unsalted butter, softened
  • 1 large egg
  • 1 vanilla bean
  • 186 g all-purpose flour
  • 47 g cornstarch
  • 0.5 tsp salt

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 stand mixer
  • 1 rubber spatula
  • 1 cutting board
  • 1 paring knife
  • 1 medium bowl
  • 1 parchment paper
  • 1 sheet pan
  • 1 rolling pin
  • 1 sheet pan
  • 1 plastic wrap
  • 1 tart ring
  • 1 paring knife
  • 1 rice or dried beans

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: In a stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, cream the confectioners’ sugar and unsalted butter, softened for 30 seconds on low speed. Add the egg, scrape down the sides of the bowl with a rubber spatula, and mix on medium speed until evenly combined.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Working on a cutting board, press the vanilla bean flat, then use the tip of the paring knife to halve it lengthwise, from tip to tip. Turn the knife blade over and use the back of the blade tip to scrape the seeds from the center of each half.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: In a medium bowl, combine the all-purpose flour, cornstarch, and salt. With the mixer on low speed, stir in the flour mixture and vanilla bean seeds until just combined and no more dry patches are visible, about 10 seconds more. Finish mixing the dough by hand to ensure it is not over-mixed. The dough should be creamy, smooth and have the consistency of cookie dough.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Transfer the dough to a sheet of parchment paper on your work surface and sandwich it with another sheet of parchment paper, flattening it into a 1 inch thick disk. Transfer the dough disk to a sheet pan and refrigerate until firm, 30 to 45 minutes.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text:
Liberally flour the work surface and a rolling pin. Unwrap the dough and transfer it to your work surface. Roll out the dough out into a rectangle about 1/8 inch (3mm) thick. (Make sure to work fast so the dough doesn’t get too warm.) Place on a sheet pan and loosely cover with plastic wrap. Refrigerate for 30 minutes. (If you feel your dough is still cold and easy to work with, you can proceed directly to the next step without chilling the dough sheet.)

Tip

You can also roll out the dough between two sheets of parchment, if you find that your rolling pin is sticking to the dough. It also helps when transferring the rolled out dough onto the sheet pan before chilling in the fridge.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Remove the dough from the refrigerator and slide the dough sheet to a work surface. (Peel off the layers of parchment paper, if using.) Using the tart ring as a guide, cut a circle from the center of the dough sheet that is 1 inch (2.5 cm) wider than the outside of the ring, so that the dough round will be big enough to come up the sides of the ring.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text:
Now: the fun part. You’re going to “fonçage” the tart dough, or form it into a tart shape in the tart ring. First, butter the inside of the tart ring. Line a sheet pan with parchment paper and place the tart ring at the center of the pan. Place the dough round on top of the ring. Push down gently with your fingers and press the dough along the inside of the ring, making sure to get into the inside edges. It’s important here not to press too hard and to keep the tart shell an even thickness so that it doesn’t bake unevenly. Use a paring knife to trim the excess dough hanging over the edge of the ring. Return to the refrigerator to chill for about 30 minutes.

Tip

If your dough starts to feel warm and lose its shape, return it to the fridge for 15 minutes. Chilling the dough allows the gluten to rest. Working with dough that’s too warm or overworked will cause the finished product to shrink while baking.

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text: While the tart shell is chilling, place a rack in the center of the oven and preheat the oven to 350°F (175°C) for conventional or 325°F (160°C) for convection.

docs.title: Step 9
docs.text:
Blind-bake the tart shell by lining it with parchment paper or a large coffee filter so the surface of the dough is completely covered. An easy trick to folding the parchment is similar to folding a snowflake, where you fold it in quarters and keep folding smaller segments to the point, cutting in a curve to form a circle. Press the parchment completely to the side of the tart dough.

Tip

Since tarts are filled with creams or mousses (which can’t be baked), you’ll have to bake the tart shell in advance of filling it.

docs.title: Step 10
docs.text:
Fill with enough rice or dried beans to hold down as weights. Bake the tart on the center rack for 15 to 20 minutes, until it’s a light golden, sandy color and you don’t see any wet spots.

Tip

This particular tart dough won’t rise too much, so if you don’t blind-bake the tart shell in advance, it’s still going to be ok.

docs.title: Step 11
docs.text: Tip: Some tart or pie shell recipes will tell you to “dock” (or pierce with a fork) the bottom of the dough before baking to prevent it from puffing up. You DON’T need to dock this dough as it won’t rise too much, especially as it’s being weighed down with pie weights during the blind-baking process.

docs.title: Step 12
docs.text:
Bake the tart shell on the center rack for 8 minutes. Rotate the pan 180 degrees and bake for 8 minutes more or until the tart shell is a light golden brown. Unmold the tart shell while still warm. Let cool completely at room temperature.

Tip

Always make sure your tart shell is fully cooled before you start assembling any cream-based tarts. If the shell is still too hot or warm when you pipe in your pastry cream, you’ll end up with a soggy-bottomed tart.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • Dominique Ansel

docs.title: Vegan Empanada Pastry
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 12 15 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 1.75 cups cold coconut oil
  • 4 cups all-purpose flour
  • 1 Tbsp granulated sugar
  • 2 tsp baking powder
  • 1.5 tsp salt
  • 1 cup ice water
  • 4 tsp apple cider vinegar

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 food processor
  • 1 bowl
  • 1 large bowl
  • 1 tortilla press or rolling pin

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Using the shredder attachment on a food processor, shred the cold coconut oil. Transfer the shredded oil to a bowl, cover, and refrigerate.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Over a large bowl, sift together the all-purpose flour, granulated sugar, baking powder, and salt.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Place the bowl in the freezer for 15 minutes.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: In a food processor, add the flour mixture and coconut oil and pulse until just combined. With the processor running, add the ice water and apple cider vinegar until a loose dough forms.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Turn the dough out onto a clean surface and use your hands to press the dough into a ball.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: Divide the dough into 12 equal pieces (about 3 ounces each) and roll each one into a ball.

docs.title: Step 7
docs.text: Use a tortilla press or rolling pin to flatten the balls into roughly 6 inch circles.

docs.title: Step 8
docs.text: Place the dough circles between layers of parchment or plastic wrap and chill until ready to use.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • The Gracias Madre Cookbook

docs.title: Dark Chocolate Mirror Glaze
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 8 inch cake 30 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 206 g granulated sugar
  • 142 g heavy cream
  • 12 g gelatin, powdered
  • 60 g cold water
  • 148 g room temperature water
  • 71 g unsweetened cocoa powder

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 medium pot
  • 1 bowl
  • 1 spatula
  • 1 heatproof bowl

docs.title: Instructions
docs.text:
Tip

Make this the day before you’re ready to glaze your cake, as the glaze needs to set in the fridge first before using.

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: In a medium pot, bring granulated sugar and heavy cream to a boil over medium heat, stirring until the sugar dissolves.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: In a small bowl, dissolve the gelatin, powdered in 60 g (1/4 cup) of cold water.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: In a bowl, combine the 148 g (2/3 cups) room temperature water with the unsweetened cocoa powder, stirring with a spatula until it becomes a uniform paste.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text: Stir the bloomed gelatin into the cream-sugar mixture until dissolved, then stir in the cocoa powder paste until combined. Remove the pot from the heat, and pour the glaze mixture through a mesh strainer over a heatproof bowl to remove any clumps of undissolved cocoa powder. Emulsify the mixture with a hand blender to remove any lumps, until smooth.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Cover and chill in the fridge overnight to set, until ready to use.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text: When you’re ready to glaze your cake, remove the glaze from the fridge and heat in the microwave until it’s exactly 86 to 95°F (30 to 35°C), so it’s liquid and pourable and will give your cake a shiny, uniform finish. If it looks like it’s slightly separated, use a hand blender to blitz it together. Make sure to tap the container a bit so that the bubbles from blending go away.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • Dominique Ansel

docs.title: Fruit Glaze (Nappage)
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 500 g 5 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 139 g granulated sugar
  • 346 g water
  • 15 g NH pectin

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 medium pot
  • 1 bowl
  • 1 whisk

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: In a medium pot, bring half of the granulated sugar and all of the water to a boil.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text:
In a bowl, whisk the other half of the sugar with the NH pectin. Once the syrup is boiling, sprinkle the sugar-NH pectin mixture into the syrup, whisking constantly until dissolved.

Tip

It’s important to combine some of the sugar with the NH pectin first, and then sprinkle it into your sugar water slowly. If you were to add just NH pectin in all at once, you’ll end up with a clumpy glaze.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: Continue boiling the syrup, whisking constantly, to dissolve and activate the pectin, about 3 to 4 minutes. Remove from the heat and let cool to room temperature.

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text:
Tip

It is best to make this clear glaze ahead of time, let it cool, the re-warm it just before using.

docs.title: Step 5
docs.text: Pour the nappage into a resealable container and refrigerate until ready to use.

docs.title: Step 6
docs.text:
When you’re ready to glaze, microwave the glaze until it’s hot and liquidy, so it’ll easily and evenly pour on or brush onto fruit (you may add a little water to loosen it up if it’s too thick). If it looks like it’s slightly separated, use a hand blender to blitz it together. Make sure to tap the container a bit so that the bubbles from blending go away. Brush a thin and even layer onto your fruits that are already on your finished cake or tart.

Tip

Because your nappage is hot when brushed on, make sure whatever fruits you’re brushing it onto are cold so that it doesn’t wilt them. The nappage should set solid within 1 minute.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • Dominique Ansel

docs.title: Lemon Glaze
docs.text: Total Time 10 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 1.25 cups confectioners' sugar, sifted
  • 0.25 cup fresh lemon, orange, or lime juice
  • 1 tsp vanilla

docs.title: Instructions
docs.text: This glaze should be spread on warm cakes or Christmas cookies. It has a fine consistency for embedding decorative nuts and fruits.

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Beat together until smooth confectioners' sugar, sifted, fresh lemon, orange, or lime juice, and vanilla.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • Joy of Cooking

docs.title: Milk Glaze
docs.text: Total Time 10 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 0.5 cup confectioners' sugar, sifted
  • 2 tsp hot milk
  • 0.25 tsp vanilla

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: This can be used as a substitute for fondant on small cakes such as petits fours.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Beat together until smooth confectioners' sugar, sifted, hot milk, and vanilla.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: • Joy of Cooking

docs.title: Royal Icing
docs.text: Serves  Total Time 3/4 cup 10 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients - Fresh Egg Whites
docs.text:
• 1 large egg white
  • 0.33 cup confectioners' sugar
  • 0.67 cup confectioners' sugar

docs.title: Ingredients - Powdered Egg Whites
docs.text:
• 1.33 cups confectioners' sugar
  • 1 Tbsp powdered egg whites
  • 2 Tbsp water

docs.title: Cookware
docs.text:
• 1 microwave-safe bowl
  • 1 medium bowl
  • 1 thermometer

Note

This decorative icing dries hard like plaster and is pure white unless tinted with food coloring. Mad with a bit less sugar, it is still spreadable (or you can add a little water); otherwise, it is stiff enough to pipe and makes beautiful filigree, lace, tiny dots, and string work on wedding cakes. The icing is mostly sugar and not especially delicious, though it is used to ice certain traditional wedding (and other) cakes. Our advice is to use it only when decoration is more important than taste and/or in very small quantities. Royal icing is usually made by beating confectioners' sugar into raw egg whites, above. In this version, the egg whites are heated to 160°F as a safeguard against salmonella bacteria; it is a simple process. We also give a variation made with powdered egg whites that does not require heat. Avoid making Royal icing on humid days. Be sure that any container or utensils that comes in contact with the icing is grease-free, and do not store the icing in a plastic container. While working, keep the bowl of icing covered with a damp dish towel and, when not piping, cover the tip of the icing bag as well to prevent drying.

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text: Stir together in a microwave-safe bowl until thoroughly combined egg white and 1/3 cup confectioners' sugar.

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text: Microwave on high until the mixture reaches 160°F on a thermometer (it should not exceed 175°F), 30 to 60 seconds. If you need to take more than one temperature reading, wash the thermometer thoroughly or dip it into a mug of boiling water before taking additional readings. Add and beat on high speed until the icing is cool and holds stiff peaks 2/3 cup confectioners' sugar or as needed.

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text: If the icing is not stiff enough, add more sugar.

docs.title: Step 4
